cmeAnalyses.note: This analysis is based on the calculated longitude of the Active Region 3664, which has rotated behind the west limb.

note: Very wide eruption to the NE in all coronagraphs, notably bright with a twisted flux-rope structure beautifully observed in SOHO LASCO C2. The source is an eruption from new AR 3682, associated with an M4.4 class flare observed in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as field line movement and EUV wave in SDO AIA 171/193/211 starting around 2024-05-14T17:09Z, with a post-eruptive arcade forming shortly after. A massive loop is seen well in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-05-14T17:33Z before it erupts further, not seen often at that scale.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using the source of AR 3682 (N18E72) and finding a great triangulation between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs almost exactly at this point.

note: Bright CME seen due West in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is EUV wave seen beyond the SW limb starting at 2024-05-15T08:18Z in SDO AIA 171/193. Widely opening field lines with northern deflection seen on or just beyond the SW limb at an apparent latitude of S15 (before deflection). This CME overlaps heavily with CME: 2024-05-15T08:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the BULK using candidate source location AR 13664 approximated longitude of W105, and best fit between coronagraphs.

note: Fast CME seen to the WSW in all coronagraphs, overlaps with CME 2024-05-15T08:36Z. The source is an X3.4 flare (partially occulted) from AR 3664 that peaked at 2024-05-15T08:37Z, observed in SDO AIA 131/193/304, and located around the west limb at approximately W100-W105 at this time. Additionally observed source signature as large EUV wave in SDO AIA 171/193/211/304 starting around 2024-05-15T08:18Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the BULK using candidate source location AR 13664 approximated longitude of W105 and best fit between coronagraphs, finding a good triangulation deflected to W114.

note: This CME is a faint but distinct loop visible to the West in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. A distinct source for this CME is not discernable in UV imagery, so it is likely beyond the West limb. This CME is preceded by two much larger CMEs (2024-05-15T08:36Z and 2024-05-15T08:48Z) with source locations that are clearly beyond the limb and are measured to have similar speeds to this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between C3 and STEREO A COR2 frames and inference that the source location is farsided based on UV imagery.

note: CME seen to the NNE in all coronagraphs. Observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 as a loop centered over an unnumbered region on the disk ~N35E35. This loop slowly begins rising around 2024-05-16T06:30Z before before explosively erupting and breaking around 2024-05-16T09:15Z. A broad area of dimming to the N and E of this area is observed in SDO AIA 193 with the eruption, a double ribbon flare is observed in SDO AIA 304 underneath this loop, and a post-eruptive arcade starts forming around 2024-05-16T10:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made by triangulating available SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery with STEREO COR2A using the broad, on-disk source centered ~N35E35 as a basis.

note: This CME is seen to the W/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is a distinct loop of material (a flux rope) seen slowly rising from on or just beyond the SW limb, at an apparent latitude of S25, starting at 2024-05-15T10:00Z in SDO AIA 171/193 as well as in GOES SUVI 284/304/193. The longitude of candidate source location Active Region 13664 was at approximately W105. This CME is visible in only a few frames of STEREO A COR2 due to a short data gap lasting from 2024-05-15T12:23Z-13:38Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Used approximate location of source signature as seen in UV imagery, used candidate source location AR 13664 approximated longitude of W105, and best fit between coronagraphs.

note: Wide CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. A data gap in SOHO that will not backfill from 2024-05-15T13:36Z - 2024-05-15T16:05Z in C2 (T13:40Z-T16:30Z in C3) missed a large portion of the event, but it is still observed in later frames. Associated with an X2.9 flare from new AR 3685 which peaked at 2024-05-15T14:38Z in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as wide field line opening and EUV wave in SDO AIA 171/193/211 with a post-eruptive arcade across all wavelengths, both observed around 2024-05-15T14:20Z with the flare start time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using the X2.9 flare from AR 3685 on or just beyond the SE limb as the source, finding a decent fit between STEREO COR2A and the limited available SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not clearly visible in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in SWPC_CAT due to lack of source location. A best fit between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs could not be obtained due to a range of parameters fitting this CME.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source can be seen as opening field lines starting at 2024-05-15T20:39Z best seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284. A potential candidate active region is Active Region 13664, located around approximately W110.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge using approximate location of AR 3664. No STEREO A COR2 imagery was available for this measurement.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. A source was not clearly visible in EUV imagery, but a candidate source may be old Active Region 3664.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters obtained based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, using potential source location beyond limb. The longitude may vary by approx. +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not clear in EUV imagery, and this CME may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters obtained based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, using potential source location beyond limb. The longitude may vary by approx. +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not clear in EUV imagery, and this CME may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, based on possible backside source location.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, but faint opening field lines and some brightening can be seen around S15E70 in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2024-05-16T07:00Z. The eruption is not clearly visible in STEREO A EUV imagery or other wavelengths.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as potential source location.

note: Faint CME with unclear leading edge visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not clearly visible in EUV imagery and may be beyond the west limb from the perspective of EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME seen to the W in STEREO COR2A, not yet observed in SOHO LASCO due to a lengthy planned data gap that will end at 2024-05-17T02:10Z. The source is far-sided around the west limb, and very likely old AR 3664, estimated to be located around W120 at this time. Best observed as fieldline movement and an EUV wave starting around 2024-05-16T13:34Z in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Final analysis with two coronagraphs now that SOHO LASCO imagery is available.

Preliminary 3-frame measurement with only available STEREO COR2A data, until SOHO LASCO is available (further analysis will follow). Estimated far-sided longitude of AR 3664 at W120 used, but could range W110-W130.

note: Bright three-lobed (and hence wide) heart-shaped northern CME fully covered by a night time data gap in STEREO. Its source is likely a super faint movement of a field line and a movement of matter on the NNW front at 18:54Z seen only in AIA 171 possibly confirming that the CME is backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is conclusive since the CME source is likely on/behind the NNW limb and no STEREO imagery is available.

note: Narrow CME in the NNW. No clear source has been found for it although there is some very minor dimming in the north and also a movement of field line on the NNW limb around 23:50Z but both are inconclusive.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS measurement is conclusive for this CME since it is covered by a data gap in STEREO and no clear source has been found.

note: Faint narrow outflow with unclear front. The source is likely Active Region 3664 located at ~128 deg.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME to the south. No clear source found on disk, although there is eruption in AR 3683 after 03:00Z (S23W23) but this seems too far to the west.

cmeAnalyses.note: Specialtive analysis as no clear source for this CME found on the Earth-facing disk.

note: Narrow western CME following 2024-05-17T00:12Z CME. Coronal signature of this CME is seen in the west in AIA 193 as opening/moving of field lines after 03:33Z. The source is likely Active Region 3664 located at ~130 deg.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on a fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Narrow, faint CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Potentially associated with AR 3679. A filament eruption is visible in this area around 2024-05-17T03:00Z in SDO AIA 304 which appears to deflect to the north in EUV imagery. Dimming and post eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs and on the location of the possible source (filament eruption).

note: Bright CME seen to the west. A backsided source is indicated for it by a massive and fast restructuring of magnetic field behind the west limb which is seen at 2024-05-17T12:38Z in SDO AIA 171 and less prominently in AIA 193. The source is likely the former Active Region  13664 which is now at the longitude of 135 degrees. The backsided flare is confirmed by the STIX instrument at the Solar Orbiter which saw a significant flare.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis of the bulk based on the fit in two coronagraphs and confirmed by the calculated current farsided longitude of the former Active Region 13664.
Analysis of the shock of this CME based on the fit in two coronagraphs and confirmed by the calculated farsided longitude of former Active Region 13664.

note: Faint CME likely associated with an eruption starting around 2024-05-20T12:00Z close to the coronal hole in the northwest at ~(N28E45), with dimming and bright post-eruptive arcades as coronal signatures.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the source location confirmed by the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: This faint, narrow, and irregularly shaped CME is seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The only discernible source may be some very small ejecta from just beyond the SW limb at an apparent latitude of S20 or so, visible in GOES SUVI 304 at 2024-05-17T18:34Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of irregular and faint leading edge using a farsided longitude and best fit between coronagraph imagery.

note: This heart-shaped CME is seen to the E/SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. This CME is not observed by STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-05-17T20:53Z to 2024-05-18T01:23Z. Associated with the M7.2 flare from AR 13685 (S13E52). Widely opening field lines, an EUV wave, and post-eruptive arcade can be seen in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at 2024-05-17T20:54Z, and ejecta and brightening can be seen in SDO AIA 304/171. This eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 195 at 2024-0517T20:55Z as widely opening field lines and brightening, and in STEREO A EUVI 304 at 21:15Z as ejecta, brightening, and post-eruptive arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using location of source as seen in UV imagery (S11E65) and best fit of bulk portion as seen in C2 and C3.

note: This slow CME is the first of three overlapping slow CMEs seen to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is widely but slowly opening field lines on the Southern limb as seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284, starting at about 2024-05-18T05:09Z. Prominence material - some of which lingers and some of which escapes - can be seen just beyond the S/SW limb in SDO AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304 around 05:24Z. Imagery of this CME was affected by the scheduled calibration maneuvers which entailed a reduction in LASCO imagery cadence.

cmeAnalyses.note: The exact longitude is uncertain, though believed to be farsided based on UV imagery. Measurement taken using best fit between available SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Imagery of this CME was affected by the reduction in LASCO cadence due to scheduled calibration maneuvers.

note: This CME is visible to the W in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3.  Imagery of this CME was affected by the scheduled calibration maneuvers which entailed a reduction in LASCO imagery cadence. Source is narrow ejecta seen from beyond the W limb at an apparent latitude of S20 starting at 2024-05-18T12:37Z in SDO AIA 304/171 and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of a faint leading edge in StereoCAT using only STEREO A COR2 imagery. The candidate source of this CME is just beyond the SW limb and at an apparent latitude of about S20 as seen in SDO AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304, so a plane-of-sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery could possibly be considered reasonable for ascertaining an accurate measurement. This measurement is still very uncertain though, due to uncertainty of the exact source location longitude and limited available SOHO LASCO imagery (due to the scheduled maneuver affecting LASCO imagery cadence).

note: Thin, faint CME seen to the E in all coronagraphs. The source is unclear, and may be visible as some weak field line movement over the east limb in SDO AIA 171/193, otherwise no EUV signature observed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 given the uncertain source and limited imagery.

note: Filament eruption seen to the SSE in all coronagraphs. Source is a long filament on-disk, spanning approximately S65E40->S35W20 (centered ~S40E10) at 2024-05-18T19:00Z, slowly rising and eventually lifting off from the disk. The filament extends a bit further SE, but that portion beyond ~S65E40 remains on the disk. Best observed as the filament erupting in SDO AIA 171/193/304, also as field line movement and dimming in SDO AIA 171/193, with a double ribbon flare in SDO AIA 304. A weak post-eruptive arcade is observed after the eruption as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO and STEREO COR2A, using the rough center of the filament eruption ~S40E10 as an initial source, finding some southward deflection which may also be observed in AIA imagery.

note: Thin, faint CME seen to the E in all coronagraphs. The source is unclear, and may be visible as some weak field line movement over the east limb in SDO AIA 171/193, otherwise no EUV signature observed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 given the uncertain source.

note: Thin, faint CME seen to the east in all coronagraphs. The source is not too clear, but may be associated with an M1.9 flare from AR 3685 that peaked at 2024-05-19T13:44Z, best observed in SDO AIA 131. Some weak field line movement is observed at this time of the flare in SDO AIA 171/193, and dark filamentary material is seen rising along field lines after the flare occurs and correlates to the start time of the CME in coronagraph imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO and STEREO COR2A using AR 3685 as an initial source, finding a good nearby fit. In the already low amount of available imagery, the front is notably faint and blurry, which made for difficulty tracking the leading edge.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The start of the CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to data gaps from 2024-05-19T15:16Z-19:12Z. The source of the CME is unclear, and may be on the far side.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. A best fit could not be obtained between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT, so the plane of sky method was used.

note: Visible in the NW of STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The start of the CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gaps from 2024-05-19T15:16Z-19:12Z. There is continuing outflow following the initial leading edge of this CME. The source is a northwest filament eruption centered around N33W25 starting at 2024-05-19T14:33Z. The filament liftoff is visible in SDO AIA 193/304. Opening field lines and post eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 171//193. The filament eruption is also visible from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters obtained using source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SSW in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The start of the CME is not visible in SOHO due to data gaps from 2024-05-19T15:16Z-19:12Z. The source is a filament eruption seen lifting off beyond the limb in GOES SUVI 304. The liftoff starts very gradually around 2024-05-19T12:00Z. Footpoints for the filament are not visible on the disk in EUV imagery, so it is believed to be on the back side. The filament liftoff is also visible on the limb in STEREO A EUV 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. Limited imagery was available for this measurement due to the faintness of the leading edge.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is the M2.5 flare starting at 2024-05-19T17:47Z from AR 3685 (S10E33). An eruption can be best seen in SDO AIA 304 following the flare. It is also visible in SDO AIA 193 and STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Limited imagery was available for this measurement due to the CME's faintness.

note: Fast halo CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is believed to be backsided, with moving field lines and EUV wave visible in SDO AIA 171/193 at 2024-05-20T05:22Z. A filament eruption and C6.7 flare peaking at 2024-05-20T05:54Z from Active Region 3683 (approx. S24W65) occurred around the same time, but was determined not be the source of this fast halo CME due to location and timing.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of what was determined to likely be the SHOCK of this CME using backsided source and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.
Measurement of the bulk of this CME using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME to the east. Its source could be 2024-05-20T18:36Z slow eruption in AR 3688, with dimming enlarging the coronal hole located to the south of this AR. The eruption is likely centered around (S25E35).

cmeAnalyses.note: Reanalysis with more precise source location.
Analysis based on the source location and confirmed by good fit in 2 coronagraphs

note: Faint CME to the SE (the second, more S in a pair of closely following faint and narrow CMEs). Its source could be the continuing eruption SE of AR 3688 seen after 20Z as dimming seen as enlarging the SE CH to the south of the Active Region. This dimming is centered at S28E33.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and on the source location.

note: Narrow faint CME with uneven front in the SW. Its source could be the C4.8 flare in AR 3683 (S24W77) peaking at 2024-05-21T07:32Z and there is also associated very minor post eruptive arcade in AIA 304 south of AR 3683 (S35W77) that could indicate that the latitude of the source is southward of the AR.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the fit with two coronagraphs. It is slightly uncertain since the CME seems to be much more southward than the flare.

note: Faint southward CME with a fuzzy front. A possible source a large-area slow filament eruption seen starting to erupt at ~2024-05-21T09:04Z south of the coronal hole in the southeast in AIA 304 and 193, with slowly appearing (in AIA 193/304) massive post-eruptive arcades centered at S47E15. The filament seems to be directed more southwestward than the latitude of the arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Uncertain analysis based on the fit in coronagraph. The CME seems more southwestern than the location of the post-eruptive arcades, but it corresponds well to the latitude of the erupting filament seen in AIA 304.

note: CME seen to the SW in all coronagraphs. Source is likely an eruption from AR 3683 with a C6.6 flare (S23W77) which peaked at 2024-05-21T14:13Z observed in SDO AIA 131. Seen best in GOES SUVI 284 as field line movement and dimming rising up from the region and deflecting southward within the corona. Also observed as field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made as a triangulation between SOHO and STEREO. Notably difficult capture of the leading edge due to the southward deflection (observed in GOES SUVI 284), which misaligned the CME travel direction from the measurement tool connected to disk center. A best fit is done with low confidence, but there is high confidence in this CME being out of the ecliptic regardless.

note: CME seen to the NW in SOHO only, as STEREO is in a data gap at this time. The source is not completely certain, but is likely an M1.9 flare (S06W47) from AR 3679 which peaked at 2024-05-21T19:31Z best observed in SDO AIA 131. The CME is observed deflected northward if this is the source, but it is backed up by SDO AIA 171/193 imagery showing the signature could erupt northward instead of outward from the region. Observed as dimming after the flare and some weak field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, as STEREO COR2A is in a data gap and did not observe this front. Source of AR 3579 used (S06W47) as a basis, and finding the longitude fit with the observed EUV northward deflection. Some variance could exist in the longitude given the one-spacecraft measurement.

note: Filament eruption seen to the S in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is a filament which is observed best in SDO AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304's wider FOV over the far southern limb, in close proximity to the south pole. As such, narrowing down a longitude is difficult. This filament began to slowly lift off ~2024-05-21T14:00Z, erupting more explosively ~T17:00Z, and fiercely whipping around in the corona ~T19:00Z before fading away and leaving the FOV into this observed CME front.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement given the uncertain source longitude due to proximity to the southern pole of the disk, and no available COR2A imagery. As such, the longitudes could technically vary wildly as they converge to the poles. The eruption is likely due south with parameters similar to this plane of sky, based on its evolution in EUV imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Since this event is far-sided and there is no source location available, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. Source is not completely certain, but likely an M1.5 flare (S06W52) from AR 3679 which peaked at 2024-05-22T03:13Z, best seen in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as dimming and some weak field line movement at the time of the flare in SDO AIA 171/193/211, deflected northward of the region, supporting the source at S06W52 leading to a NW-directed CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO and STEREO COR2A using the M1.5 flare from AR 3679 (S06W52) as an initial source, and finding a fit at this longitude with northward deflection that was observed in SDO imagery.

note: Faint event with a dimpled unclear front. The source is more likely behind the NW limb as there is a minor movement of field lines behind the limb in AIA 171 around 2024-05-21T11:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is certain since the source seems to be behind the limb and we can obtain fits with a range of longitudes.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at this time. Based on the rate of solar rotation, former Active Region 13664 is estimated to be around longitude -158 at the time of this event. However, it was difficult to obtain a decent measurement based on this longitude. It is possible this region is responsible for this CME, but this event would likely have been deflected from the source if so.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and there is no precise source location, the measured parameters vary slightly.

note: Bright lightbulb-shaped CME to the SE where the source is a 2023-05-23T00:39Z eruption of an unusually-looking filament stretched longitudinally and centered at S35E45, as seen in SDO AIA 304/171. The eruption of this filament is also marked by the massive post-eruptive arcades seen in AIA 193 after ~2024-05-2302:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on fit in two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption and subsequent M4.2 flare from Active Region 13679 (S09W60) starting around 2024-05-23T02:15Z in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery which appears to deflect northward.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: First CME in a series of three CMEs likely associated with M-class flares from Active Region 3679. The likely associated very minor eruption is seen in AIA 193 as faint minor dimming/posteruptive arcades after 04:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the associated flare and confirmed by the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption centered around S32E18 which begins starting around 2024-05-23T06:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Post-eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 07:00Z. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-05-23T07:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely a small filament eruption centered near S12E03 which begins to lift-off around 2024-05-23T06:45Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. This eruption appears to deflect towards the southeast as it leaves the solar disk/initial source location. Post eruptive arcades begin to form in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery around 07:20Z. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-05-23T06:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LACSO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is mostly obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery and becomes too diffuse to measure after a few frames. This measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: Second CME in a series of three CMEs likely associated with M-class flares from Active region 3679

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the associated flare and confirmed by the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: Third CME in a series of three CMEs likely associated with M-class flares from Active region 3679

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the associated flare and confirmed by the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames prior to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event becomes diffuse and difficult to track after a few frames, so this measurement relies on early imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is likely an eruption from N19E80 starting around 2024-05-23T22:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly as there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available to confirm the measurement due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at this time.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is likely an eruption near AR 3679 (S12W78) starting around 2024-05-24T02:45Z as seen in SDO AIA 131 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery which occurs during this event.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on fit with two coronagraphs. No source was found on disk or on limb.
A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is likely a small dimming region centered near S14W67 in SDO AIA 193 imagery starting around 2024-05-24T06:30Z. Faint field line movement is visible over the W/SW limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery starting around 2024-05-24T07:20Z as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A at this time, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available to confirm the measured parameters. They may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is only seen in one timestamp of STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption visible just on or slightly beyond the northeast limb starting around 2024-05-24T07:40Z as seen in SDO AIA 131 and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly as there is no STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event due to a data gap.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is a wide opening of field lines visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-05-24T310:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location. STEREO A COR2 imagery was not available to assist in triangulating the longitude due to a data gap.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely an eruption centered near N45W75 starting around 2024-05-24T11:25Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery, but the center of the eruption could be closer to the limb/on limb. A strong opening of field lines is visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery, with post eruptive arcades starting to form around 12:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on fit with two coronagraphs, indicating that the source longitude is higher than estimated (behind the limb).

Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A during this time, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available to confirm the measurement. The measured parameters may very slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-05-23T20:53Z. The source is a wide opening of field lines visible beyond the eastern limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-05-24T13:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided/unknown source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Narrow CME to the west with the likely source an M-class flare and an associated minor eruption on/near the western limb seen starting around 2024-05-25T20:12Z in SDO AIA 304 imagery and as opening of field lines in AIA 193/171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the location of the associated flare.
Initial plane-of-sky analysis made with SOHO LASCO imagery, while STEREO imagery was not available.

note: Faint front with initial bright right hand boundary and core parts, this CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-05-25T12:23Z to 2024-05-26T01:09Z. The source appears to be moving/opening field lines beyond the SW limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-05-25T17:00Z with multiple "waves" possibly indicating more than one eruption. The CME in difference imagery appears to have two fronts following the same path at the same speed, it is possible this analysis includes two overlapping CMEs.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement due to single-spacecraft analysis and limited views of exact source. This analysis may include more than one CME front based on difference imagery features.

note: Bright front CME to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be moving/opening field lines seen in SDO/AIA 94 starting around 2024-05-26T16:45Z. The associated moving/opening field lines are not as clear in STA EUVI 195, however slight changes along the limb suggest the eruption is beyond STA's field-of-view (~104 degrees).

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based off of the best fit of the CME in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Large partial halo, potential full halo CME with likely H-alpha emission seen with a bulk portion to the east in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an X2.8 flare peaking at 2024-05-27T07:08Z from an unnumbered active region just beyond the SE limb (likely old AR3664 based on solar rotation calculations). The flare included the release of plasma/filament material best seen in SDO/AIA 304 and was followed by moving/opening field lines and EUV wave best seen in SDO/AIA 211 and GOES SUVI 284, as well as post-eruptive arcades best seen in SDO/AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters are based on the best fit of the BULK of the CME. The CME exhibits a dimpled front and continues to expand in width as it progresses out of the field of view. Most of the CME's bulk is captured in this analysis, however portions on the left hand boundary were excluded in later frames due to the expansion of the CME.

Parameters based on the SHOCK of the CME. Due to the irregular shape of the CME and shock, some portions of the shock were excluded to attempt a best fit. Parameters may vary due to limitations with measuring techniques.

note: Faint narrow CME preceding the brighter and wider 2024-05-28T05:38Z CME likely from the same backsided source. No clear source have been found, although there is a slow movement of field lines in AIA 171 in the  SW for a long time. There might be a super minor restructuring of magnetic field configuration likely far behind the SW limb seen in AIA 335 around 2024-05-27T20Z seen in AIA 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very speculative analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs. There is no clear source and the fit can have a range of longitudes, at least from 100 deg to 130 deg.

note: Large, wide and bright CME to the SW. Source appears to be beyond the SW limb based on field line movement seen in SDO/AIA 94, 335, and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very speculative analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs. The fit can have a range of longitudes, at least from 105 deg to 140 deg. The CME's coronal signatures were interpreted as indicating a more backsided source of 135 deg, however this is subjective. No clear backsided Active Region candidate has been found for this event (former Active Region 3683 which is at the longitude of 170 degrees) is not a candidate for this event based on the fit.

note: Faint CME in the SSW with no clear source; however there are a couple of potential coronal signatures - a slow possible ejecta seen in the SSW in AIA 171 starting after 2024-05-28T18Z and a faint movement of field lines far behind the limb in the SSW in AIA 171 at the same time as well. The CME is almost completely covered by the nighttime data gap in STEREO A coronagraph.

cmeAnalyses.note: Speculative analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. The source is backsided and the CME is almost completely covered by the nighttime data gap in STEREO coronagraph.

POS analysis of this event was also made since the two coronagraph measurement of this CME is approximate due to the source being farsided and the CME being mostly covered by the nighttime data gap in STEREO.

note: A faint most likely backsided high southern latitude CME in the SSW.  A possible source is an ejecta and movement of field lines seen in AIA 171 leaving the AIA field of view in south southwest after 2024-05-28T22Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is covered by the night time data gap in STEREO and only Plane of Sky analysis is possible.

note: A very faint partial halo CME in the NW seen only in difference imagery (SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2). No on-disk source have been found on the earth-facing disk, so it is likely backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: An extremely speculative analysis based on one fit with two coronagraphs. No source has been found for this CME and the front is very faint in both coronagraphs. Unfortunately, fits with two coronagraph are possible with a wide range of longitudes.
Only POS analysis is definitive since the lack of source and faintness of the front of this CME make a 3D analysis very speculative.

note: Extremely faint full halo with a fuzzy faint front only seen in difference imagery in the first few timestamps of SOHO LASCO C2 and in one early timestamp of C3. The source has not been found on the Earth-facing disk. The halo is not discernible in STEREO A COR2.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very uncertain analysis based on the fit of this very faint halo in one coronagraph (LASCO) with very few timestamps.

note: Faint and narrow CME mostly seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/STEREO A COR2 (too faint to be seen in more than a couple timestamps in C3). The source is a relatively narrow opening of field lines on/behind the E limb seen starting 2024-05-29T04:30Z in AIA 193/171 and a super faint ejecta seen in AIA 304. The opening of field lines is preceded at 2024-05-29T02:30 by another, more minor, on/close to limb eruption seen in AIA 335. These eruptions are followed by slowly appearing post-eruptive arcades on the east limb seen after 2024-05-29T05:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the source (close to the east limb) and confirmed by the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: Large, bright partial halo CME to east in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is the X1.4 class flare from AR13697 with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 193, 171, and GOES SUVI 284. Additionally, a thin filament ejecta was visible during the eruption as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Post-eruptive arcades followed the flare as seen in SDO/AIA 193 and 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters of the SHOCK of the CME based on SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.
This CME appears to have three parts, a shock, bulk/leading edge, and a core/trailing edge. These parameters are based on the potential BULK of the CME.

This CME appears to have three parts, a shock, bulk/leading edge, and a core/trailing edge. These parameters are based on the CORE/trailing edge of the CME which appears as the brightest portion in white-light imagery the longest.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event follows in the path of CME: 2024-05-29T14:48Z. The source is likely an eruption starting around 2024-05-29T16:30Z from AR 3697 (S21E70) as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 103, 304 imagery. Post eruptive loops begin to form around 17:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption near or slightly beyond the S/SW limb starting around 2024-05-29T17:45Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely a small eruption/brightening near Active Region 13697 (S25E70) starting around 2024-05-29T19:10Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available and the measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain/far-sided source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption visible near the southeast limb (~S40E90) in SDO AIA 304 imagery starting around 2024-05-30T00:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption near AR 3697 (S22E60) starting around 2024-05-30T03:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event becomes diffuse after early imagery, and this measurement relies on early frames as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. The source is likely an eruption centered near S10E80 starting around 2024-05-30T08:50Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193, and post eruptive loops begin to form around 10:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This bright CME is visible to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Opening field lines and material liftoff seen beyond the SW limb starting around 2024-05-30T20:27Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, and faintly in 304 imagery. Seen in GOES SUVI 304 and 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using fit between coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Overlaps with CME:2024-05-30T21:12Z. Source is opening field lines seen beyond the S limb starting around 2024-05-31T03:27Z as seen in SDO AIA 171. Opening field lines are also seen in GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured using best fit.

note:
A somewhat asymmetric full halo CME with two consecutive fronts seen best in SOHO LASCO C3 (but also in C2). With the exception of one (or two) early timestamps this event is covered by a large gap in STEREO A COR2. The indication of the backsided source of this halo in EUV imagery is possibly a faint and very fast movement of field lines that likely happens far behind the east limb seen starting 2024-06-01T18:39Z in AIA 171 in the ESE. 
The backsided analysis is supported by the location of a large backsided active region in helioseismology imagery from GONG - likely the former AR 13679 that was around lat/lon -8/-170 at the time of this event. In addition, STIX instrument on the Solar Orbiter detected a significant flare (equivalent of GOES X1)peaking at 2024-06-01T18:45Z.
Identifying the coronal signatures of this CME is complicated by an almost simultaneous X1.0 class flare from Active Region 13697 on the Earth-facing disk followed by a later M7.3 flare from the same front-sided Active Region. The front-sided flares are accompanied by relatively weak coronal signatures of eruption - dimming and post-eruptive arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Somewhat uncertain analysis of the outer, earlier front of this halo CME (possibly its shock), based on the fit with two coronagraphs. Only one coronagraph frame is available for STEREO A COR2 bc of a data gap, adding to the uncertainty of analysis. These parameters are somewhat confirmed by the location of a large backsided active region in helioseismology imagery from GONG which is likely the former AR 13679 that was at lat/lon -8/-170 at the time of event.

Approximate analysis of the second front of this halo CME (possibly its bulk), based on a fit with two coronagraphs. For STEREO A COR2 imagery only one timestamp is available (bc of a large data gap), adding to the uncertainty of analysis. Analysis is supported by the location of a large backsided active region in helioseismology imagery from GONG - likely the former AR 13679 that was around lat/lon -8/-170 at the time of this event. In addition, STIX instrument on Solar Orbiter detected a significant flare at 2024-06-01T18:45Z.

note: A CME to the SE with a complex uneven (pointy) front that comes on the heels of and overlaps with the preceding 2024-06-01T19:12Z halo CME (which was concluded to be backsided). The source of this, likely front-sided, CME could be the M7.3 flare from Active Region 3697 (S20E21) peaking at 2024-06-01T19:40Z and an associated eruption signified by post-eruptive arcades and a somewhat more eastern, not very deep, dimming centered very approximately around (S20E25). The front (e.g. the width) of this CME is not easy to determine because of the overlap with the preceding, likely backsided, halo and because the CME is partially obscured by the pylon in C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very uncertain analysis is based on the source location of the dimming associated with the flare and on the fit with one coronagraph (SOHO) since in STEREO A COR2 the CME is fully covered by the night time data gap. The shape of the CME front, as it is seen overlapping with the preceding, likely backsided, halo, is very complex and the exact width is hard to determine. There also can be a range of possible longitudes (at least from -20 to -25 degrees), from the longitude of the associated flare to the more eastern longitude of the associated dimming.

note: Narrow CME in the south with no source found on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-02T20:38Z to 2024-06-03T00:53Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain/far-sided source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption near or slightly beyond the western limb starting around 2024-06-02T23:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event become diffuse in later imagery and therefore relies on earlier frames for the measurement.

note: Super faint CME likely associated with the M4.8 flare from Active Region 3695 (N27W41) peaking at 2024-06-03T14:11Z. There is an associated eruption with beautiful bright ejecta seen in AIA/SUVI 304 starting at 2024-06-03T14:03Z, however most of the plasma seems to fall back onto the disk (looking like a firework). The CME is only seen faintly in several early C2 timestamps and is not seen in C3/COR2A imagery likely because of its faintness.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph measurement with SOHO C2 images only, based on the location of Active Region 3695 which produced the associated flare and ejecta.

note: This slow CME is visible to the East in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2. The source is opening field lines seen just beyond the E limb and spanning from latitude S00 to S15 in SDO AIA 171 lasting from 2024-06-04T03:30Z-04:20Z. Ejecta also seen in SDO AIA 304. This CME seems to have interacted with a nearby streamer, possibly blowing out part of the streamer.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of slightly asymmetrical leading edge.

note: This faint CME to the southeast is visible in both C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery, although it is most visible in STEREO A COR2 white light imagery and difference imagery. The pylon in SOHO LASCO C2 obstructs portions of the already-faint leading edge. The source is gradually opening field lines and ejecta seen on or just beyond the E/SE limb in GOES SUVI 284 and SDO AIA 171 starting at about 04:00Z, but does not fully leave the GOES SUVI field of view until closer to 05:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement (here, Lon:-90) using StereoCAT. Extreme faintness of leading edge in SOHO LASCO imagery was not conducive to a multi-spacecraft measurement.

note: This CME has a brighter narrower bulk with a wider fainter shock seen to the east. No clear source found on the Earth-facing disk, however there are two potential sources: a very slow movement of field line beyond the east limb going on after 2024-06-04T20Z (which is far too early) or a similar slow movement of a field line beyond the sourtheast limb starting at 2024-06-05T01:20Z. Both movements are seen in AIA 193 and 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is definitive since the source is not seen on the Earth-facing disk and the possible source (movement of field line) could be on or far behind the east limb. The fit with two coronagraphs gives a wide range of longitudes (at least from -90 to -125 degrees).

note: Asymmetrical (front slanted towards the south) CME to the east following/overlapping with the preceding 2024-06-05T01:25Z CME. Source could be a very slow movement beyond SE limb starting at 2024-06-05T01:20Z, both seen in  in AIA 193, 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is definitive b/c this CME produces a fit with a range of longitudes with two coronagraphs (longitudes at least between -90 and -125 deg). The source is likely behind the limb (movement of field lines) but it is not definitive.

note: Faint CME in the east. Its source rather unclear continuous movement of field lines behind the east limb. (There is also a minor eruption in AR 3704 at 2024-06-06T08:21 (at S18E46) with dimming but this source does not produce a fit with two coronagraphs).

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is definitive since the source is so unclear and the fits with two coronagraphs are possible with a wide range of longitudes.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-05T15:53Z to 2024-06-06T00:38Z. The source is a large filament eruption which begins to lift off around 2024-06-05T16:00Z spanning N01E55 to N23E55 (centered around N15E53) as seen in AIA 131, 171, 193, 304, and GOES SUVI 304 imagery. Dimming is visible in the southern portion of the eruption site, and post-eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193 starting around 17:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly as no stereoscopic viewpoint was available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to an eruption visible beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 304 imagery starting around 2024-06-05T20:55Z. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-06-05T23:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely a dimming region/field line movement observed near Active Region 13698 (N21W40) as seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery around 2024-06-05T19:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge of this event becomes diffuse and difficult to measure in later imagery. This measurement relies on earlier imagery as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption visible slightly beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA 171 and 304 imagery starting around 2024-06-05T20:30Z. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-06-05T22:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Faint CME seen to the West in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, very faint in SOHO LASCO C3. The source is ejection of some very faint material from S20W75 (AR 3697) starting at 05:12Z in SDO AIA 304, rising loop and opening field line seen in SDO AIA 171/193 at 05:27Z, a small post-eruptive arcade seen forming at 16:33Z at S17W68 in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using source location and best fit between coronagraphs. Leading edge becomes too diffuse to track prior to reaching halfway into STEREO A COR2 field of view.

note: Large halo CME visible in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. The source appears to be two back-to-back M-class flares from AR13697 with associated dimming signature to the north as well as nice filament ejecta to the west and north. Post-eruptive arcades are beginning to show in SDO/AIA 193. There is a large EUV wave associated with this event, as best seen in SDO/AIA 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement made with more complete SOHO frames in LASCO C2/C3 following its downlink backfill. Very little has changed between the preliminary analysis, finding a good triangulation between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs here.

SHOCK measurement made with more complete SOHO frames in LASCO C2/C3 following its downlink backfill. This shock front is dimpled between two apparent fronts, seen in both SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs, which made for some difficulty triangulating the two images. Eventually settled on a triangulation using the top of the halo shock as the shared feature between both, finding a good fit.
PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS. SOHO imagery is currently downlinking, preventing from further triangulation. This analysis is based on the BULK of the CME.
PRELIMINARY ANALYSIS of the SHOCK front of the CME.

note: CME seen to the WSW in all coronagraphs, with much difficulty due to the ongoing oversaturation in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 from a solar energetic particle event prior. As such, LASCO C2 is difficult to analyze for CME start times, and this ID could vary some from the selected time. The source for this CME is uncertain with no distinct source observed, and could potentially be related to some outflow from AR 3697 following large CME 2024-06-08T01:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with only SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, given the poor image quality of LASCO C2 (ongoing SEP) coupled with the uncertain source location.

note: CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs, with much difficulty due to the ongoing oversaturation in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 from a solar energetic particle event prior. As such, LASCO C2 is difficult to analyze for CME start times, and this ID could vary some from the selected time. The source for this CME is uncertain with no distinct source observed, and could potentially be related to some outflow from AR 3697 following large CME 2024-06-08T01:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with only SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, given the poor image quality of LASCO C2 (ongoing SEP) coupled with the uncertain source location.

note: CME seen to the SW in only SOHO (due to a STEREO data gap), with much difficulty due to the ongoing oversaturation in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 from a solar energetic particle event prior. As such, LASCO C2 is difficult to analyze for CME start times, and this ID could vary some from the selected time. The source for this CME is uncertain with no distinct source observed, and could potentially be related to some outflow from AR 3697 following large CME 2024-06-08T01:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with only SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, given the poor image quality of LASCO C2 (ongoing SEP) coupled with the uncertain source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-06-08T16:38Z to 2024-06-09T00:38Z. The source may be related to an eruption starting around 2024-06-08T17:20Z from ~S20W85 as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Minor field line movement is visible near the SW at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location. This event becomes too diffuse to measure after a few frames and the measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-06-08T16:38Z to 2024-06-09T00:38Z. The source is likely related to an eruption and subsequent M1.0 flare from Active Region 13703 (S09W44) starting around 2024-06-08T21:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available to confirm the measured parameters. They may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a faint eruption visible near the southwest limb in SDO AIA 131 imagery starting around 2024-06-09T01:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to an eruption visible near the southwest limb in SDO AIA 131 imagery starting around 2024-06-09T04:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event disappears after a few frames and the measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-06-09T14:53Z. The source is likely related to an eruption near Active Region 13697 (S19W90) starting around 2024-06-09T15:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131 and 171. An opening of field lines is visible over the SW limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery at this time as well

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: Bright fast CME off the west limb seen in both coronagraphs. Its source is likely the series of two M-class flares from Active Region 3697 (S18W91). Ejecta in AIA 131 was seen starting at 2024-06-10T10:00Z and the opening of field lines starts at 10:20Z however the major opening of field lines is seen at 10:45Z indicating that the major contribution might have come from the M5.3 flare peaking at 2024-06-10T10:58Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs and on the source location of the associated flare.

note: A CME with a dimpled bulk front (and a much wider fainter shock front) which is very closely following the 2024-06-10T11:00Z CME. This CME is likely associated with the X1.5 class flare from Active Region 3697 that follows the M5.3 class flare. Coronal signatures include minor post-eruptive arcades on west limb and faint minor dimming seen in AIA 193 starting after 2024-06-10T12:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and on the location of the associated flare.
Very approximate analysis of the likely more backsided shock based on the best fit with two coronagraphs only.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not in STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. Observed as a minor eruption/dimming in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2024-06-11T17:00Z centered around S15W60.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the source region to start, finding southward deflection. Heavy overlap with a much wider CME erupting shortly after this leading edge is observed.

note: Wide CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not in STEREO COR2A due to a lengthy data gap over this period. The source is an occulted M9.5 flare from AR 3697 (estimated around the limb ~S18W96 at the time) which peaked at 2024-06-10T18:40Z, best observed in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as field line movement and an EUV wave in SDO AIA 171/193/211 starting around 2024-06-11T17:54Z, with post-eruptive arcades forming after the flare peak.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement using only SOHO C3 imagery, due to a STEREO COR2A data gap. Source longitude of AR 3697 (S18W96) used as a basis, finding a northward deflection with a good fit.
SHOCK measurement using only SOHO C3 imagery, due to a STEREO COR2A data gap. Source longitude of AR 3697 (S18W96) used as a basis, ultimately fitting much better around W139.

note: Loop CME seen to the NE in all coronagraphs. Observed as a loop rising to the NE loosely around 2024-06-10T21:00Z best in SDO AIA 171, and post-eruptive arcade starting ~2024-06-10T23:31Z in SDO AIA 171/193 centered ~N32E55 near no active regions.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made by triangulation between SOHO and STEREO, finding deflection away from the source centered around N32E55, but this deflection northwestward is observed during the rising loop eruption in SDO AIA 171.

note: Wide filament eruption seen to the SW in all coronagraphs. Source is a filament eruption from the far-side of the disk, observed best as the filament material itself in SDO AIA 304 launching around 2024-06-10T22:30Z from around S30-S40. The filament material appears to be closer to the limb, but is accompanied by a wider far-sided field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211 that appears further around the limb. This is corroborated by the fit in swpc_cat between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs not working unless longitudes >W130 were used. It appears that two fronts are traveling together from this front--perhaps the filament and field line movements--and are thus measured as one for this analysis.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the two apparent fronts from this eruption as one, requiring a right hand boundary measurement. Source initially appeared as the far-sided filament closer to the limb, perhaps W100-W110, but ultimately could not fit a triangulation between SOHO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A unless we went W130-W145.

note: Narrow CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Partially overlaps with CME: 2024-06-10T23:36Z in the field of view of the coronagraphs. The source is unclear, and may be beyond the west limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method chosen for this measurement due to lack of clear source location, and the imagery of the leading edge was too unreliable to determine the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint loop CME to the NE in all coronagraphs. Observed as a dim, diffuse area of dimming best seen in SDO AIA 171/193/211 centered around ~N12E27, starting around 2024-06-11T04:48Z. Also seen as field line movement to the NE in SDO AIA 171/193/211 stemming from this area, and some small but noticeable double ribbon flaring in SDO AIA 304 at this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location with adjustment for best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, but may be on or beyond the west limb as seen in SDO AIA imagery, as field line movement can be seen around 2024-06-11T08:00Z-10:00Z in SDO AIA 171/193 and STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. Due to the uncertainty in the source location of this measurement, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is unclear, but there may be some field line movement beyond the west limb as seen from SDO EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement chosen due to lack of STEREO A imagery and no clear source location.

note: Backsided partial halo CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-06-11T23:12Z after a data gap; it is first seen in STEREO A COR2 coronagraph at 2024-06-12T00:38Z, after a large data gap which starts at 2024-06-11T12:53Z. Coronal signatures of this event include a backsided EUV wave seen as a fast opening/movement of field lines behind the west limb and a significant restructuring of magnetic field behind the limb seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, GOES SUVI 195, 171 and 304 imagery starting at 2024-06-11T22:39Z and in EUVI STEREO A 195 imagery after the data gap. The likely source of the CME is the old Active Region 3697 which is at S18W112 at the time of eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: UPDATED BULK measurement using source location approx. longitude of W112, several frames of C3, and the one frame of STEREO A COR2 that had some indication of the leading edge in the frame.
Very approximate analysis of this backsided event based on the best fit of what appears to be the bulk front of the CME (vs its wider shock).

note: Large bright CME seen to the west in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A imagery for this event from 2024-06-12T12:53Z to 2024-06-13T00:38Z. Moving/opening field lines best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-06-12T15:00Z beyond the western limb. Moving/opening field lines are also visible in SDO/AIA 171 starting around 2024-06-12T15:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the BULK of the CME and potential source of AR13697 based on solar rotation calculation and visual inspection of source from EUV imagery. Longitude may vary due to lack of stereoscopic viewpoints of CME and source.

Parameters based on best fit of the SHOCK of CME using potential source of AR13697 (based on solar calculation). Portions of the CME shock to the north and south of the CME were excluded due to measurement limitations.

note: This CME is visible as a halo in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided. An eruption and subsequent M1.2 flare from Active Region 13711 (S12E12) is visible starting around 2024-06-12T22:40Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, and 304 imagery. However, this eruption appears to deflect towards the west and the source location does not provide an accurate measurement for this CME. Therefore, this event is more likely to be far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: The measured longitude is speculative due to the far-sided and uncertain source location. The measured parameters were based on the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and may vary.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is either far-sided, or may be related to the eruption and subsequent M1.2 flare from AR 3711 (S12E12) starting around 2024-06-12T22:40Z seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain source location and difficulty in obtaining a good fit between SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is related to field line movement near/slightly beyond the southwest limb as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-06-13T01:19Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west/northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source may be related to a faint eruption visible beyond the western limb in SDO AIA 131 and 304 imagery, with subsequent field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery, starting around 2024-06-13T03:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR 2 imagery. The measured parameters may vary slightly as the source is far-sided and there is no precise source location.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured longitude may vary as there is no precise source location due to the far-sided source.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely field line opening visible near or slightly beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-06-13T06:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured longitude is loosely based on the approximate location of former Active Region 13697 based on the rate of solar rotation.

note: This CME is visible to the west/northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames preceding a data gap from 2024-06-13T15:53 to 17:53Z. The source may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery starting around 2024-06-13T15:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The measured longitude may vary slightly as the precise source location is unknown.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and subsequent field line movement visible near or slightly beyond the western limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-06-13T17:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to faint field line movement visible beyond the western limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery starting around 2024-06-14T00:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge becomes diffuse and difficult to track in later imagery, so this measurement relies primarily on early frames.

note: Faint CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not visible on the disk in available EUV imagery, but a rising loop can be seen off the west limb in SDO AIA 171 around 2024-06-15T00:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method chosen due to lack of suitable fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT, which was complicated by the diffuse, faint, unclear leading edge of the CME.

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source may be backsided. Opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-06-15T05:11Z. Field line movement is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. This best fit is also supported by preliminary measurement in StereoCAT.

note: Narrow, faint CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The start time is approximate due to the CME's faintness in early frames of SOHO LASCO C2. The potential source is an eruption around S10E50 starting at approximately 2024-06-15T06:57Z. The eruption is best seen as post-eruption dimming and post-eruption arcades in SDO AIA 193, GOES SUVI 284, and STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. The CME fades away rapidly in the field of view of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is some faint brightening and opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-06-15T07:48Z. The eruption is also faintly visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2, with possible deflection in the coronagraphs from the source eruption.

note: CME visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption with liftoff starting around 2024-06-15T11:10Z in SDO AIA 304. The eruption is also visible with moving/opening field lines in SDO AIA 171/193/335, brightening and post-eruptive arcades visible in SDO AIA 335, and dimming and post-eruptive arcades in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and 304. The filament eruption may deflect towards the west after liftoff as seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2, with slight deflection from source location. This measurement focuses on the brightest leading edge of the CME. In later frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, a fainter, possible shock front is visible ahead of this leading edge, which was also analyzed and determined to have a similar speed.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely on the far side, but field line movement in unclear in available EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters obtained using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 due to lack of source location.

note: Faint CME seen to the West in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Becomes diffuse only a few frames into C3. Source is uncertain. There is a small eruption on the disk at an area ranging from S10-20 and W20-35 (at AR 3711) starting at 2024-06-16T06:03Z, but there is also subtle field line movement beyond the SW limb which may be a candidate source as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement taken due to uncertainty of source location. The leading edge becomes diffuse after about 3 frames of C3 difference imagery.

note: Very faint and slow CME seen to the N/NE and visible only in SOHO LASCO C2. The source is likely on the farside due to lack of signature on the Earth-facing disk. There are no frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this CME due to an ongoing data gap which started at 2024-06-16T15:38Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement taken due to uncertainty of source location. Leading edge becomes diffuse before reaching SOHO LASCO C3 field of view. There are no frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this CME due to an ongoing data gap which started at 2024-06-16T15:38Z.

note: One of a few overlapping faint CMEs visible to the W/SW in SOHO LASCO C2. The source is very likely farsided based on a lack of distinct source signature in SDO AIA imagery. There are no frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this CME due to an ongoing data gap which started at 2024-06-16T15:38Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement taken due to lack of clear source location. Leading edge becomes diffuse after a handful of frames in C3. There are no frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this CME due to a data gap which started at 2024-06-16T15:38Z.

note: Wide CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is widely opening field lines beyond the S/SE limb as seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2024-06-17T08:00Z. There is a fainter full halo portion of this CME which may be the shock portion.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge using the best fit between an abundance of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 frames. Source location is farsided as indicated by UV imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely backsided. Field line movement beyond the S/SW limb visible in SDO AIA 171 and very faint field line movement in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-06-17T08:18Z. [The M1.5 flare with peak time 2024-06-17T08:04Z from AR13712 was considered as a candidate source for this CME, but after analysis it was determined that the source is beyond the limb (possibly sympathetic with the eruption that resulted in the southeast CME:2024-06-17T08:24Z).]

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of bulk portion using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 and using a source location beyond the limb, as indicated by UV imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and NNE in STEREO A COR2.
