This CME occurs at the same time as multiple other CMEs in the coronagraphs, but was determined to be a separate CME with a distinct leading edge. The source is likely backsided, as no source eruption was visible on the disk in available EUV imagery. Moving field lines can be seen in SDO AIA 171 on the NE limb starting at 2024-06-17T08:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Wide CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely backsided. Field line movement beyond the NE limb visible in SDO AIA 171 and very faint field line movement in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-06-17T10:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The M1.5 flare peaking at 2024-06-17T10:46Z from AR 3712 produced a minor eruption but was determined to likely not be the source of this CME, due to the fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. This CME was determined to be backsided. Opening field lines can be seen beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA 171 at 2024-06-17T10:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 CME in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not visible on the disk in available EUV imagery, but there is possibly some field line movement visible between frames 10:35Z and 10:55Z in STEREO A EUVI 195 and 304 imagery at a fairly high northern latitude and beyond the W limb as seen from STEREO A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Overlaps in the field of view of the coronagraphs with CME: 2024-06-17T20:57Z to the south. The potential source is an M1.3 flare from Active Region 3711 as seen in SDO AIA 131/193. Dimming is visible in SDO AIA 193 as well as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171/193. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-06-17T19:23Z to 2024-06-18T00:23Z, the CME is not visible in COR2A until the leading edge is out of the field of view.

cmeAnalyses.note: Longitude based on potential source location. Measurement of the brighter leading edge, not the fainter material that was not clearly measurable in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: CME visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Partially overlaps with CME: 2024-06-17T20:21Z in the field of view of the coronagraphs. The source is on the far side, and can be seen as material exiting beyond the limb in the far south of GOES SUVI 304 from 2024-06-18T20:16Z to 20:44Z. This material can also be seen lifting off along with opening field lines in SDO AIA 171. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-06-17T19:23Z to 2024-06-18T00:23Z, the CME is not visible in COR2A until the leading edge is out of the field of view.

cmeAnalyses.note: The plane of sky method was chosen for this measurement due to lack of source longitude, no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for a measurement, and far southern appearance in the coronagraphs, which makes deriving a possible latitude/longitude difficult.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the N/NE in STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption centered around N25E70 in SDO AIA imagery. The filament can be seen lifting off starting around 2024-06-17T22:00Z in SDO AIA 193/304. In GOES SUVI 304, as the filament is departing the disk, some filamentary material can be seen moving on a northward trajectory. Some brightening and post-eruptive loops are visible in SDO AIA 193 and opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171. The source eruption is not visible in STEREO A EUV imagery due to a data gap from 2024-06-17T15:25Z to 2024-06-18T00:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Longitude approximated from source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Limited C3 imagery was available for this measurement due to the CME's faintness.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is faint, but may be some brightening with opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 193 and STEREO A EUV 195 around AR 3711 starting at 2024-06-18T03:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Limited imagery was available for this measurement due to the CME's faintness.

note: Very faint CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-18T07:53Z to 16:09Z. Directly precedes CME: 2024-06-18T12:24Z in the field of view in the coronagraphs. The source may be beyond the SE limb, and faint moving field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-06-18T09:36Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of source longitude and no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for a measurement.

note: Bright, wide CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Start of the CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-18T07:53Z to 16:09Z. The source is likely on the back side, and opening field lines can be seen on the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-06-18T10:54Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A range of longitudes were obtained in SWPC_CAT, ranging from -122 to -144. Latitudes ranged from -44 to -60. This was deemed to be the best measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs, but only briefly in STEREO COR2A as it enters a data gap after the first few frames. This CME front was quite difficult to analyze due to the source activity--two simultaneous filament eruptions in the NW with one visible front. The first filament spanning N45W25<->N41W34 began lifting around 2024-06-18T14:00Z and erupting more explosively around 2024-06-18T16:00Z in SDO 304, leaving behind a broad double ribbon flare in SDO AIA 304 and dimming in SDO AIA 171/193/211 centered around N59W34, with a post-eruptive arcade forming around 2024-06-18T16:40Z in SDO AIA 171/193/211. The second filament was a prominence over the NW limb, which began destabilizing around 2024-06-18T12:40Z and erupting around 2024-6-18T16:40Z in SDO 304 followed by a post-eruptive arcade visible over the limb in SDO AIA 171/193/211 starting around 2024-6-18T18:00Z. A potential second front was observed ~380 km/s with a fitted source of N35W25, but this is uncertain, but noting this observation due to the missing secondary front we would expect with two filaments.

cmeAnalyses.note: Initial fit made using the on-disk filament source alongside a triangulated fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and the limited STEREO COR2A frames available. Due to observed acceleration while measuring, only C3 frames are used for this measurement once the speed stabilized. There is significant variance possible in this measurement, with the two filaments erupting simultaneously and blending into this singular observed front.

note: CME visible in the SW of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2, with a faint leading edge. The source eruption is centered around S35W50 in SDO AIA 193 and is best seen as field line movement and faint dimming. The eruption is also visible in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to the faintness of the leading edge in STEREO A imagery.

note: CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2, where the event fails after a few frames. Observed as moving field lines likely around the western limb in SDO AIA 171/193 starting around 2024-06-18T21:03Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement given the likely far-sided source and only being visible in SOHO LASCO C2 for a few frames before the CME front fizzles out.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. There are 2 candidate sources for this eruption. The first is weak dimming/post eruptive arcades in a broad area centered around S43E18 in SDO AI AIA 193, gradually starting around 2024-06-18T02:21Z. Another potential source starts earlier, at about 2024-06-18T16:16Z, and is seen around S25E60 as an ejecta of material.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of diffuse leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME may deflect to the east of the source location.

note: First of two paired CMEs seen to the W in all coronagraphs (this one is more northern), following an M1.1 flare which peaked at 2024-06-19T06:38Z from AR 3711 seen in SDO AIA 131 with some field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171/193/211 at this time. Two fronts appear to travel out from this eruption, both only fitting near this source but fitting far enough apart in lat/lon to warrant two separate entries (see CME 2024-06-19T07:00Z). Interestingly, this eruption did not look too impressive in SDO AIA imagery, but far-sided fits of the fronts proved far worse than using this source longitude, so higher confidence is granted in this source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using the source of AR 3711 (S12W76) and triangulation between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs, finding a great fit near this source. This fit is of the more northern of the two fronts sourced from this same eruption.

note: Second of two paired CMEs seen to the SW in all coronagraphs (this one is more southern), following an M1.1 flare which peaked at 2024-06-19T06:38Z from AR 3711 seen in SDO AIA 131 with some field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171/193/211 at this time. Two fronts appear to travel out from this eruption, both only fitting near this source but fitting far enough apart in lat/lon to warrant two separate entries (see CME 2024-06-19T06:48Z). Interestingly, this eruption did not look too impressive in SDO AIA imagery, but far-sided fits of the fronts proved far worse than using this source longitude, so higher confidence is granted in this source. Both fronts unfortunately appeared in SOHO LASCO C2 at the same frame, so this CME was bumped to T07:00Z to avoid the overlap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using the source of AR 3711 (S12W76) and triangulation between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs, finding a great fit near this source. This fit is of the more southern of the two fronts sourced from this same eruption.

note: A very minor faint CME mostly seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and only in a few early timestamps of C3, not seen in STEREO A COR2 (it is mostly covered by a data gap in STEREO). Its source is likely a narrow but long filament eruption on/behind the SE limb seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting after 2024-06-19T16:28Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is definitive since the associated filament may be on or behind the SE limb. It is possible that the longitude is close to -90 degrees and this analysis is close to a 3D analysis.

note: A super minor faint jet mostly seen in SOHO LASCO C2 but also seen in C3 and in STEREO A COR2. Its source could be a very minor eruption off the SE limb seen in GOES SUVI 304 at 2024-06-20T05:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate measurement based on the fit with two coronagraphs. Potential source (eruption off/behind the SE limb) is super minor.

note: This CME is first seen at 2024-06-20T09:24Z propagating to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and in later frames by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. There is no clear source seen on the Earth facing disk, leading to the conclusion that this event likely occurred on the back side.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement is based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Parameters may vary slightly as the source of this CME is likely backsided, leading to the lack of a precise source location.

note: A narrow CME in the northeast seen in both coronagraphs. Its source is most likely the faint opening of field lines behind the NE limb and the post-eruptive arcades peaking from behind the limb seen in AIA 193 starting after 2024-06-20T12:40Z. There is also a very faint ejecta seen (likely behind the limb) in GOES SUVI in the northeast starting at 2024-06-20T13:04Z. There is a very faint front (which could be the shock) preceding a brighter following front, which could be the bulk (or the core) of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the assumption that the source is behind the limb and on a good fit with two coronagraphs. The longitude could vary by +- 10 degrees (to produce a fit with two coronagraphs).

note: A faint CME with no bright front in SOHO LASCO C2 (the front looks like a dark loop in C2 but is brighter in C3 and in STEREO A COR2. Coronal signatures are not very clear. The clearest indication of the source of this CME is a faint movement/opening of field lines in EUVI A 195 near the SE limb, close to AR 3719 (S12E60) after 2024-06-20T12:05Z, followed by minor post-eruptive arcades near this Active Region. In AIA 193 there is some minor activity in AR 3719 seen as well: after 2024-06-20T11:24Z we can see minor post-eruptive arcades forming in this area.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs, corroborated by the location of the likely source (Active Region 13719).

note: Faint, narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. It is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 due to its faintness. The source is unclear, but there are signs of moving field lines visible in SDO AIA 193 prior to the eruption from AR 3719 (approx. S14E50).

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method chosen for this measurement due to the lack of clear source location. The CME's leading edge is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery, and could not be measured with a best fit with SOHO in SWPC_CAT. The CME fades away quickly after early frames of C3 difference imagery.

note: Faint, narrow CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely beyond the east limb. Field line movement and brightening loops can be seen in SDO AIA 193 around 2024-06-20T18:04Z. An additional candidate source beyond the east limb is seen as material departing beyond the east limb in GOES SUVI 304 at 2024-06-20T19:08Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The plane of sky method was chosen for this measurement due to lack of source eruption longitude and no measurable leading edge in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. There are 2 candidate sources: the first is an eruption seen beyond the SE limb in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 283 around 2024-06-20T22:00Z. Shortly after these opening field lines, there was an M5.7 flare peaking at 2024-06-20T23:16Z from AR 3719 (approximately S16E55). However, based on analysis of SDO AIA and GOES SUVI imagery, it is believed that there was not a significant eruption associated with this flare, and field line movement is attributed to activity beyond the east limb. The candidate east limb source eruption is not clearly visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, taking into account potential source eruption beyond east limb. Due to the uncertainty of this measurement, due to lack of visible source location on disk, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The possible source eruption is seen as opening field lines on the east limb, best seen in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-06-21T09:48Z. Field line movement can also be seen in SDO AIA 94/171/193 along the east limb. The eruption is not clearly visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. Due to lack of source location in available EUV imagery, this measurement is approximate, and the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: This CME is visible as a partial halo to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a large eruption visible near/slightly beyond the eastern limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-06-21T23:37Z. A wide opening of field lines is visible near the eastern limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery at this time as well. Based on GONG far-sided imagery, it is possible this eruption occurred from former Active Region 13697. This region would have been located around longitude -110 to -115 degrees at the time of this event based on the rate of solar rotation.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the inner, bright bulk portion based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured longitude was loosely based on the approximate longitude of former Active Region 13697.
Measurement of the fainter shock feature based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to field line movement visible beyond the eastern limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 204-06-22T02:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise location is unknown, the measured longitude may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption visible from beyond the southeast limb starting around 2024-06-23T03:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured longitude may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and subsequent M2.4 flare from Active Region 13716 (N10W75) starting around 2024-06-23T06:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 08:30Z in SDO AIA 131, 171, and 193. This event overlaps with CME: 2024-06-23T07:48Z and CME: 2024-06-23T09:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge was difficult to track as it overlapped and merged slightly with CME: 2024-06-23T07:48Z and surrounding outflow.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an opening of field lines visible beyond the western limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-06-23T06:15Z. This event overlaps with CME: 2024-06-23T07:00Z and CME: 2024-06-23T09:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge of this event was difficult to track as it overlapped with surrounding outflow and the leading edge of CME: 2024-06-23T07:00Z.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an opening of field lines visible near/beyond the western limb starting around 2024-06-23T08:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery. Large post-eruptive arcades form near the western limb starting around 11:00Z as well. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-06-23T07:00Z and CME: 2024-06-23T07:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured longitude may vary slightly.

note: Slow CME with the flux rope structure and a cavity clearly seen in coronagraphs. The source may be a minor slowly developing dimming at (S40E20) in AIA 193 around noon. The CME is probably associated with an eruption of one of the narrow filaments stretching from SE to NW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the possible source - a minor slowly developing dimming at (S40E20) in AIA 193 around noon, corroborating the lat/lon derived by fitting with two coronagraphs perfectly. The CME is probably associated with an eruption of one of the narrow filaments stretching from SE to NW.

note: A faint narrow CME in SSE seen in early timestamps in both coronagraphs. No clear source have been found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: There is no clear source in EUV imagery and the front of this CME can be fit with a very wide range of longitudes (from -30 to -70 deg), so only POS analysis is definitive.

note: Bright 3-part CME with an even wider shock front. The start of the CME might be a bit earlier but it is more likely that there is a preceding front of a narrower precursor CME that gets swept into the 2024-06-24T02:48Z CME. The clear source of this CME is an eruption starting around 2024-06-24T01Z off of or behind the SW limb and seen as an unusually long/persistant brightening off of the SW limb seen in AIA 131/335 between 2024-06-24T01Z and as opening  of field lines on/behind the SW limb in AIA 193/171 starting after 2024-06-24T01Z. The opening of field lines starts as relatively narrow but becomes wider after 2024-06-24T02Z and is followed by very high rising post-eruptive arcades seen  on/just behind the SW limb. It is likely that the eruption is from Active Region 3712 which was at ~S25W91 at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the assumption that the CME is associated with Active Region 3712 which was at S25W91 (behind the limb) at the time. The fit in two coronagraphs corroborates this.

note: A very faint CME with a fuzzy unclear front that is visible only in a few early timestamps in SOHO C2/C3 coronagraph and super faintly in STEREO A COR2. No source has been found.

cmeAnalyses.note: No clear source has been found. The fit with two coronagraphs can be obtained with longitudes from 60 to 90 degrees but the front is extremely faint in both coronagraphs. POS measurement is the only definitive measurement.

note: Narrow and faint CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Source is opening field lines seen starting around 2024-06-24T19:54Z in SDO AIA 171/193. Post-eruptive arcades become visible in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 starting around 2024-06-24T23:22Z. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to both faintness of the leading edge and a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-06-24T15:38Z to 2024-06-24T23:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using source location observed in UV imagery and best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to both faintness of the leading edge and a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-06-24T15:38Z to 2024-06-24T23:53Z.

note: Partial halo CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a large filament eruption. The filament extended from approximately N15W55 to S30W15 on the disk, with liftoff seen starting around 2024-06-24T21:40Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive loops are visible in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: A CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2, C3 and STEREO A COR2. The leading edge is unclear. Source is opening field lines seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193 and an M1.0 flare from Active Region 13723 peaking at 2024-06-25T12:45Z best seen in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of somewhat messy leading edge based on source location and best fit between coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME visible in the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SE in STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption centered around S10W05, between ARs 3719 and 3720. Liftoff and brightening starting around 2024-06-25T22:18Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME was difficult to measure due to it's faintness in available coronagraph imagery.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source may be beyond the west limb. Opening field lines are visible on/beyond the limb from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195 starting at approximately 2024-06-26T02:05Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, also taking in account source location beyond the west limb. Due to the uncertainty in source location, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible in the east of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Some candidate source eruptions in the east include a small eruption with brightening starting around 2024-06-26T05:40Z in SDO AIA 335 to the northeast of AR 3723 (approx. S15E50). Field line movement is also visible on the east limb in SDO AIA 171/193/335 as well, but there is no clear source eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 and candidate source location around longitude E50.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source can be seen near the limb in SDO AIA imagery, and it best seen as opening field lines in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at approximately 2024-06-26T09:30Z. The eruption is also visible in SDO AIA 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs, but only briefly in one frame of STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. The source is a long-duration eruption from AR 3728 alongside a long-duration C6.2 flare which peaked at 2024-06-26T15:30Z, best seen in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as some accompanying field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193 that gets deflected southward from this region, and some small brightening in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made mainly off of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery using the AR 3728 source longitude (with the observed southward deflection), with only one available STEREO COR2A frame making for an unideal triangulation.

note: CME seen to the SW in all coronagraphs. Source is likely an eruption near AR 3719, with a C2.0 class flare occurring just SW of the region, which peaked at 2024-06-27T17:12Z and best observed in SDO AIA 131. Also observed as field line motion and brightening of erupting material in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made via triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding some southward deflection from the source of AR 3719 (S17W42).

note: Thin CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is not certain, only potentially observed in SDO AIA 171 as moving field lines over the SE limb around 2024-06-28T20:55Z, indicating a source may exist on or near the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery given the uncertain source and poor STEREO COR2A running difference data quality as it is mid-campaign.

note: Faint partial halo seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and just to the SE in STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME is not entirely certain, but appears to originate from the cluster of ARs 3723, 3727, 3728, centered roughly around S20E25 (as such, this is used as the CME source coordinates). Some small C-class flaring is observed here as early as 2024-06-27T19:45Z, more noticeable closer to 2024-06-27T21:24Z possibly due to post-eruptive loops observed across SDO AIA 94/131/171/193. However, more confidence in this area is given via a good triangulation of the CME front between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A in swpc_cat when measuring.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made via triangulation of the front between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a fit roughly in the SE near the location of a cluster of ARs. The CME is notably faint and hard to follow in SOHO imagery due to the more direct angle, but STEREO imagery offers a better side-angle of the front that helps triangulate this as a front-sided longitude.

note: CME seen to the W in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain and unobserved in SDO AIA imagery, analyzed as a plane-of-sky for its speed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery given the uncertain source and poor STEREO COR2A running difference data quality as it is mid-campaign.

note: CME with a hazy leading edge seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption at S20W62, at AR 3719, starting at 2024-06-29T03:09Z as seen in SDO AIA 304. Ejecta can be seen throughout the eruption in SDO AIA 304 and 171. Opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193. Eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 193 and 304. The CME:2024-06-29T04:00Z overlaps with this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using source location seen in UV imagery and best fit between coronagraphs. STEREO-A was in a campaign which affected STEREO-A COR2 difference imagery for this CME.

note: Very faint loop CME seen to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a bit elusive, but may possibly be the liftoff of some filamentary material from one of the many filaments currently on the Earth-facing disk. Based on a stereoscopic measurement (with Lat:-17 and Lon:36), this may possibly be the liftoff of some material from a filament visible in SDO AIA 304 imagery which spanned from S40W10 to S25W60 at the start time of this CME. This CME overlaps with CME:2024-06-29T03:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using best fit between coronagraphs. STEREO-A was in a campaign which affected STEREO-A COR2 difference imagery for this CME.

note: Wide CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and S/SW in STEREO A COR2. The source is a large filament eruption spanning from S30E10 to S20W40. Liftoff seen starting at about 2024-06-29T15:09Z in SDO AIA 304. Dimming and post-eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 193. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195/304 after a data gap from 2024-06-29T13:05Z to 2024-06-29T17:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SW in STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption centered around S55W30 in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-06-29T16:47Z. This partially overlaps with the filament eruption associated with CME: 2024-06-29T16:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as leading edge using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption from AR 3719 (S15W65) with brightening and opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at 2024-06-29T21:08Z. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Very faint CME visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The start time is approximate due to the slow, faint nature of the CME in the field of view of SOHO LASCO C2, and the CME becomes more prominent in C2 around 2024-06-30T08:12Z. The source is unclear, but may be a slow eruption starting at 2024-06-30T00:07Z centered near the central meridian, around N20, best seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. Deflection in the field of view is possible, or a portion of the CME may not be measurable due to the CME's faintness.

note: Faint, narrow CME seen in the west of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME starts out slowly in SOHO LASCO C2. The source may be visible off the west limb as slow rising field lines in SDO AIA 171/193 around 2024-06-30T03:57Z. A faint dimming may also be seen on the disk, around N10W80, from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195, but this eruption is unclear.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO chosen due to limited usable STEREO A imagery, lack of clear measurable leading edge in coronagraph imagery, and the uncertainty in source location.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption best seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304 from AR 3719 in the southwest starting around 2024-06-30T13:37Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery usable for this measurement.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Only visible in early frames of STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-06-30T17:09Z to 2024-06-30T23:39Z. The source is an eruption from AR 3734 (approx. N10E65) which may have an associated C2.1 class flare peaking at 2024-06-30T15:49Z. Brightening is seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, based on source location.

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an M2.1 flare peaking at 2024-07-01T11:02Z from AR 13730 (approx. S19W37). The flare is best seen in SDO AIA 131, the ejection of material following the flare can be seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304, and opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171/193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location, with slight adjustment for best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. The CME may deflect in the field of view.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-07-01T13:09Z to 2024-07-02T03:09Z. The source is not clearly visible in available SDO or STEREO A EUV imagery, and may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of source location.

note: CME visible to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the S/SE of STEREO A COR2. The source is likely a filament eruption centered around S35E10 with liftoff seen in SDO AIA 304 around 2024-07-02T02:27Z. Dimming is visible in SDO AIA 193, opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 171, and post-eruptive arcades are best seen in SDO AIA 193 and 335. The eruption is also visible in the SE from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT. There may be a fainter front, possible a shock, ahead of this measurement, but it was deemed not measurable with available imagery. STEREO A imagery is limited to 2 frames due to ongoing campaign.

note: CME visible in the southwest of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not found in available EUV imagery, but faint field line movement may be seen beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-07-02T06:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The leading edge of this CME was not clearly measurable in STEREO A COR2. The plane-of-sky method was chosen due to lack of clear source location.

note: Faint CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Due to it's faintness, it is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption on or just beyond the east limb from the point of view of SDO EUV imagery. An eruption can be seen on the limb starting at 2024-07-02T05:20Z, around latitude S15, in SDO AIA 335. Opening field lines are also seen in SDO AIA 171/193, and post-eruptive loops are best seen in SDO AIA 335.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location on east limb using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only. The CME was not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery and was not utilized for this measurement. Due to the uncertainty in the source location on the limb, the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source appears to be an eruption with moving/opening field lines from AR13730, possibly associated with a lower level C-class flare as seen in SDO/AIA 193 and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The leading edge becomes diffuse quickly and is difficult to track in later frames. This measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and after a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a C4.7 flare from AR3730 visible in SDO/AIA 131 with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of CME features using source location. STEREO A COR2 imagery was not usable in measurement due to ongoing campaign impacting difference imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is an M1.5 flare from AR13730 as seen in SDO/AIA 131 with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based off of the source of the CME and the best fit of the CME features in difference imagery. STEREO A COR2 difference imagery was not used in this measurement due to an ongoing campaign impacting image availability.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption from Active Region 13730 (S20W65) starting around 2024-07-03T10:57Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Minor field line movement is visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. There is only one frame available in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to an ongoing campaign, so the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to an ongoing campaign. The source is likely an eruption and M1.0 flare from Active Region 13723 (S21W74) starting around 2024-07-04T14:25Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to an ongoing STEREO campaign, only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery was available for this event. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source is a filament eruption with only a narrow stream of ejecta actually lifting off the solar disk as seen in SDO/AIA and GOES SUVI 304. The feature appears to have a narrow portion related to the ejecta that separated from the more rounded filament eruption which may have contributed to a fainter wider front that disappears before exiting the C2 field of view. There are associated moving/opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky parameters based on the fit of the narrow feature related to the filament ejecta that was able to release from the sun. The wider portion which is not visible beyond C2 had a measured POS speed of 331 km/s, a lat of -9 degrees, and a half-width of 45 degrees.

note: Streamer blowout CME to the N/NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to unclear source location and lack of stereoscopic viewpoints.

note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source is an M1.4 flare from AR13730 with associated moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 193 and 171 as well as GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on apparent source location and best fit of CME features in SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery.

note: CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is uncertain, but there are two possible candidates, both seen starting at about 2024-07-06T17:00Z in SDO AIA 171 and 193: opening field lines on or just beyond the W limb, centered at about N05 or some field line movement/possible small field line opening/possible small post-eruptive arcades seen from ARs 3729 and 3733 (S05W50 and N05W50, respectively).

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement taken using best fit between coronagraphs, which matched one of the two candidate source locations seen on UV imagery of the Earth-facing disk.

note: CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO-A COR2. Source is opening field lines on the SW limb, most likely from Active Region 13724 which was at about S15W110 at the time of the eruption, as seen in SDO AIA 171/193 starting at 2024-07-05T18:57Z. There is also some movement/activity centered at S05W50 on the disk at a similar time, but the movement more likely to be associated with this eruption seems to be from the SW limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement taken using best fit between coronagraphs and approximate source location based on UV imagery of the Earth-facing disk.

note: CME and streamer blowout visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. An exact source is unclear, but there is continuous slow field line movement in the NE quadrant of the disk close to the NE limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs.

note: Messy CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is field line movement from beyond the SW limb seen starting at 2024-07-05T20:52Z in GOES SUVI 284. This movement is also seen in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-07-05T21:27Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement taken using best fit between coronagraphs and assessment that the location of the source is beyond the southwest limb of the Earth-facing disk based on UV imagery.

note: Another messy loop CME seen to the W/SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is field line movement seen on the W limb in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-07-06T12:16Z. Possibly some very subtle opening field lines and a possible post-eruptive arcade with footpoints at N05W70 and S05W70 seen in SDO AIA 171 around 2024-07-06T11:21Z (opening field lines) and 2024-07-06T14:10Z (arcade). Data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery from 2024-07-06T13:38Z to 2024-07-06T15:38Z affected analysis of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the partially visible leading edge which precedes the core portion with the same shape. Measurement using best fit between coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption near S03E62 starting around 2024-07-07T10:50Z as seen in SDO AIA 131 and 193 imagery. Field line movement is visible near the eastern limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event becomes diffuse and difficult to measure after a few early frames. This measurement relies on early imagery as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and subsequent C4.2 flare from Active Region 13740 (S18W24) starting around 2024-07-08T11:10Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured longitude deviates about 20 degrees west of the source location, possibly due to deflection from the source eruption.

note: Faint CME in the west mostly seen in SOHO coronagraphs (only one, poor quality, image is available from STEREO A because of a large data gap). No clear source have been found. There is a preceding eruption from Active Region 13740 (S18W26) starting around 2024-07-08T14:45Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery, however the analysis with this longitude does not produce a good fit when using the single available STEREO image.

cmeAnalyses.note: No clear source for this CME has been found. There is only one timestamp in STEREO A coronagraph available and it is of a very poor quality, so POS measurement is most appropriate.

note:
A relatively bright complex-shaped CME with two lobes seen in the west in coronagraphs. The source is likely a clear opening of field lines seen in SUVI 284 on or behind the west limb after 2024-07-08T21:30Z. STIX instrument on the SolarOrbiter registered an equivalent of an M1.1 flare from the west limb (for Solar Orbiter) at 2024-07-08T21:21Z, confirming the possible source of this CME as behind the west limb (for SOHO and STEREO A). 
An alternative source could be an eruption between Active Regions 3739 and 3734 centered (~S02W50) which is first seen around 2024-07-08T21:20Z in AIA 304 and (as minor dimming) in AIA 193, however the fit of this CME with two coronagraphs gives higher longitudes than 50 degrees (between 90 and 110 degrees).

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate measurement because the source is likely behind (or on) the limb and because the CME front is relatively faint in coronagraphs. The fit with 2 coronagraphs favors the on-limb or behind the limb source, with the variability of longitude  from at least 90 to 110 degrees.

Because the CME source has not been found on the Earth-facing disk and is likely backsided, but the analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs gives a range of possible longitudes, it is beneficial to also make a plane of sky measurement of this CME.

note: An extremely faint and slow CME in the southeast only seen in the early imagery in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 (and not seen in C3 because of its faintness). Its source could possibly be seemingly sympathetic eruptions in Active Region 3738 (S08E26), accompanied by a C-class flare, and Active Region 3736 (S18W04). The area between these two active region register a very faint but large-area dimming seen starting after 2024-07-09T05:30Z and centered around S25E20.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs and supported by a faint dimming between two active regions as a possible source. The CME front is very faint (not seen in SOHO LASCO C3 at all) and the source is very faint, resulting in the high uncertainty of analysis.

note: Very faint and narrow CME to the southwest seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, seen for only a few early frames in C3 because of its faintness. The source is very uncertain, as there are several small movements of field lines and small areas of brightening occurring across the disk at the time, however, the strongest candidate is a very small eruption from Active Region 13740 (S18W52) seen as very narrowly opening field lines around 2024-07-10T08:15Z in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement using three frames of SOHO LASCO C2. Faint leading edge becomes too diffuse to track after only three frames of C2, and is altogether too faint to track the same feature reliably in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Complex shaped asymmetrical halo first seen in SOHO to the northeast but then encompassing the whole sun. It has a clear, narrower bulk to the northeast and a more wider farsided shock. It looks like a full halo in STEREO A after a long data gap which ends at 2024-07-11T23:38Z, with only one COR2 image showing the whole CME front before the CME exits the field-of-view of the coronagraph. No source on the earth-facing side has been found in EUV imagery, so it is clearly a backsided event. One possible indication of the farsided eruption may be a slight fast movement of field lines in the northeast seen in GOES SUVI 284 at ~2024-07-10T21:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: This analysis is based on the fit with two coronagraphs for the wider and slightly fainter more full-halo like shock front (vs the more partial halo bulk to the NW in SOHO).
Analysis based on the best fit of the more NE brighter front of this complex-shaped CME with two coronagraphs.
Initial, very approximate, analysis based on a fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Narrow CME in the northeast in coronagraphs where the source is a filament eruption beyond the northeast limb clearly seen in AIA 171/193/304 lifting off after 2024-07-11T01:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit in coronagraphs. Longitudes could range between approximately -100 and -110 degrees.

note: A narrow faint CME/Jet to the southwest where the source is an eruption in Active Region 13740 (S18W64) seen at 2024-07-11T05:30Z in AIA 193 as a fast ejecta from the active region and a minor dimming.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the location of the source (eruption in Active Region 3740) and confirmed by the fit of the front in two coronagraphs.

note: Bright CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Well-defined leading edge with cavity containing material following. Source is a streamer blowout seen as opening field lines and possible slow-moving ejecta originating from about N10W90 in SDO AIA 131/171/193 at about 2024-07-11T21:12Z-23:58Z. Small eruption with ejecta seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2024-07-11T14:13Z, but it slows down significantly before leaving the FOV and is possibly the triggering eruption for this streamer blowout. A broader opening of field lines can be seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting later at 2024-07-11T20:01Z. Small eruption with ejecta is also seen in SDO AIA 171/193, but possible relationship to streamer blowout is most clearly seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured using best fit, which yielded a longitude closer to W80 than originally estimated W90. Smaller eruption noted in CME note was located at approx. W80.

note: Faint 3-part CME clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is the eruption of a filament located just beyond the SE limb, with one endpoint visible at S30E90 and the rest of the filament extending beyond the SE limb, which later makes itself known as ejecta, twisting as it erupts and clearly from beyond the limb as seen in SDO AIA 304. Movement of material seen in SDO AIA 304 starts as early at 2024-07-12T04:11Z, with full liftoff seen at 2024-07-12T05:15Z. Ejection of material and moving field lines are seen in SDO AIA 131/171/193 around 2024-07-12T05:15Z. This eruption is also seen in STEREO A EUVI 304 and faintly in EUVI 193 starting at 2024-07-12T05:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Filament spanned from E90 to likely several tens of degrees beyond the SE limb, as evidenced by UV imagery. Several attempts to measure were made, each time using longitudes that were progressively further beyond the E limb. Longitude E124 produced the best stereoscopic fit between coronagraphs.

note: Extremely faint CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is a 'second push' of the filamentary material / continuation of the filament eruption from beyond the SE limb, which first resulted in CME: 2024-07-12T06:12Z. This additional filamentary material is seen ejecting from beyond the SE limb starting around 2024-07-12T07:06Z in SDO AIA 304/171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of very faint leading edge, using best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Leading edge is too diffuse to track with confidence in SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery.

note: A very faint but fast partial halo CME covered by a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 and first seen in C3. The source (initially very hard to identify) was found in GOES SUVI 304 as a long but faint filament erupting (likely) behind the ENE limb starting at 2024-07-12T22:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis of the brighter narrower bulk front of this CME based on the best fit in two coronagraphs, somewhat confirmed by the potential source - a behind the ENE limb filament.
Approximate analysis of the fainter and wider likely shock front of this CME based on the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: Jet-like CME to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Source appears to be moving/opening field lines along the NE limb as seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-07-14T09:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO and STEREO A difference imagery. Measurable longitudes were between -90 to -80 degrees with speeds ranging between 700 km/s to 750 km/s.

note: A very faint slow CME in the southeast, largely covered by a data gap in STEREO A coronagraph. The source is likely beyond the southeast limb, with some minor movement of field lines observed on/beyond the limb. There is some on-disk activity in the southeast quadrant starting around 2024-07-14T13:18Z, however the timing of it is imperfect and this on-disk eruption is very small.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. The source is unclear.

note: Narrow fast jet with a brighter narrower bulk and a fainter also narrow shock. One potential source - unspecified flaring and rising loops on the NE limb simultaneous with the flare from Active Region 3738 in the west - is not supported by the analysis using the best fit of this narrow CME with two coronagraphs, which indicates an off-the-limb location.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. The fit points to the active region 3752 (N22E63) as the source of this CME, however all coronal signatures indicate a location close to the limb.

note: A very minor (slow, faint) CME associated with the M2.7 flare from AR 3738. Coronal signatures include opening of field lines on the NW limb and post eruptive arcades, as well as a dimming that is best seen in STEREO EUVI A 195 starting at 09:25Z. The CME is well seen only in SOHO LASCO C2 and is very faintly seen only in a couple initial timestamps of STEREO A COR2; is not seen in C3 at all b/c of faintness.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the location of the associated flare and is confirmed by the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a prominence eruption visible off the NE limb in SDO AIA 304 with liftoff starting around 2024-07-16T00:08Z. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171/193/335, brightening best seen in SDO AIA 94/131/193, and post-eruptive arcades are best seen in SDO AIA 94/171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, and may be beyond the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Measured longitudes ranged between -80 to -95 degrees with speeds between ~850 km/s to ~930 km/s depending on the longitude used.

note: Faint CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. It is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 white light imagery, and may be obscured by the instrument pylon. The potential source is an M3.6 flare peaking at 2024-07-16T07:37Z from Active Region 3753 (approx. N10W25). There is a data gap in SDO imagery from approximately 2024-07-16T07:07Z to 2024-07-16T07:47Z, but following this gap, post-eruptive arcades and dimming can be seen in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: This measurement uses SOHO LASCO C2 imagery only due to the CME's faintness in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery. The CME was not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not yet visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. Associated with an X1.9 flare from AR 3738 (approx. S09W75) peaking at 2024-07-16T13:26Z as seen in SDO AIA 131. EUV wave visible in SDO AIA 193 and opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 171/193/335. Post-eruptive arcades are also visible.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement of the bulk leading edge of the CME using additional SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.
Measurement of the fainter, wider, potential shock feature of this CME, with slight adjustment to longitude for the CME fit in SWPC_CAT.
Very preliminary measurement based on limited available SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to current gap in downlink period. This CME will be remeasured when more imagery is available.

note: Narrow, faint, jet-like CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The potential source may be opening field lines visible in SDO AIA 171/193 starting around 2024-07-16T16:57Z. It may be associated with a dimming observed around S50E30 starting at 2024-07-16T17:28Z, but this is believed to be a better candidate for the CME first observed in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-07-16T19:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky method chosen due to lack of clear source location and no available STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The candidate source eruption is best seen as dimming in SDO AIA 193 near S50E30 starting around 2024-07-16T17:57Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, based on source location.

note: Faint CME seen as a halo in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and a partial halo in STEREO A COR2. The source is an M1.9 flare from AR 3744 (approx. N18W11) with peak time 2024-07-16T22:06Z. EUV wave, opening field lines, and dimming are best seen in SDO AIA 171/193. The eruption is not visible in STEREO A EUV imagery due to a data gap from 2024-07-16T13:35Z to 23:35Z. While there is some field line opening associated with another M-class flare shortly beforehand, M1.6 with peak time 2024-07-16T21:24Z, the broad area of dimming is more clearly associated with this later M1.9 flare.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.
Preliminary measurement based on faint halo feature of CME, which may possibly be the shock. The CME may deflect from the source location.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. This was determined to likely be separate from CME: 2024-07-16T23:12Z. There were multiple source candidates for this CME, with the best candidate being an eruption with moving/opening field lines from AR 13751 around 2024-07-16T20:27Z as seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Associated with an M5.0 flare seen in SDO AIA 131 from S10W30 (AR 13743) which had a peak time of 2024-07-17T06:39Z. Dimming is seen in SDO AIA 193, opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 171, and post-eruptive brightening is seen in SDO AIA 131/193/304. Seen in SDO AIA imagery before a shutter maneuver/eclipse lasting from 17/07:07Z to 17/07:48Z. Seen also in GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Filament eruption seen to the SE in all coronagraphs, but only a few frames of STEREO COR2A due to a data gap over this period from 2024-07-17T13:38Z-T23:38Z with a rogue image at T20:23Z that assisted with triangulation. The source is a filament sitting on or just inside the SE limb around S32E90, which began to erupt around 2024-07-17T17:00Z. The start of this eruption was observed in SDO AIA 131/171/193/211/304 but cut short due to a shutter maneuver, GOES SUVI 171/195/284/304 caught the entire, spectacular filament eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis including both outermost lobes of the CME front together (including a diffuse nose seen in C2 that protrudes out from the main, bright loop), as they initially travel separately but catch up and travel together in the latest frames of C3. Using source of the filament on the limb at E90 and is not a plane-of-sky measurement.

Analysis of the bright, inside loop of this CME, inside of the diffuse nose viewed in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Some uncertainty lies in which feature of this CME is the most trackable leading edge, but this measurement has similar parameters and speed to the wider measurement including all features. Using source of the filament on the limb at E90 and is not a plane-of-sky measurement.

note: Faint loop CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is slowly opening field lines seen on the SE limb in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-07-17T23:00Z, immediately following the liftoff of a filament, also on the SE limb, which was the source for CME:2024-07-17T9:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement using an abundance of frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. The exact source location is uncertain due to the faintness of the field line movement identified as the candidate source in UV imagery, but it is possible that the true longitude is in fact close to E90.

note: Very faint loop CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear/indiscernible. May be part of continued outflow following the filament eruption on the SE limb which was the source for CME:2024-07-17T9:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Faint CME with an irregular and faint leading edge seen to the South/slightly SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and for a few frames in STEREO A COR2. The source is a bit uncertain, but the strongest candidate is an eruption with ~10 degree wide opening field lines and the ejection of a small amount of material faintly seen from on or just beyond the SE limb in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-07-18T06:40Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Very faint and narrow CME seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to data gap lasting from 2024-07-18T13:38Z to 2024-07-18T17:53Z. Source is likely on the far side due to lack of clear source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement of very diffuse leading edge using several frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and two frames of C3 imagery.

note: Extremely faint loop CME visible to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is likely on the far side due to lack of clear source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between coronagraphs.

note: A minor faint jet seen in SOHO LASCO C2, C3 and in SOHO LASCO COR2. No clear source was found on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: A speculative measurement since the source has not been found and analysis is solely based on the fitting with two coronagraphs. Front-sided longitudes do not yield a fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Semi-faint CME to the east in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. A potential source is seen as moving/opening field lines in GOES SUVI 284 along the eastern limb starting around 2024-07-19T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on a plane-of-sky fit using swpc_cat difference imagery.

note: CME visible in the SE of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Overlaps with CME: 2024-07-19T22:24Z in the field of view of the coronagraphs. The source is likely a filament eruption stretching diagonally from S40E20 to S20W02 starting around 2024-07-19T18:30Z with dimming seen in SDO AIA 193 and post-eruptive arcades beginning around 2024-07-19T20:30Z as seen in SDO/AIA 304 and 193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery following a data gap from 2024-07-19T13:35Z to 22:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location.

note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Overlaps with CME: 2024-07-19T20:36Z in the field of view of the coronagraphs. The potential source may be a secondary eruption near the filament eruption centered around S30W15 as seen in SDO AIA 304 imagery starting around 2024-07-19T18:30Z. Dimming can be seen slightly south of this eruption, near S35E10, starting around 2024-07-19T20:37Z in SDO AIA 193. It is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery following a data gap from 2024-07-19T13:35Z to 22:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location.

note: CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain, and only possibly observed in EUV imagery in GOES SUVI 284 loosely around 2024-07-20T20:00Z as some field line movement high over the SE limb. However, this CME triangulated well to ~E130 between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs and unwell to on-disk longitudes, so this CME is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement of this CME between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A given the uncertain source longitude, finding a good far-sided fit (and a poor on-disk fit) around E120-E140.

note: Bright CME seen to the WNW in all coronagraphs. The source is an eruption from AR 3744 and M1.4 flare which peaked at 2024-07-21T03:55Z (best observed in SDO AIA 131). Also observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 as rapidly opening field line movement starting around 2024-07-21T03:28Z followed immediately by a post-eruptive arcade.

cmeAnalyses.note: Well triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A using the source of AR 3744, finding a great fit at these coordinates. This measurement excludes C2 and some earliest C3 and COR2A frames to provide a more accurate final speed, as some acceleration was observed in the measurement with every frame.

note: CME seen to the W in all coronagraphs. The source for this is uncertain, with the only potential source being activity just inside, on, or beyond the west limb given CME history in the area. Field line movement is observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 171/195/284 starting slowly around 2024-07-21T10:00Z, alongside post-eruptive arcades slowly becoming visible on the limb around 2024-07-21T12:00Z in those wavelengths, however that source may better align with CME 2024-07-21T12:12 than this one.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME seen to the WNW in all coronagraphs, but only in earliest frames of STEREO COR2A due to a data gap beginning at 2024-07-21T13:53Z. The source for this is likely field line movement just inside, on, or just behind the WNW limb observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 171/195/284 starting slowly around 2024-07-21T10:00Z, alongside post-eruptive arcades slowly becoming visible on the limb around 2024-07-21T12:00Z in those wavelengths.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, given the visible EUV source but unclear specific longitude. Despite only having a few available COR2A frames, this was enough to get a good fit around W85-W95, settling on W88 as the best fit.

note: Narrow, faint CME seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source appears to be moving/opening field lines along the eastern limb as seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-07-21T16:13Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement due to lack of stereoscopic viewpoints of the CME.

note: Halo CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. STEREO A COR2 is in a data gap during this event. The source of this CME appears to be an M1.0 flare from AR13757 (N15E20) peaking at 2024-07-21T16:31Z. Filament ejecta is visible in SDO/AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304 with significant northward deflection. The bulk of the CME is likely the brighter portion visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery to the NE. The fainter halo portion is possibly associated with this event, though there is some uncertainty due to a lack of visible dimming to the south of the source location.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based off of the best fit of the suspected BULK of the CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO difference imagery. No STEREO A COR2 imagery is available for this CME.
Parameters based on the potential SHOCK feature using SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 difference imagery. There is uncertainty with this analysis due to lack of stereoscopic viewpoints.

note: CME seen to the E in all coronagraphs. The source is uncertain, and may be associated with active regions rotating onto the east limb and weak field line movement in GOES SUVI 284. This entry is for a brighter, more thin loop that appears first in SOHO before being followed by a slower, diffuse front that measured plane-of-sky at 210 km/s and 45 degree half width.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement given the uncertain source of this CME and diffuse nature of the front/entire eruption.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to slow field line movement visible near or slightly beyond the southeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-07-22T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured longitude may vary slightly as the source is far-sided and a precise source location is therefore unknown.

note: This CME is visible as a far-sided halo in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery, with the bulk of the material directed towards the northwest. The source is likely far-sided as faint field line movement is visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 171, 193, 284 imagery starting around 2024-07-22T23:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the inner bulk feature based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.. Multiple measurements produced speeds ranging from 1277 km/s to 1544 km/s and longitudes spanning 170 to 176 degrees.

Measurement of the possible shock feature based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Multiple shock measurements produced speeds ranging from 1544 km/s to 1691 km/s. It is difficult to obtain a decent fit of the entire shock feature in both SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This measurement therefore focuses on the brighter, northern shock feature without compromising on the fit between coronagraphs.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is an eruption in the SW quadrant of the Earth-facing disk, spanning from S20-S40 and from W40-W50, near Active Region 13749. Dimming is seen in SDO AIA 193, brightening is seen in SDO AIA 304, brightening and brief arcades are seen in SDO AIA 131 at 2024-07-23T03:52Z, dimming and opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 171. This eruption is also seen in STEREO A EUVI 193/304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using source location and best fit between a multitude of frames in C2/C3 and four frames of STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Leading edge is extremely faint in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery, but the feature is just visible enough to track for a few frames.

note: Faint, narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. A potential source may be seen as field line movement off the SE limb starting around 2024-07-23T03:48Z in SDO AIA 171/193, but no clear source eruption is visible on the disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to lack of source location. The leading edge was not clearly measurable in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Bright CME seen to the E in all coronagraphs. The source is an M2.4 flare from an unnumbered region on the SE limb around S10E77, which peaked at 2024-07-23T14:28Z, best seen in SDO AIA 131. Also observed starting around 2024-07-23T13:34Z as rapid field line opening with an EUV wave, followed by post-eruptive arcades, in SDO AIA 171/193/211 with surface brightening in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Improved BULK measurement as SOHO data backfilled shortly after the prelim measurement (and prior to sending a notification from it). Better triangulated between SOHO and STEREO to the source of E77, and does not include the poor quality frames of SOHO LASCO C3 in the latest frames of this CME.

SHOCK measurement triangulated between SOHO and STEREO imagery. While the source is at E77, that does not visually fit swpc_cat well even in one coronagraph, and requires heavy deflection east or west to fit, favoring a front-sided fit around E30-E40. Some uncertainty lies in this shock analysis as a result.

Preliminary BULK measurement of the CME using only STEREO COR2A data and the source of the M2.4 flare as a basis, finding a good visual fit around E70. SOHO LASCO C3 is used roughly to help line up to E70--but poor data quality prevented reliable use of C3 for an actual measurement. SOHO has yet to backfill data covering this CME outside of the latest frames, and imagery currently available is choppy and not usable, so this presented analysis is the best possible until SOHO downlinks data over this period and is subject to change upon further analysis.

note: Faint CME visible to the east in STEREO A COR2. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real-time due to a data gap starting at approx. 2024-07-23T23:54Z. Rising loops and opening field lines are visible on the SE limb in SDO AIA 171/193 starting around 2024-07-24T23:40Z, but there is no clear associated activity visible on the disk, and this eruption may be beyond the east limb of the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery. No SOHO imagery was available at the time of this measurement and no source longitude could be determined based on the eruption signature in EUV imagery.

note: CME visible along the NE streamer in STEREO A COR2. The start time is unclear due to the CME's slow start in the coronagraphs. The source is unclear, and the CME may be backsided. SOHO LASCO imagery was not available for this CME in real-time due to a data gap starting around 2024-07-23T23:54Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on a possible source location (filament eruption visible in SDO AIA 304 imagery centered near N30E80 at 2024-07-24T05:15Z). The measured parameters may vary slightly as there is no stereoscopic viewpoint available due to a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery at the time of this event.
Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2. This method was chosen due to lack of clear source location, and no SOHO LASCO imagery available for a measurement.

note: CME visible to the west in STEREO A COR2. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in real time due to a data gap. The source is likely an M3.6 flare peaking at 2024-07-24T07:42Z from AR 3751 (approx. S08W60). There is a gap in SDO AIA imagery from ~2024-07-24T06:48Z to 07:45Z, but the eruption is visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and GOES SUVI imagery. The flare is best seen in GOES SUVI 131, EUV wave and opening field lines are visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and GOES SUVI 195/171 starting around 2024-07-24T07:40Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery only due to lack of SOHO imagery. Longitude based on approximate source location.

Measurement of the wider, faint, faster shock feature ahead of the leading edge of the CME. This measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery only due to lack of available SOHO imagery, and the longitude is based on the approximate source location.

note: Visible in the west of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 following a data gap spanning from 2024-07-23T23:48Z to 2024-07-24T15:48Z and COR2A following a data gap from 2024-07-24T13:53Z to 16:53Z. The source may be associated with rising field line movement seen off the west limb in SDO AIA 193 around 2024-07-24T10:57Z. A small eruption from AR 3751 is seen in the hours prior to this CME, however the eruption is not clear in EUV imagery

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of clear source location. The leading edge was not clearly measurable in COR2A imagery as it was far out in the field of view.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is related to an M3.0 flare and associated eruption from Active Region 13751 (S08W70) starting around 2024-07-24T17:10Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Field line movement is visible near the western limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption and subsequent opening of field lines visible on or near the western limb starting around 2024-07-24T18:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. This event partially overlaps with CME: 2024-07-24T17:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and opening of field lines visible just beyond the eastern limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-07-24T22:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The northern part of the front that sticks out ahead of a smoother front closer to the bulk of the CME was excluded from the measurement due to fitting constraints.

This is a preliminary plane-of-sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery with a longitude of -70 degrees. The source is likely near or beyond the western limb, with a measured longitude likely closer to -90 degrees.

note: Messy halo CME seen with a bulk portion to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Solar Orbiter detected an estimated X7 class flare on the far side peaking at  2024-07-24T23:25Z that may be the source of this halo feature.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit of the bulk of the halo. Fainter portions of the wider halo visible to the south/southeast were excluded from this measurement. Different portions of the CME were analyzed to confirm far sided parameters.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. A candidate source eruption may be an eruption from AR 3762 (S12E10) starting around 2024-07-25T00:30Z in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. The dimming extends as far as longitude E40 in SDO AIA 193 imagery, and the CME may exhibit deflection in the field of view of the coronagraphs. Another candidate source may be eruptive activity seen from the SE cluster of ARs, AR 3764, 3765, or 3766.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. The CME may deflect in the field of view from the source location.
