The source is an eruption and subsequent M3.2 flare from AR 3842 (S18E09) starting around 2024-10-02T13:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery from 2024-10-02T14:08Z to 2024-10-02T17:08Z, in addition to being in campaign mode for the Parker Solar Probe perihelion pass which affects COR2A image quality and cadence.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made using source longitude as seen in UV imagery, as well as best fit using multiple SOHO LASCO C2/C3 frames and only one good frame of STEREO A COR2. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery from 2024-10-02T14:08Z to 2024-10-02T17:08Z, in addition to being in campaign mode for the Parker Solar Probe perihelion pass which affects COR2A image quality and cadence.

note: CME visible to the N/NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is opening field lines seen at a high northern latitude and beyond the N/NW limb in SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-10-02T16:17Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 which is in campaign mode, but the CME was visible for several frames.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-03T08:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption centered at approx. N25E70 with liftoff beginning at approx. 2024-10-03T07:30Z as seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304. Field line opening can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284. This filament erupted gradually, so there is a small amount of material seen preceding the main bulk of the CME from which the measurement was based.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Due to the ongoing campaign, there were no useable STEREO A COR2 frames for this measurement.

note: CME first seen to the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2020-10-03T09:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption beginning at approx. 2024-10-03T09:19Z centered at approx. S30W15 with Southern deflection as seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304. Field line movement is also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Full halo CME observed in SOHO LASCO, and full halo directed slightly more eastward in STEREO COR2A. The source is an X9.0 flare from AR 3842 observed in many wavelengths but mainly SDO AIA 131, starting at 2024-10-03T12:08Z and peaking at T12:18Z. Also observed as an EUV wave and dimming in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284, with surface brightening in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

SHOCK measurment triangulated between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The shock front is notably wide with a "layered" appearance in both SOHO and STEREO with some apparent concentric fronts, along with being a bit "wider" than it was "taller" with an overall oval-shape in SOHO. The best fit between both shock fronts is presented here, though it does not capture 100% of the shock front which may be even wider.

note: CME seen to the NW within the outflow of the halo CME: 2024-10-03T12:48Z associated with a filament eruption lifting off near N25W52 or so seen best in SDO AIA/GOES SUVI 304. The CME is not seen in STEREO A well, due to poor image quality and a data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using only SOHO C2/C3; the CME is not seen in early STEREO A frames, and then STEREO A data drops out, so this one-spacecraft measurement is approximate in that it has a fixed longitude; it is possible there is more westward deflection (higher longitude) and the latitude is lower.

note: Large loop CME seen to the NE in SOHO/STEREO A embedded in outflow of halo CME: 2024-10-03T12:48Z. Associated with a filament eruption/snapping of magnetic field lines and surge seen best in SDO AIA/GOES SUVI 304 and SDO AIA 171 near N30E60; the signature in SDO AIA 171 is particularly clear, as there is widely opening field line movement off the northeast limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using primarily SOHO C2/C3 and a few STEREO A frames; the measurement fit the observed source on the disk well.

note: CME with an auriform presentation in both the outline of its bulk and shock, seen to the west in SOHO. Associated with a strong eruption from AR 13844 near S10W50 following an M6.7-class flare; an EUV wave is seen in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO leading edge measurement using a fixed, known longitude based on the source eruption in EUV imagery; the CME is not visibly seen in STEREO A imagery easily, especially during an ongoing STEREO A campaign, but it may potentially be seen to the southeast in STEREO A imagery.
Measurement of shock front using only SOHO imagery, since the CME is not visible well in STEREO A.

note: Narrow, faint CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-03T22:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this CME is a minor filament eruption beginning at approximately 03/20:30Z centered at N35E50 as seen in SDO AIA 171 and 304, although the CME itself appears to be deflected towards the North. Minor field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193 as a result of this eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Narrow CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-03T23:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no clear source seen on the disk for this eruption, however faint field line movement can be seen along the NE limb in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 195 beginning at approximately 03/22:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is faintly visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and to the south in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be two eruptions in close proximity to each other in the SW quadrant of the Earth-facing disk. A dimming region possibly associated with a faint filament eruption is visible in SDO/AIA 193 starting around 2024-10-04T02:00Z in the SW near ARs 13842, 13839, and 13844 followed by moving/opening field lines visible in SDO/AIA 171 starting around 2024-10-04T03:00Z in the SW below ARs 13844, 13843, and 13836. The moving/opening field lines are largely visible heading to the west while the dimming appears to have some southern directionality. A third separate eruption from AR 13842 (an M4.0 flare) is likely associated with an overlapping CME feature. There is some uncertainty with this analysis due to the multiple eruptions in close proximity and timing to when the CME is first visible in coronagraph imagery. Both SOHO and STEREO A coronagraphs have data gaps during this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of faint leading edge in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. There is a high level of uncertainty with this analysis due to multiple nearly simultaneous eruptions leading up to the CME in imagery. The width of the CME is very uncertain.

note: A southern CME with a somewhat uncertain front seen with some uncertainty overlapping with the earlier 2024-10-04T04:13Z CME and discernible mostly in difference imagery (not clearly seen in white light images). It is likely associated with the M4.0 flare from Active Region 3842 and the associated narrow, south-directed ejecta seen in AIA/SUVI 304 starting at 2024-10-04T05:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. Parameters are uncertain because the CME front is not clear as it is overlapping with the preceding wider CME.

note: CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-04T06:24Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The likely source of this CME is a very minor eruption from AR 3838 (N1W52) beginning at approx. 04/05:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 193, although the CME is likely slightly deflected Northward. Minor field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Few STEREO A frames were usable for this measurement due to the faintness of the CME.

note: Faint loop CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-04T10:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The likely source of this CME is field line movement seen in the vicinity of S35W30 beginning at approximately 04/09:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-04T13:25Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an eruption from the vicinity of AR 3844 (S15W37) beginning at approximately 04/12:30Z, although the CME itself appears to exhibit Southern deflection. Field line opening can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 171 along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A wide CME directly north in STEREO A coronagraph and a bit towards NNE in SOHO. There is a wider shock and a narrower brighter bulk. The shock looks like an asymmetric halo with additional part seen to the west in COR2A. There was no source found on the Earth-facing disk so the CME is likely backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. It incorporates the most faint western part of the halo in STEREO A COR2.

Very approximate analysis based only on the fit with two coronagraphs (since no source has been found in the EUV imagery). Latitude could be lower or higher (at least from 30 deg to 50 deg) but ~40 degrees seems to produce the best fit.

note: A very diffuse front with many follow up emission. The source may be a broad field line movement over the NW limb beginning as early as 2024-10-04T23Z but the source is unclear.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate POS measurement. The front is so fuzzy that it is difficult to fit it with both coronagraphs.

note: A very faint front only seen in running difference imagery from SOHO (C2 and C3), but not discernible in the white light SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery (which is sparse and low quality because of the currently STEREO campaign). No definitive source has been found for this CME. This front is followed by multiple similar faint fronts.
A very faint and narrow outflow to the south and southwest.  The source has not been found - but there is a lot of activity in the SW quadrant which may be obscuring the source.

cmeAnalyses.note: An uncertain measurement based on fit with two coronagraph and not confirmed by the source location (source not found).

note: CME seen to the SW in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain, with no one distinct eruptive source and the entire southwest quadrant of SDO AIA 171 imagery observing broad field line movement from as early as 4Z this morning, likely due to the numerous active regions in the SW and SW limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to the uncertain source, and poor image quality in STEREO COR2A running difference imagery with an ongoing campaign that cannot resolve the diffuse CME front.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and in STEREO COR2A white light imagery. The source is a thin jet-like filament eruption from on or just beyond the SW limb, best observed erupting at 2024-10-05T11:52Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky using only SOHO LASCO C3, as the CME deflects in C2 and cannot be traced, and STEREO COR2A campaign data is very poor running difference quality and unfortunately not usable to triangulate this source which may lie just barely beyond the limb. However, this POS analysis is likely close to the true source, which is directed well out of the ecliptic.

note: A very faint front - one of multiple faint fronts today - that is mainly seen in difference imagery and has no clear source in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and not confirmed by source location (no source has been found).

note: Bright CME to the northwest. Its source is likely the inconspicuous  opening of field lines in the northwest behind the limb seen in AIA 193/171 after 2024-10-05T19:05Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs, not confirmed by the source location since the source is behind the limb. The longitude could be at least -10 to +10 degrees off.
Stereo data are very sparse and low quality because of the ongoing campaign so the SOHO based POS analysis is in order.

note: Faint, narrow CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-06T04:48Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME appears to get overtaken by CME: 2024-10-06T06:12Z. There is no clear source seen on the disk for this event, however some very minor field line opening can be seen in GOES SUVI 284 at approx. 06/04:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. CME had been over taken by the time it entered SOHO LASCO C3. CME exhibits strong Southern deflection.

note: Faint, fast CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-06T05:48Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is seen overlapping with CME: 2024-10-06T04:48Z and CME: 2024-10-06T06:12Z. There is no clear source seen on the disk as this CME is likely far sided, however minor field line movement can be seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-06T06:12Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no abundantly clear source seen on the disk, however some faint field line opening can be seen near the SW limb in SDO AIA 193 and 211 beginning at approx. -6/05:30Z. This CME is seen overtaking CME: 2024-10-06T04:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint, somewhat asymmetric, CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-06T16:12Z. No clear source has been found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: An extremely approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs, however the sole STEREO A image showing the front of this CME after the data gap is very poor quality, in addition to the source of this CME no having been found in EUV imagery.

note: A faint narrow outflow towards northwest. No clear source have been found for it, although there is a lot of activity in the western part of the disk today. The CME is not seen in STEREO imagery because of a large data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Since there is no STEREO A imagery available for this event because of a large data gap only POS analysis is definitive.

note: CME first seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-07T03:48Z. Also seen in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is like some activity from the vicinity of AR 3841. There is some minor brightening and movement along field lines best seen in SDO AIA 171 starting about 1.5 hours prior to the CME appearing in C2.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-07T04:36Z. The source of this CME is possibility related to some faint field line movement from beyond the SW limb best seen in SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-10-07T03:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Wide, bright CME seen to the southwest in SOHO C2/C3 seemingly composed of two or more overlapping loops with internal structure clearly visible and no cavity. Presence of very faint shock may possibly be seen due south in LASCO C2 running difference imagery and may begin to reveal itself to the north-northeast in late SOHO frames after 22:30Z, though disjoint from the main CME body. Associated with a sympathetic eruption resulting from the long duration X2.1/X1.0-class flares (AR3842) located farther behind the southwestern limb than where the X2.1 takes place (W60) as seen in SDO AIA 171 imagery; the CME appears to originate closer to the southwestern limb. Fast, widely opening field lines are also observed in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: STEREOCat one-spacecraft (SOHO) bulk measurement with plane of sky angle set to -2 degrees in order to fix longitude; SWPC_Cat measurements of the leading edge of the CME best fit longitudes near 45 degrees west given the CMEs rounded appearance and presence in the south, which were felt to be unrealistic given the source location of the eruption.

Shock measurement using one spacecraft (SOHO) C2 and C3 images which fits the widest extent of the south and southwestern portions of the CME leading edge as well as a north-northeastern portion that reveals itself in later SOHO frames after 22:30Z which is assumed to be part of the CME shock, though it is disjoint. This measurement is in support of solar energetic particle modeling activities, and as such, is not an approximation of the source location and should not be used for trajectory analysis.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames prior to a data gap starting at 2024-10-08T03:38Z. The source may be related to field line movement visible near the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery around 2024-10-08T00:40Z. Additionally, there are rising loops/possible post-eruptive arcades visible near the western limb around 01:00Z in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193 imagery which may also be related to this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is visible in STEREO A COR2 for a few frames prior to a data gap beginning at 2024-10-08T03:38Z. The source is likely related to an eruption near S19W72 starting around 2024-10-08T01:54Z seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is limited imagery for this event and various CME fronts/outflow features that make it difficult to track the leading edge in coronagraph imagery. Because of this the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is only visible in STEREO A COR2 after the leading edge is out of the field of view due to a data gap from 2024-10-08T03:38Z to 09:23Z. The source is a large filament eruption centered near S25W30 which begins to erupt, deflecting southward, around 2024-10-08T05:20Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery at the time of the eruption, and post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 06:30Z in SDO AIA131, 171, and 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. There is uncertainty in this measurement due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery and limited imagery in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The measured parameters may therefore vary slightly.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and a few frames of STEREO A COR2 prior to a data gap starting at 2024-10-08T13:23Z. The source is likely far-sided, and seen as faint opening of field lines visible beyond the eastern limb in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2024-10-08T11:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and an early frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT, as well as candidate source location beyond the limb. This measurement is approximate, and the longitude may vary by approximately +/- 10 degrees.

note: Relatively narrow CME first seen in the East initially by STEREO A COR2, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in later frames. This event gets quickly overtaken by the X1.8-flare-associated halo 2024-10-09T02:12Z CME. The source of this event is possibly a more minor flare sympathetic to the X flare happening at the same time in Active Region 3853 (N20E63) with post-eruptive arcades or more minor opening field lines and slight dimming seen in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284 originating from the vicinity of AR 3852 (S14E53). This more minor flare is not measurable since it coincides with the more intense flare.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate measurement based on the fit in two coronagraphs and confirmed by the possible location of the source (dimming). Only a few timestamps are available for this front in coronagraphs.

note: Bright, fast and complex-shaped full halo CME associated with the X1.8 class flare from the Active Region 13848 (N13W08). The CME has two lobes or fronts: the more western, slightly earlier one, and the more central on to the northeast. The flare is associated with the significant eruption marked by an EUV wave, a large area of deep dimming and by bright post-eruptive arcades. There also  seems to be a second eruption - the initially slowly developing eruption of a very large filament spanning from N20W15 to N15W55, to the northwest of the Active Region 3848, which starts prior to the X flare (~2024-10-08T22:19Z). This earlier eruption may be responsible for the more western lobe or front of this CME (which could possibly be a separate CME). The X-class flare could be potentially be responsible for the more central, northeastern lobe/front of this complex event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two-coronagraph analysis of the complex-shaped (two-lobed) brighter front we consider to be the bulk of this CME. This analysis is based on the location of the X flare as the source, which is confirmed by a good fit with two coronagraphs. This analysis encompasses both the more eastern lobe/front of this CME and the more western lobe, which are best seen in LASCO C2.
SHOCK measurement made using running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

Two-coronagraph analysis of the more central front/lobe of the complex halo CME seen in coronagraphs. This analysis is based on fitting in two coronagraphs of the more eastern lobe of this complex CME event, the source of which is the X-class flare.  Note that the more western lobe is considered in this analysis to be a separate, 2024-10-09T02:23Z, CME associated with a large filament erupting to the west of the Active Region 13848 prior to the X flare.

note: A clear, more western loop especially well seen in SOHO C2 (starting at 2024-10-09T02:12Z) and overlapping with a more central front associated with the Xclass flare. The start time was set to 02:23Z to distinguish it from the more central CME. The source of this more western front is likely the initially slowly developing eruption of a very large filament spanning from N20W15 to N15W55 to the northwest of Active Region 3848 which started prior to the X flare (~2024-10-08T22:19Z). This earlier eruption may be responsible for the more western lobe/front, while the flare could be responsible for the more central, northeastern front of this complex CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two-coronagraph analysis of the western loop-like front/lobe of the complex halo CME complex. Analysis is based on the source location (approximate center of the erupting filament) and confirmed by a decent fit in two coronagraphs. Encompasses only the western lobe/front of this complex (with the more western lobe deemed to be the X-flare associated separate CME).

note: CME visible to the W/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and a few frames of STEREO A COR2 after a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-10-09T13:53Z to 2024-10-09T18:53Z. This CME is associated with the X1.4 flare from AR 13842 (S10W85) close to the SW limb. There is a narrow stream of ejecta visible in GOES SUVI 304 sourced from AR 13842 but deflected to the north and off the limb. In GOES SUVI 284, wide and fast opening field lines and departure of plasma from the W limb is visible. Very limited SDO AIA imagery for this event due to a shutter maneuver.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using approximate longitude of source location observed in UV imagery along with the best fit in available frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. The leading edge of this CME was not captured by COR2A due to a data gap.

Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 frames. SOHO LASCO image quality heavily affected by the comet observations/campaign. The leading edge of this CME was already beyond the COR2A field of view after a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-10-09T13:53Z to 2024-10-09T18:53Z.

note: Likely a streamer blowout, this CME is seen to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. There is no discernable source in UV imagery, so this event is likely on the far side. This CME was affected by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-10-10T05:08Z to 2024-10-10T08:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using several frames of C3 and COR2A. This CME was affected by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 lasting from 2024-10-10T05:08Z to 2024-10-10T08:53Z. Image quality for this CME was also affected by the ongoing comet campaign [and calibrations?]

note: Halo CME first seen by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-10-01-T09:53Z, as well as in the East by SOHO LASCO C2/C3. There is no clear source seen for this event, however spacecraft triangulation (currently a 26 degree separation) reveals that this event likely originated from the far side, so a source eruption would be too far beyond the West limb to be visible.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Fast jet CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-10T18:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this event is clear opening field lines seen on or just beyond the NW limb (approx. N12W90) beginning at approx. 10/17:00Z in SDO AIA 193. This CME appears to exhibit a strong Northern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: STEREO A COR2 data is poor due to an ongoing campaign, and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery is poor due to the comet passage. POS measurement due to the source being near the limb and a range of fitting longitudes (approx. 80 to 115).

note: CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-11T12:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen on or just beyond the NW limb (footpoint at approx. S02W90 exhibiting Northern deflection) beginning at approx. 11/12:08Z as seen in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304. Opening field lines are also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Narrow CME first seen in the SW by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-10-11T13:09Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in later frames. The source of this event is likely an area of opening field lines seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 193 beginning at approx. 11/12:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is faintly visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 171 around 2024-10-11T15:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the uncertain/far-sided source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and is visible in STEREO A COR2 prior to a data gap lasting from 2024-10-11T17:48Z to 23:38Z. The source is likely an M2.1 flare and subsequent eruption from Active Region 13852 (S09E23) starting around 2024-10-11T16:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Additionally, an EUV wave/dimming is visible around the eruption site in SDO AIA 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and one frame of STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured parameters may vary slightly as the source is likely far-sided and there is no source location to assist in the measurement.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is likely far-sided and there is no precise source location for this event, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured longitude may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption and opening of field lines visible beyond the southwest limb starting around 2024-10-12T10:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and there is no precise source location, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Faint CME seen to the ESE in STEREO COR2A, and very faintly/diffusely to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Given the observed time of this CME no on-disk source was observed in SDO or GOES imagery, with the closest potential source being be a slow dimming from AR 3852/3854 (around S10E08) starting around 2024-10-12T16:54Z in SDO AIA 193. However triangulation between SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs, with lower confidence due to faintness in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, resulted in a source fit around S10E37.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between STEREO COR2A and SOHO LASCO C2/C3, notably difficult due to faintness and diffuse nature of the front in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 compared to the more visible front in STEREO COR2A. Far-sided longitudes did not fit at all between coronagraphs, so despite the lack of clear on-disk source, this CME appears front sided and this best fit is provided.

note: Slow CME that speeds up in later frames. Appears to be a streamer blowout with a very small streamer to the SW of it. There is no clear source for this CME and due to it's directionality directly south in both coronagraphs it may have a wide range of potential longitudes.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Using later frames to capture a hopefully more accurate speed as the CME speeds up in later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Large messy CME to the W/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME. There may be a wide shock feature associated with this CME that is faintly visible in white light and difference imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery of the bulk of the CME. The fainter potential shock portion to the SW is excluded from this analysis.

note: Faint CME to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This CME slightly overlaps the CME at 2024-10-13T01:36Z. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-13T17:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. There is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this event due to a data gap from 13/13:53Z to 13/22:53Z. There is no clear source seen for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Limited usable coronagraph frames and measuring with a vast range of Lat/Lon fits in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Bright loop CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-14T00:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an M3.4 class flare from AR 3848 (N17W78) peaking at 2024-10-14T00:17Z. This flare can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 131, along with opening field lines seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, GOES SUVI 284, and STEREO A EUVI 195. A region of dimming is also visible to the North of this flare in SDO AIA 193 and STEREO A EUVI 195, which is indicative of a more Northern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-14T09:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a very long filament eruption beginning at approx. 14/08:00Z centered at approx. S30W70 as seen in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, GOES SUVI 284 and STEREO A EUVI 195 along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 131, 193 and STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-14T10:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this CME is minor field line movement seen along the NW limb in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Event is very faint in COR2A

note: Streamer blowout CME to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The exact source is not clear, but may be associated with moving/opening field lines in the NE of SDO/AIA 171 and 193 starting around 2024-10-14T09:30Z. The front of this CME is very diffuse, but a later front that was more defined was used for the analysis of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of most defined leading edge. There is material ahead of the measured front that was not included in this CME measurement.

note: CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-14T14:36Z, although this event likely began sooner but was not visible due to the cadence of SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. The source of this CME is an M1.8 class flare from AR 3848 (N17W86) peaking at 14/13:37Z. This flare is seen clearly in SDO AIA 131 along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, GOES SUVI 284 and STEREO A EUVI 195. Post eruptive arcades are also visible in STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using source location and SOHO imagery. No usable STEREO A COR2 imagery for measurement.

note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. It overlaps in the field of view with CME: 2024-10-14T20:36Z. The source can be seen as brightening seen near AR 3848 just beyond the west limb. Field line movement is also seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location.

note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Overlaps in the field of view with CME: 2024-10-14T17:36Z. The source is likely on the west limb, and some possible post-eruption brightening visible at 2024-10-14T21:27Z in SDO/AIA 304 near AR 3848.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location.

note: Faint CME seen to the S in C2, C3 and to the SW in COR2A. There is no discernable source in UV imagery found. This CME is likely far-sided, based on the lack of source on the Earth-facing disk and when comparing the position of the CME in SOHO LASCO to STEREO A COR2.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME visible in the SE of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely the liftoff of filamentary material from a long filament stretching along the S/SE limb, seen in SDO AIA 304 around 2024-10-15T01:24Z. There appears to be recurring partial eruptions from this filament, so there may be additional fronts seen at later times from this same source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. Limited imagery was available for this measurement due to data gaps in real-time in SOHO and STEREO A coronagraph imagery.

note: Narrow CME visible to the NW in STEREO A COR2. Not visible in real-time in SOHO LASCO imagery due to a data gap from approximately 2024-10-15T08:30Z-22:15Z. The potential source is some faint field line movement best seen beyond the NW limb in STEREO A EUV 195 at 2024-10-15T10:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first visible in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-10-15T22:06Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The start time of this CME is delayed due to data gaps in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 (15/07:48Z to 15/21:26Z) and STEREO A COR2 (15/13:23Z to 15/23:09Z). The source is associated with the M1.7 flare peaking at 2024-10-15T18:18Z from AR 3848 on the NW limb, around N19W90. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-10-15T18:13Z. The eruption is not visible in STEREO A EUVI 195 due to a data gap in real-time from 2024-10-15T13:25Z-22:55Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3. There was no SOHO LASCO C2 or STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this measurement, as the leading edge had already left the field of view when imagery returned from the data gaps.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-15T23:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of thus CME is a small eruption seen on NW Limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-10-15T21:37Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible near or slightly beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 193 imagery starting around 2024-10-16T00:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible near or slightly beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 193 imagery starting around 2024-10-16T03:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is faintly visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the northwest limb in SDO AIA 193 imagery starting around 2024-10-16T07:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made in SOHO LASCO C2 using a longitude of 90 degrees as this event was too faint to measure in STEREO A COR2 imagery and there was no source longitude due to the far-sided source.

note: This CME is visible as a far-sided halo, primarily directed towards the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and northwest in STEREO A COR2. The source is likely far-sided as an opening of field lines is visible beyond the northeast limb starting around 2024-10-16T22:10Z in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery. The source may originate from former Active Region 13841, which was located around longitude -163 at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk feature based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Wide loop to the southwest with many consecutive fronts which overlaps with the far-sided halo 2024-10-16T23:12Z CME. The source is likely a faint slow opening field lines seen far beyond the SW limb in GOES SUVI 284 and in EUVI A 195, starting as early as 2024-10-16T22:50Z and lasting until about 2024-10-17T04:50Z. There is a faint opening of field lines and there appears to be a rising loop departing as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on a fit of the front in two coronagraphs, however there are multiple consecutive fronts seen in coronagraph. The source (very faint opening of field lines behind the limb in the southwest) indicates a source far behind the limb. There is a range of longitudes that gives a good fit with two coronagraphs.

note: A moderately narrow CME to the northeast preceding the wider CME: 2024-10-17T08:36Z. Its source could be a part of the erupting filament seen in SDO AIA imagery spanning from N30E10 to N40E50. The movement and gradual liftoff of the filamentary material can be seen in SDO AIA 304/171/193 and GOES SUVI 304/284 starting ~2024-10-17T06:00Z-07:30Z. This eruption is possibly the source of both CME:2024-10-17T07:36Z and CME:2024-10-17T08:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: A loop like CME to the northeast following a narrower 2024-10-17T07:36Z CME. The source could be the filament eruption seen in SDO AIA imagery spanning from about N30E10 to N40E50. Movement and liftoff of the filamentary material can be seen in SDO AIA 304/171/193 and GOES SUVI 304/284 lasting from about 2024-10-17T06:00Z-07:30Z, so this may be the source of both CME:2024-10-17T07:36Z and CME:2024-10-17T08:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit in two coronagraph and confirmed by the location of the source (the larger, central, part of the filament eruption).

note: Jet-like, narrow CME seen out to a few solar radii first at 2024-10-17T23:12Z to the east after SOHO and STEREO A data refilled but the start time is earlier than this; possibly associated with a minor eruption near or just beyond the eastern limb as seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284 with northward deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement to a few more solar radii.
Measurement of the leading edge out to a few solar radii using STEREO A and SOHO imagery to triangulate the leading edge.

note: Faint CME with a fuzzy front, preceded and followed by outflows and following the slow/faint 2024-10-18T06:12Z CME. The start time of this event can be a bit earlier. The source is possibly a very minor faint eruption with ejecta/movement of field lines seen on/behind the NW limb in AIA 193/171 starting at 2024-10-18T11:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate measurement based on the fit with two coronagraphs. The source is likely behind the limb and the fit gives a range of possible longitudes. Additionally, the front is very fuzzy.

note: Faint diffuse CME to the W/SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3 (barely visible), and possibly STEREO A COR2 imagery (unclear if feature seen to the west in STA is outflow or this CME). This CME is likely associated with the M6.5 flare from AR13854 (S03W82) peaking at 2024-10-19T06:56Z best seen in SDO/AIA 131. A filament to the north of the AR begins to erupt around 2024-10-19T06:24Z as seen in SDO/AIA 304 and appears to lift off with the flare and may be associated with this CME as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the source location of the M6.5 flare. The CME features are not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Due to single spacecraft mode, there is a larger amount of uncertainty with this measurement.

note: This CME is visible to the E/NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be an eruption from AR 3863 starting around 2024-10-19T09:00Z in SDO/AIA 304/171/211/94. Moving/opening field lines are visible in the SE of SDO/AIA 171, however it is not clear if these moving/opening field lines are associated with this eruption or another eruption that may be associated with the CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-10-19T09:48Z to the SE.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of features in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Narrow CME to the south. A potential source could be the opening of field lines to the S/SE in SDO/AIA 171 around 2024-10-19T09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs. Only backsided longitude and high southern latitude produce a fit.

note: Narrow faint CME with a dimpled front. The likely source is a minor movement of field line behind the northwest limb at latitude ~20 seen starting around 2024-10-19T17:40Z in AIA 193/171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs. The source is behind the limb and the front is faint and diffuse. Not simulated because there are no missions in the CME's path.

note: Minor faint CME to the southeast, becoming wider with time, consisting of a faint shock on its sides. The source for this eruption appears to be movement/opening of field lines just behind the SE limb (lat ~-20) seen around 2024-10-19T22:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement to approximate longitude; longitude parameter has uncertainty of about +/- 15 degrees.

note: Faint jet-like CME seen to the east-northeast predominantly in SOHO C2 imagery, but also in C3 imagery and STEREO A COR2; it appears with much more contrast in running difference imagery as opposed to white light imagery. Likely associated with far-sided eruptive activity as evidenced by triangulation, although a possible very low confidence source could be the post eruptive arcades on the earth facing disk around N27E70.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement (SOHO, STEREO A) to triangulate the longitude; the leading edge was found to be consistent with a far-sided eruption rather than the source on the Earth-facing disk.

note: Bright loop CME seen to the southeast in SOHO and STEREO A imagery, associated with a significant field line movement behind the southeastern limb as seen best in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement of the brightest portion associated with the CME using SOHO C2, C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Jet CME seen to the northeast in SOHO C2 imagery shortly after the wide and bright 2024-20-21T09:24Z CME seen to the southeast, possibly overlapping. No major source eruptions were found for this CME, but the CME may be associated with a magnetic field line breaking off the eastern limb best seen in SDO AIA 193 observed near 2024-10-21T11:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using triangulation to determine longitude; uncertainty in longitude is up to +/- 20 or 25 degrees.

note: New CME embedded in the outflow in the CME: 2024-10-21T09:24Z seen to the southeast associated with a secondary, sympathetic eruption taking place off the southeast limb following the 2024-10-21T08:00Z opening field lines characterized by new opening field lines seen best in GOES SUVI 284 off the southeast limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement taking into account the brightest portion of the CME using only SOHO and assuming the source is similar in longitude to the previous eruption to which it is sympathetic.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The start time was difficult to determine as this event overlaps with preceding CME: 2024-10-21T13:48Z and CME: 2024-10-21T09:24Z. The source is likely far-sided and related to an opening of field lines and eruption visible beyond the southeast limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193 and 304 imagery starting around 2024-10-21T14:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Because the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Faint CME visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The CME is visible after a data gap in C2. The source is not clear but may possibly be associated with an eruption near N07E00 starting around 2024-10-22T04:44Z. This eruption is best seen in SDO/AIA 131, 304, and 193. There is possibly deflection to the north due to a coronal hole due south of the source eruption location.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of CME in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Source is one of several instances of narrowly opening field lines and ejecta from either on or just beyond the E limb at latitude N00, but with northern deflection. Instances start as early as 2024-10-22T03:41Z (very diffuse outflow associated with that instance). There is a clearer instance of ejecta seen at 2024-10-22T07:30Z, which may possibly be the source for this CME, though the timing is rather early. It's also possible the source for this particular front is sourced from even further beyond the limb than we can see in UV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement triangulated betweeen SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery.

note: Fan-shaped CME seen to the SE in all coronagraphs. The source appears to lie on or just beyond the SE limb, observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211 as rapidly moving field lines starting around 2024-10-22T17:01Z, and further evidenced on the far-side around E95 by triangulation between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement using SDO observations and between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO COR2A coronagraphs, using some frames of SOHO LASCO C3 with notable trouble following the front as the leading edge travels directly into the LASCO C3 pylon.

note: CME seen to the W/SW in all coronagraphs, but not until later frames of STEREO COR2A due to a data gap spanning 2024-10-22T13:38Z-T19:38Z. This CME has a wide fan-shaped front extending further to the southward direction in coronagraph imagery, with the brightest bulk and nose more in the ecliptic. The main source is a brightening between ARs 3860/3859 centered around S05W61, observed in SDO AIA 131 alongside field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193 and some surface brightening in SDO AIA 304, beginning around 2024-10-22T17:04Z. A small filament just to the NE, centered around N03W48, erupts simultaneously in SDO AIA 304 with this (starting slowly around 2024-10-22T16:41Z) and may contribute to the front despite the offset in location.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, focusing on the brighter distinct nose more in the ecliptic over the more diffuse, dimmer material traveling towards the south in the coronagraphs, which proved difficult to capture in one measurement between the craft and may be outflow from this broad eruption as seen in SDO AIA imagery.

note: Faint flux rope CME, which is also a streamer blowout, seen to the south in STEREO A COR2 and south/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. There are initially two overlapping fronts seen in early C2 and early COR2A coronagraph imagery: a faint flux rope loop and a more narrow hollow loop which at first appears to travel faster, but by the time both fronts reach the edge of the C2 FOV, both fronts appear to travel as one. No clear source is seen on disk in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 coronagraph imagery. Multiple frames of C3 and COR2A difference imagery were available to make the measurement.

note: This CME is visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The CME is blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery. The source of this CME appears to be filament ejecta seen near S17E80 in SDO/AIA 304 starting around 2024-10-23T10:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the best fit using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. SOHO LASCO C3 was not usable due to being behind the control arm in C3's view.

note: CME seen to the north-northeast in SOHO LASCO and northeast in STEREO A COR2 that appears to be associated with a minor eruption with northward deflection occurring near N19E15 south of Active Region 3864 as seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284. Flickering magnetic field lines are observed off the northeast limb nearly simultaneously after the on-disk signature seen in SDO AIA 171 which may suggest, with low confidence, a possible simultaneous far-side component. Triangulation of the CME using SOHO/STEREO A coronagraphs suggested with higher confidence that the CME was predominantly associated with the on-disk signatures.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement with additional SOHO C2 and C3 frames that were not previously available due to a data gap.

Two spacecraft leading edge measurement using SOHO/STEREO A which suggested there was heavy northward deflection of this eruption, as it was found that the leading edge did not easily fit both coronagraphs for latitudes less than about 35 degrees for all longitudes. The measurement process also more heavily favored the on-disk signatures (longitude -10 to -15) rather than the far-sided longitudes.

note: Faint and fast loop seen to the southeast as defined by its brighter leading edge similar in appearance to the 2024-10-23T11:12Z CME; no definitive source for this CME was found, but could be associated with moving field lines off the southeast limb as seen best in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement of the CME using SOHO and STEREO A coronagraphs. Uncertainty in longitude of up to 20 degrees.

note: Narrow, faint CME observed to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 first during a SOHO data gap at which point SOHO later backfilled. Likely associated with diverging field lines seen off the southeast limb beginning around 14:45Z but becoming more apparent by 16:00Z best in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO/STEREO A to triangulate a potential source longitude; possible uncertainty in longitude up to 15 degrees.

note: Partial halo CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an X3.3 flare starting at 2024-10-24T03:30Z from AR 3869 (approx. S17E68). Brightening and post eruptive arcades are observed in SDO AIA 131/171/193/335, EUV wave seen in SDO AIA 193, and opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 171/193. The eruption is also seen from STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

SHOCK MEASUREMENT triangulated between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A, following the outermost leading edge of the wider, fainter shock traveling ahead of the bulk. This notably does not capture the entire shock-like feature observed in both SOHO and STEREO coronagraphs in the SWPC_CAT measurement tool. This fit follows the leading edge of the shock best, cutting short from the widest portions of the partial halo.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source may be activity from AR 3869, as opening field lines can be seen in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-10-24T09:00Z. The CME is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-24T11:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. There is no clear source seen for this event, leading to the conclusion that the source is likely beyond the Eastern limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: CME is not measurable in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. POS due to a very wide range of longitude fits (approx. -125 to -45).

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-24T11:36Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is some very minor field line movement seen along the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. Event was blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-24T12:12Z as well as by C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this eruption is some minor field line movement seen along the SE limb in SDO AIA 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. C3 was not available for measurement due to event being blocked by the pylon.

note: CME first seen in the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 running difference imagery beginning at 2024-10-24T13:48Z. In real-time, there was no SOHO LASCO C2/C3 white light imagery available due to a data outage beginning at 2024-10-24T12:48Z that resolved and backfilled on 2024-10-25. There is also no STEREO A COR2 imagery available due to a data gap from 13:23Z to 23:38Z. The source of this CME is a small area of field line movement along the SE limb (approx. S40E90) as seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location. There was no available STEREO A COR2 imagery available for measurement and this event was also blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Narrow jet CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 running difference imagery beginning at 2024-10-24T14:36Z. In real-time, there was no SOHO LASCO C2/C3 white light imagery available due to a data outage beginning at 2024-10-24T12:48Z that resolved and backfilled on 2024-10-25. There is also no STEREO A COR2 imagery available due to a data gap from 13:23Z to 23:38Z. The source of this event is a small eruption along the East limb (approx. S02E85) as seen in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location. There is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for measurement due to data gap.

note: Narrow jet CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 running difference imagery beginning at 2024-10-24T16:12Z. In real-time, there was no SOHO LASCO C2/C3 white light imagery available due to a data outage beginning at 2024-10-24T12:48Z that resolved and backfilled on 2024-10-25. There is also no STEREO A COR2 imagery available due to a data gap from 13:23Z to 23:38Z. The source of this CME is some faint field line movement seen beyond the East limb in SDO AIA 171. This source seems to be obscured by the brightening of an active region which has just rotated onto the disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: CME fits with a range of longitudes (approx. -115 to -75).

note: Narrow jet CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 running difference imagery beginning at 2024-10-24T18:48Z. In real-time, there was no SOHO LASCO C2/C3 white light imagery available due to a data outage beginning at 2024-10-24T12:48Z that resolved and backfilled on 2024-10-25. There is also no STEREO A COR2 imagery available due to a data gap from 13:23Z to 23:38Z. The source of this event is a narrow eruption of material seen along the East limb (approx. S11E85) exhibiting Northern deflection in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location. There is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this measurement due to a data gap.

note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source may be activity from a cluster of ARs in the southeast, including potential eruption activity from AR 3872, as opening field lines are seen around 2024-10-25T02:00Z near the SE limb in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT, as well as potential source location.

note: CME visible to the NE in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source is an M1.1 flare peaking at 2024-10-25T07:33Z from AR 3873 (approx. S10E72) as seen in SDO AIA 131. The eruption is best seen in GOES SUVI 304. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195/304. In real-time, SOHO data was unavailable starting around 2024-10-24T12:48Z, but later backfilled.

cmeAnalyses.note: While SOHO white light imagery is not available for this event, running difference imagery is available for SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source can be seen as an ejecta of material near AR 3873, best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-10-25T08:37Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and faintly visible in STEREO A COR2. The potential source can be seen around N10 near the limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-10-25T12:17Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of clear source location near the west limb and no usable STEREO A COR2 difference imagery at this time.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption from AR 3873, near S10E70. An eruption can be seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-10-25T14:49Z from AR 3873, and there is another eruption preceding it starting at 2024-10-25T12:41Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only due to limited image availability in STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and (slightly brighter in) STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME and only a few frames available in STEREO A COR2 imagery before the nightly data gap in real-time imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit in SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Mostly SOHO LASCO C2 frames used due to faintness of event in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery and limited STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint jet-like CME to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. No STEREO A COR2 imagery available during this CME due to nightly data gap in real-time imagery. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. No STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this event.

note: Faint jet-like CME to the S in SOHO LASCO C2, C3. Data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery. Source appears to be small eruption from AR3865 (S22E00) which is heavily deflected south with some southeast directionality.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 using potential source location. No STEREO A COR2 imagery available due to data gap.

note: This CME is visible as a partial halo directed towards the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption which is associated with an M9.5 flare from Active Region 13873 (S14E56) and X1.8 flare from Active Region 13873 (S16E60) starting around 2024-10-26T06:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A wide opening of field lines is visible over the southeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193, with post eruptive arcades visible in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 starting around 07:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk portion based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event is wide and difficult to fit between coronagraphs, with measured longitudes ranging from -41 to -66.

SHOCK MEASUREMENT based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery tracking the wider, faint front which precedes the bulk of this CME. This measurement does not capture the entire shock feature observed in both coronagraphs, and instead follows the leading edge of the shock best, missing the widest portions of the partial halo.

note: Loop CME seen to the south-southeast in the outflow of the halo CME 2024-10-26T06:48Z. May be associated with a secondary eruption or outflow near S35E60.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using two spacecraft showing southward deflection of the eruption.

note: Narrow yet bright CME seen best in SOHO C2 nearly due west along the outflow of several more minor CMEs to the southwest. Likely associated with eruptive activity just behind the western limb as evidenced by opening field lines seen in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-10-26T07:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation accomplished using two spacecraft leading edge measurement.

note: Faint CME/outflow in the wake of the earlier significant 2024-10-26T06:48Z CME. Its source is not clear but there is some movement in the filament eruption in the SE preceding this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Jet CME seen to the south-southeast in STEREO A COR2. Unclear source. May potentially be associated with eruptive activity from the southeast, including the recently eruptive Active Region 3872 with strong southward deflection. No SOHO imagery is available to corroborate a potential longitude due to comet observing.

cmeAnalyses.note: STEREO A plane of sky measurement (-62.7 degrees longitude).

note: This CME is visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. SOHO LASCO C2 imagery is not available for this event due to an on-going comet campaign. The source is best seen in SDO/AIA 171 as fast moving/opening field lines far behind the NE limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Limited STEREO A frames available for this event.

note: Bright lightbulb CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-28T08:48Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is currently not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to a data gap that began at 2024-10-28T02:30Z. The source of this event is a large filament eruption seen along the NE limb (centered at approx. N20E100) in SDO AIA , GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304. Opening field lines are also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Bright CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-28T14:00Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is observed in SOHO LASCO C3 white light imagery, but running difference image quality at this time does not capture the front. The source of this event is a far sided eruption seen along the SW limb. Wide opening field lines can be seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, GOES SUVI 284, and STEREO A EUVI 195. Post eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 211 and STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/STEREO COR2A, and the observed source just beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA imagery. SOHO LASCO is currently in a comet observation campaign affecting imagery, notably LASCO C3 running difference which does not observe the front at all while it can be seen in C3 white light. Enough C2 and COR2A imagery is available and usable for a confident fit, nonetheless.

note: CME visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3. The imagery it is not available in SOHO LASCO C2 due to an ongoing campaign. The source is likely on the far side.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a campaign. There are two potential on-disk sources for this CME, including dimming seen around S25E10 in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-10-29T01:47Z and a region of dimming centered around N05W00 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-10-29T00:37Z. The eruptions are also visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation based on the SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 white light imagery in StereoCAT.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to an ongoing campaign. The potential source is an eruption best seen in SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-10-29T05:57Z, not clearly seen from STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: StereoCAT measurement based on triangulation between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 white light imagery.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a campaign There are two potential on-disk sources for this CME, including dimming seen around S25E10 in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-10-29T01:47Z and a region of dimming centered around N05W00 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 2024-10-29T00:37Z. The eruptions are also visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on triangulation between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 white light imagery in StereoCAT.

note: This event is visible for one frame in STEREO A COR2 imagery to the southwest, prior to a data gap from 2024-10-29T13:23Z to 23:23Z. In SOHO LASCO C3 this event is visible as a partial halo directed towards the southwest, but the CME is only observable for a few frames before it exits the field of view. The source is a large filament eruption spanning about S37W25 to S15W90, likely extending beyond the western limb, which begins to erupt around 2024-10-29T12:40Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. Dimming is visible around the eruption site in SDO AIA 193 around 14:15Z, and post eruptive arcades begin to form around 17:15Z in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK MEASUREMENT based on the approximate source location. This measurement relies on only a few frames of SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, for which the CME is near the end of the SOHO LASCO C3 field of view. Multiple measurements resulted in longitudes spanning 41 to 54 degrees and speeds ranging from 800 to 1054 km/s. This measurement is speculative due to the limited image availability at the time of this event.

SHOCK measurement based on the approximate source location tracking the faint, wider feature surrounding the bulk portion of this CME. This measurement is preliminary due to limited coronagraph imagery and the measured parameters may vary.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery prior to a data gap starting at 2024-10-29T20:42Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: UPDATE: This CME has an updated start time of 2024-10-29T21:48Z as seen in backfilled SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery after a data gap lasting from 2024-10-29T13:23Z to 23:23Z. At the time of this event there was a data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery from 20:42Z to 23:54Z, which has since backfilled. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south in STEREO A COR2 and in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery after a data gap lasting from 20:42Z to 23:54Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T02:00Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely beyond the SW limb as there is no definitive source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T04:12Z. Also seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely an area of broad and slow moving field lines on the SSW limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting as early as 2024-10-30T02:30Z, but with a more defined rising loop seen at 2024-10-30T03:25Z. There is also a localized area of dimming best seen in SDO AIA 193 in the SW quadrant of the Earth-facing disk starting about 2024-10-30T03:28Z. It is difficult to distinguish the sources of CME: 2024-10-30T04:12Z and the slower moving CME: 2024-10-30T05:00Z that is slightly farther to the S.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T05:00Z. Also seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely an area of broad and slow moving field lines on the SSW limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting as early as 2024-10-30T02:30Z, but with a more defined rising loop seen at 2024-10-30T03:25Z. There is also a localized area of dimming best seen in SDO AIA 193 in the SW quadrant of the Earth-facing disk starting about 2024-10-30T03:28Z. It is difficult to distinguish the sources of CME: 2024-10-30T05:00Z and the faster moving CME: 2024-10-30T04:12Z that is slightly farther to the SSW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T05:12Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely beyond the SW limb as there is no definitive source on the Earth-facing disk. This CME can be seen in white light imagery from SOHO LASCO C3 but is difficult to distinguish in running difference imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T07:48Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is likely beyond the SW limb as there is no definitive source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T09:24Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely beyond the SW limb as there is no definitive source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-10-30T11:48Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely beyond the SW limb as there is no definitive source on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a data gap lasting from 2024-10-30T14:24Z to 20:12Z. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2024-10-30T15:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 117 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the west in STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a data gap lasting from 2024-10-30T14:24Z to 20:12Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no related source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 117 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-10-30T18:38Z to 23:23Z. The source is likely related to a faint dimming region centered near S05E55 which is visible starting around 2024-10-30T19:40Z in SDO AIA 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2, the measured parameters could not be confirmed using triangulation and may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-10-30T18:38Z to 23:23Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no related source signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: Extremely faint loop seen to the West in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2. The leading edge becomes diffuse in C3. The source is some faint field line movement seen beyond the W limb in STEREO A EUVI 195 imagery at 2024-10-31T01:05Z. (The W limb in STEREO A currently equates to W117 from Earth's i.e. SDO's point of view.) Data gap in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 from 2024-10-31T04:00Z to 2024-10-31T09:24Z slightly limited imagery for this faint event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between C2 and COR2A coronagraphs. Leading edge becomes diffuse before reaching C3 field of view.

note: Faint CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a small eruption with brightening and ejecta seen in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery at 2024-10-31T02:35Z. Located at approximately S15W75 from the point of view of STEREO A, approximately S15W102 from the view of SDO.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as the source location.

note: Faint CME visible to the west in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source is unclear in available EUV imagery, and it may be backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. The CME was not measurable in SOHO C2/C3 difference imagery.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is possibly associated with a small filament eruption lifting off around 2024-10-31T07:14Z. The filament stretches from S20-S40 and E50-E70 (centered at S30E60).
