However, the best fit between SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery suggests the source may be further beyond the east limb of the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Bright loop CME seen to the N/NW in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source is a farsided filament eruption seen emerging from beyond the NW limb in SDO AIA 304 starting at 2024-10-31T08:54Z. In STEREO EUVI 304 imagery, the small filament eruption is seen spanning from roughly N40-N50 and longitudes on and just beyond the NW limb of the STEREO A facing disk (roughly W117).

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge using best fit between coronagraphs and location of source observed in UV imagery. Data gap in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 from 2024-10-31T11:18Z to 2024-10-31T2024-10-31T13:30Z, but this did not severely inhibit this measurement since the leading edge remains in the field of view for several other frames.

note: Faint, near partial halo CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-31T13:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is brightening and a subsequent eruption from Active Region 3877 (S16E02) beginning at approx. 31/12:51Z. The brightening is visible in SDO AIA 94 and 131, along with the eruptive material visible in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304, and wide but faint field line movement seen South of the Active Region in SDO AIA 193. This flare brightened in tandem with AR 3875, however AR 3875 was responsible for the majority of the brightening and is there for the associated Active Region for the event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-10-31T14:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a large, slow filament eruption along the Southern limb as seen in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304. This filament began to erupt at approximately 31/05:00Z, but appeared to hover just above the limb before fully erupting into the corona beginning at approximately 31/12:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint, narrow CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Not clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gap from 2024-10-31T22:36Z to 2024-11-01T03:24Z and the CME's faintness. May be associated with a X2.0 flare peaking at 2024-10-31T21:20Z from AR 3878 (N16E28). The eruption is visible in all SDO AIA wavelengths, with brightening best seen in SDO AIA 131, dimming, opening field lines, and post-eruptive arcades best seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only one frame of this CME was visible in SOHO LASCO C2 and it was not measurable in SOHO LASCO C3. STEREO A COR2 imagery was primarily used for this measurement.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery, and is not observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a data gap lasting from 2024-11-01T09:06Z to 22:06Z. The source may be related to an eruption north of Active Region 13875, centered near N35W40, which begins to erupt around 2024-11-01T09:01Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A dimming region is visible moving north of the eruption in SDO AIA 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location using STEREO A COR2 imagery only.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C3 following a data gap from 2024-11-01T09:06Z to 22:06Z. Due to this data gap, the start time is likely earlier than what was observed in available imagery. This CME is also visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery, following a data gap lasting from 2024-11-01T14:53Z to 23:38Z. The source is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint, narrow CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. There are potential source candidate eruptions seen on the disk in available EUV imagery, including a faint dimming seen in GOES SUVI 195/284 and STEREO A EUV 195 around S40W10 starting at 2024-11-02T05:00Z. Dimming and moving field lines can also be seen south of AR 3869 (approx. S20W50) starting at 2024-11-02T02:52Z. The eruption is not seen in SDO AIA imagery due to a data gap from approximately 2024-11-01T22:00Z to 2024-11-02T06:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The CME is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 white light imagery. The CME it not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 after a data gap from 2024-11-02T10:24Z-13:25Z. There is also a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery from 2024-11-02T08:23Z-10:23Z. The source may be field line movement seen on the limb in STEREO A EUV 195 and GOES  SUVI 195 starting at 2024-11-02T05:35Z. A data gap was present in SDO AIA imagery from approx. 2024-11-01T22:00Z to 2024-11-02T06:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between one frame of available STEREO A COR2 imagery and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT. SOHO LASCO C2 imagery was used for the majority of this measurement due to limited imagery availability.

note: Narrow jet CME first seen in the east by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-03T13:25Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. A possible source for this event is a minor eruption seen along the Eastern limb (approx. S12E85) in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304 beginning at approximately 2024-11-03T12:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-03T15:27Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an eruption and M1.1 flare from AR 3883 (S10E53) peaking at 03/15:18Z. Brightening and post eruptive arcades can be seen in SDO AIA 131, along with dimming and field line opening seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption from Active Region 13877 (S17W44) starting at 2024-11-03T23:45Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Partial halo CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is visible in SOHO LASCO C3 after a data gap from 2024-11-04T02:18Z to 2024-11-04T05:43Z. The CME is associated with an M3.8 flare from AR 3883 (approximately S04E42) peaking at 2024-11-04T01:40Z. The eruption can be seen in all wavelengths of SDO AIA imagery, with brightening best seen in SDO AIA 131, dimming and EUV wave best seen in SDO AIA 193, and opening field lines best seen in SDO AIA 171. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk of the CME based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 after a data gap starting at 2024-11-04T14:53Z. The potential source is a C6.6 flare peaking at 2024-11-04T11:55Z from AR 3885 (approximately S08W55) best seen in SDO AIA 131. Moving field lines and brightening can be seen in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and limited STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME seen to the E in all coronagraphs, with minimal frames in STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. This CME front is comprised of a slower northern piece and a faster southern piece which still relatively travel together, causing a distortion in the front as it travels from earliest frames -> later frames. The source is the double peaked M3.7 and M5.5 flare from AR 3883 (S07E38), which began at 2024-11-04T15:26Z in SDO AIA 131 with additional field line movement and very slight dimming observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement using STEREO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, with notable difficulty using COR2A running difference imagery with only two available frames over the duration of this CME due to a data gap. The on-disk source flares observed in SDO AIA 131 also assisted in triangulating this event to this source, ruling out far-sided fits.

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-05T00:09Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a region of dimming seen centered at approximately N05E35 beginning around 05/23:19Z as seen in SDO AIA 193 and 211. Field line opening is also visible in GOES SUVI 195 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-05T07:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an M2.6 flare from the East limb (S07E90) peaking at 05/06:54Z as seen in SDO AIA 131. Field line opening is visible in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, and GOES SUVI 284, along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94 and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery and in SOHO LASCO C3 following a data gap lasting from 2024-11-05T10:42Z to 13:30Z. The source may be related to rising loops visible near the eastern limb starting around 2024-11-05T11:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, and 193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.

note: Very faint loop CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-05T13:25Z, as well as in a few grainy frames of STEREO A COR2 in later imagery. There is no clear source seen for this CME, and a lack of triangulating coronagraph imagery makes determining a source location for this event difficult.

cmeAnalyses.note: CME fits a range of longitudes (approx. 65 to 110 degrees). The lack of usable STEREO A COR2 imagery makes determining precise longitude difficult.

note: Wide CME visible to the west in STEREO A COR2 and after a data gap in SOHO LASCO C3 from 2024-11-05T14:30Z-23:54Z. The source is an M4.1 flare peaking at 2024-11-05T15:26Z (approx. S15W90) on or just beyond the west limb as seen in available EUV imagery. Opening field lines and EUV wave are also visible in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: This measurement is more approximate than usual due to a large data gap in SOHO LASCO C3, and is based on limited available STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. Not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a data gap from 2024-11-05T14:30Z-23:54Z. The source is unclear, and the CME may be farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and faintly visible in STEREO A COR2. The potential source is likely on the far side, with opening field lines seen beyond the NE limb starting at 2024-11-06T05:18Z in SDO AIA 171/193. The field line movement is not clearly seen from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME seen to the northeast, primarily in STEREO A COR2 but also in SOHO. A potential source is opening field lines beyond NE limb starting 2024-11-06T08:27Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using STEREO A and SOHO C2 occurring after a data backfill.

note: Narrow CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 after a data gap and in STEREO A COR2. The likely source of this CME is a minor eruption/field line movement seen beginning at approx. 06/09:38Z near AR 3886 (S07E46) in SDO AIA 94, 193, and 211

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated 3D measurement with backfilled SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery
Plane of sky measurement using limited available STEREO A COR2 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-06T16:48Z. CME also seen to E in SOHO LASCO C3 but is not discernible in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an M1.6 flare from an unnamed active region on E limb (S10E90) that peaked at 2024-11-06T15:57Z. There have been numerous flares from this location; however, based on timing, this M1.6 flare is the most likely source candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first visible to the NW in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2024-11-06T20:23Z after a data gap. The CME is about half way through the FOV of STEREO A COR2 in the first available image. CME is also visible to the NW in LASCO C2/C3; however, after the resumption of data for the SOHO downlink period starting at 2024-11-06T20:55Z, the leading edge of the CME has already passed out of the FOV of C2. There are a couple of possibilities for the source of this CME; however, the source most likely far-sided based on measurements. There is some faint field line movement best seen in GOES SUVI 284 from well beyond the NW limb a couple hours prior to the CME first becoming visible in STEREO A COR2. The measurement of the CME indicates that former AR 3875, which rotated off the Earth-facing disk on 2024-11-04, could be a good source candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-06T23:36Z. CME also visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an M1.1 flare from an unnamed active region on or just beyond the E limb that peaked at 2024-11-06T23:16Z. The flare and some associated ejecta off the E limb can be seen in SDO AIA 304 starting at ~2024-11-06T23:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery and SOHO LASCO C2/C3 following a data gap lasting from 2024-11-07T02:12Z to 07:36Z. The source is a filament eruption visible near the southwest limb (~S30W70) starting around 2024-11-07T05:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery, and post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 2024-11-07T07:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.

SHOCK measurement following the faint feature surrounding the bright bulk portion. The outermost, widest feature of the shock is not included in this measurement. Measured parameters based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southwest limb starting around 2024-11-07T08:00Z in SDO AIA 171 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-11-07T10:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery starting around 2024-11-07T14:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided/uncertain source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event.

note: Faint, outflow-like CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-08T01:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is faint field line opening seen in the SW by SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 08/00:36Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint, outflow-like CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-08T02:48Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no clear source visible on the disk for this event, however some faint field line movement/opening seen in the SW by SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 08/01:30Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint, outflow-like CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at approximately 2024-11-08T04:17Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is faint field line opening seen along the SW limb beginning at approx. 08/03:22Z as seen in SDO AIA 171

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint, outflow-like CME first visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-08T07:12Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this eruption is faint field line opening visible in the SW beginning at approximately 08/06:36Z as seen in SDO AIA 171

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint, outflow-like CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-08T08:24Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is faint field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171 along the SW limb beginning at approx. 08/07:12Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint loop CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-08T16:36Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The start time of this CME is likely slightly earlier, but is obscured by a SOHO LASCO C2 data gap from 08/09:24Z to 08/16:36Z. The source of this event is likely far sided as faint opening field lines are visible along the NE limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 08/13:48Z, but no clear source is seen on the disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint loop CME seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not observed in STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. The source for this CME is uncertain, as no on-disk or limb signature is observed around this time--with prior field line movement around 2024-11-08T13:48Z in SDO AIA 171 being attributed to separate CME 2024-11-08T16:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to lack of STEREO COR2A data to triangulate with, and uncertain, unobserved source in EUV imagery.

note: A very minor faint and narrow CME/jet to the NW in C2/C3, not seen in STA. No clear source found on disk, however there are some moving field lines (maybe rising post-eruptive arcades) on the NW limb seen around 2024-11-09T10:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is not seen in STEREO A coronagraph and no clear source has been found, so POS analysis is the only definitive one.

note: Bright and relatively slow loop CME seen to the southeast in both SOHO and STEREO A coronagraphs; while SDO AIA 171 imagery appears to suggest the eruption originates from the far-side, GOES SUVI 284 shows several areas of brightening/dimming near S10E70 while the CME core, visible off the southeast limb, propagates outward, possibly leading to it lifting off. Triangulation of the leading edge also suggested the CME was associated with activity from the Earth-visible disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO C2/STEREO A.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an M9.4 flare and eruption from Active Region 13889 (S10E27) starting around 2024-11-10T12:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-10T17:12Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a C6.7 flare from AR 3889 (S10E30) peaking at 10/15:58Z, along with a minor eruption seen exhibiting Eastward deflection in SDO AIA 94 and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. Event was too faint to be reliably tracked in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: CME first seen in the West by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-11-10T23:09Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in later frames. The source of this event is a C8.4 class flare from AR 3881 (S09W98) beginning at 10/22:31Z. This flare is visible in SDO AIA 94, 131,and STEREO A EUVI 195, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211, and GOES SUVI 304, as well as post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 131 and STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: A very faint but fast and relatively narrow CME with the fuzzy front that is only somewhat clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 running difference imagery. Its source is likely a relatively minor filament eruption seen starting around 2024-11-11T00:10Z, as seen in SDO AIA 304/193, GOES SUVI 304/195/284 and STEREO A EUVI 195. The filament is centered at ~N20E25 and stretches from N27E40 to N17E17. Coronal signatures of this CME include an ejecta seen erupting in SDO AIA 304 and a dimming and post-eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 193/195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the location of the source (the erupting filament) also confirmed by the fit of the front in two coronagraphs.

note: A bright lightbulb-shaped CME likely associated with the SE part of a huge southern filament in the SE which is seen erupting in AIA 304 starting at 2024-11-11T14:10Z and breaking up into two parts around 2024-11-11T15:39. This massive filament stretches from at least ~S55E60 to S50E01 deg and may be roughly centered around S45E30 but could also have a sigmoid more northern part to the west (not clear if this part erupted).

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate measurement based on the best fit of the front in two coronagraph and is in accordance with the location of the source.

note: CME seen to the northeast in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is a filament eruption beginning around 2024-11-11T17:25Z, which appears to be resting far-sided prior to its eruption from N08->N30 over the NE limb, evidenced visually in SDO AIA 304 and also with far-sided brightening in SDO AIA 171 starting around 2024-11-11T22:33Z. Some filament material lands on the Earth-facing disk post-eruption, evidenced by spots of brightening on the disk in SDO AIA 304, so a range of longitudes may exist for this CME source, but nonetheless is it far-north and out of the ecliptic.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement triangulated between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery, and based on the approximate source location which is visible slightly beyond the northwest limb.

note: CME first visible to the NW in STEREO A COR2 white light imagery starting at 2024-11-12T01:53Z. The start time is earlier in COR2A running difference imagery (about 2024-11-12T01:23Z). CME also visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 after a short data gap from 2024-11-11T23:48Z to 2024-11-12T01:57Z. The source of this CME is a filament eruption starting around 2024-11-12T22:53Z with footpoints at approximately N22W56 and N14W67. The filament eruption is best seen in SDO AIA 304, but an EUV wave and some dimming can be seen in SDO AIA 193 across the NW quadrant of the disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-12T04:48Z. CME also seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely a small amount of ejecta off the ESE limb best seen in SDO AIA 304 at 2024-11-12T02:58Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first visible to the W in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-12T08:24Z. The CME disappears before reaching the FOV of SOHO LASCO C3 and is not visible in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely some field line movement best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting around 2024-11-12T07:27Z to the north of AR 3886. Some brightening can also be seen at the same location in SDO AIA 171 around 2024-11-12T08:18Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2 based on on-disk source location.

note: Faint CME seen to the SSE in all coronagraphs. The source is uncertain, as nothing is observed in SDO EUV imagery on-disk around the triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, which produced a good fit around S68E26.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. This CME front is notably more visible in later frames of running difference imagery despite its faintness in white light imagery.

note: Faint CME seen to the SSE in all coronagraphs. The source is uncertain, as nothing is observed in SDO EUV imagery on-disk around the triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, which produced a good fit around S49E02.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. This CME front is notably more visible in later frames of running difference imagery despite its faintness in white light imagery.

note: CME first visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-12T13:36Z. CME also visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is a filament eruption on the NW limb. The footpoints are centered at about N14 and N30. The filament is best seen in SDO AIA 304 and can be seen rising off the disk starting about 2024-11-12T11:51Z. The filament "snaps" at about 2024-11-12T13:10Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. CME occurs during data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint and narrow CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Source is likely a small filament, which lifts off around 2024-11-12T15:13Z in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 284, and spans approximately N32W72 to N25 with longitudes on/around NW limb before liftoff. This filament was likely destabilized by the prior, larger CME 2024-11-12T13:36Z. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-11-12T13:23Z to 2024-11-12T23:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using source location and best fit in C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap lasting from 2024-11-12T13:23Z to 2024-11-12T23:53Z.

note: Faint loop CME visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is widely opening field lines seen located just beyond the SW limb, starting around 2024-11-12T21:42Z in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between C3 and COR2A and a far-sided source location as indicated by UV imagery.

note: Slow eruptive CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-13T01:36Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is unclear as no identifiable eruption or activity is seen in the NE quadrant at in the hours leading up to this start of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to uncertain source location and range of fitting longitudes (approx. -100 to -50)

note: Faint CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is faint widely opening field lines located on/beyond NE limb seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2024-11-13T09:13Z. Some field line movement is also seen in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement due to lack of clear difference imagery in SWPC_CAT and no source location on disk.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-13T17:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not currently visible in STEREO A CORA due to a data gap beginning at 13/15:23Z. The source of this event is a minor eruption beginning at approx. 13/15:45Z located at approx. S20E05 as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193 and 211

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location as there is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this event.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-13T17:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is mostly obscured in STEREO A CORA due to a data gap from 13/15:23Z - 13/23:53Z. The source of this event is clear field line opening seen beyond the NE limb in SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 13/16:30Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and one frame of STEREO A COR2. The STEREO A COR 2 frame is fairly far out in the field of view, so while it confirms a far sided measurement, this event may fit with longitudes between -120 and -140.

note: Bright asymmetrical loop CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-13T20:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A CORA due to a data gap from 13/15:23Z to 13/23:53Z. The source of this event is a wide filament blowout originating from approx. S07E75 exhibiting heavy Northern deflection beginning at approx. 13/17:05 as seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-14T01:25Z. CME also seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely some material that is ejected from beyond the ENE limb and is deflected northward. This can best be seen in SDO AIA 304 at 2024-11-14T01:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Possible range in location from E115 to E125 and N35 to N40.

note: CME first seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-14T05:48Z. Also visible to the S in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is somewhat ambiguous but is most likely far-sided. There is some very subtly moving field lines from behind the S limb starting about 2024-11-14T3:30Z that last until about 2024-11-14T04:30Z; this is best seen in SDO AIA 171. Another source possibility is a very minor brightening around AR 3889 at about 2024-11-14T04:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on SOHO LASCO C2/C3. There was no definitive source candidate. CME was not traceable in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Very faint CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-14T06:48Z. CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 and disappears before leaving the FOV of SOHO LASCO C2. This CME is difficult to identify in white light imagery and is better seen in running difference imagery. No definitive source was found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding sources observed on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 coronagraph imagery. The source is likely an eruption near S18W28 starting around 2024-11-14T12:48Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly as this event is not measurable in STEREO A COR2 and therefore cannot be confirmed using stereoscopic viewpoints.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and in STEREO A COR2 following a data gap. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the northeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 starting around 2024-11-14T18:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. It is difficult to observe this event in STEREO A COR2, either being too faint or directed behind/out of the field of view. The source is likely a filament eruption visible slightly beyond the southeast limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-14T20:00Z. An opening of field lines is visible over the southeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: The precise source location is unknown as the source is visible beyond the eastern limb. However, the measured longitude was based on an approximate source location of -100 degrees. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result of this approximation.

note: Bright loop CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T02:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this CME is an M1.1 flare from AR 3893 (S19E47) and subsequently triggered filament eruption from approx. S45E50. Based on initial measurements, the flare and filament eruption serve as one large eruptive signature rather than two separate events, both associated with this CME. The flare can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 94 and 131, and the filament can be seen in SDO AIA, STEREO A COR2 and GOES SUVI 304. A large area of dimming is visible in SDO AIA 193 and 211, along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94 and 131, as well as rising field line loops seen in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Narrow jet CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T07:12Z. This event is too faint/narrow to be reliably tracked in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. There is no clear source seen for this CME apart from very minor field line movement seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171. This CME fades quickly in SOHO LASCO C2.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to lack of visible source and reliable STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate event.

note: Very faint CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T07:36Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is too faint to reliably track in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME appears to be a small area of dimming located at approx. S45E35 as seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2A. This event was too faint to be reliably tracked in SOHO LASCO C3

note: Wide, faint CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T10:24Z exhibiting a Northern deflection, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a far sided filament eruption seen in GOES SUVI 304, along with field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Wide CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T14:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not currently visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to an ongoing data gap beginning at 15/12:53Z. The source of this CME is a filament eruption originating from along the West limb (approx. S05W80) exhibiting a strong Northern deflection. This eruption can be seen clearly in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304, along with clear opening field lines seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen in the North by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-15T15:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not currently visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to an ongoing data gap beginning at 15/12:53Z. The source of this event is minor field line opening along the North limb as seen in SDO AIA 211. The lack of a clear source and STA COR2 imagery makes determining 3D parameters of this CME difficult.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to lack of precise source location and no STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate for a 3D measurement.

note: Jet-like narrow CME seen to the southwest in SOHO C2 during a STEREO A COR2 data gap. Likely associated with a minor, point-source eruption seen best in SDO AIA 171 around S18W45, seemingly with some southern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-spacecraft measurement (SOHO) of the CME leading edge out to about 7 solar radii assuming some southern deflection and constraining the longitude.

note: Narrow CME seen to the northeast along the northeast streamer which appears to get wider after 2024-11-16T01:36Z in running difference imagery. This CME is probably associated with an equatorial eruption near the eastern limb that was deflected northeast as seen in GOES SUVI/SDO AIA 304 probably between a longitude of -90 to -100, but may potentially be associated with a more far-sided eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement based on additional available coronagraph imagery in SWPC_CAT.

Preliminary two spacecraft leading edge measurement out to about 6 solar radii which considers the more narrow portion of the CME as observed in SOHO imagery to be associated with the limb eruption observed in GOES/SDO 304. Uncertainty in longitude about +/- 10 degrees.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is opening field lines seen near the west limb starting around 2024-11-16T08:55Z in STEREO A EUV 195 and SDO AIA 171/193. The source may be AR 3886, which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-11-15.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is partially obscured by the NE streamer in STEREO A COR2. The source is field line movement visible beyond the NE limb starting around 2024-11-16T11:09Z in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location beyond limb.

note: CME visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is best seen as opening field lines beyond the NW limb starting 2024-11-16T11:33Z in SDO AIA 171 in ISWA. Faint field line movement can be seen on the NW limb in STEREO A EUV 195 as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as source location beyond the west limb.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 due to the presence of a NE streamer. The potential source is opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284 and SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-11-16T13:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The leading edge of the CME was not measurable in available STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Faint CME first seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-17T08:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is far sided field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171 beginning at approx. 17/07:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Bright loop CME first seen to the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-17T10:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is distinct field line movement seen along the South limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2A

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-17T11:00Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening and brightening from a currently unnumbered Active Region along the NE limb (approx. N25E90) at approx. 17/09:45Z. This field line movement can be seen in SDO AIA 171, along with post eruptive arcades in SDO AIA 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-17T11:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a C5.3 flare from a currently unnumbered Active Region along the SE limb (approx. S10E90) as seen in SDO AIA 131. Field line opening is also visible in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211, along with post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94, and 131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-17T16:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is faint field line movement seen beyond the West limb in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A CME with the front clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C3 but somewhat obscured in C2 by the continuous outflow following the earlier farsided CME: 2024-11-17T10:00Z, and catching up with it, as seen in SOHO LASCO C3. The CME is fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A coronagraph imagery. No source for this CME was found on the Earth-facing disk, so the CME is likely to be farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Since the CME is fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery, only POS analysis is definitive. However, from the part of the CME that IS seen in COR2, it is likely that its latitude and longitude could be close to those of the preceding 2024-11-17T10:00Z CME.

note: CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-18T03:24Z. Also visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely a small area of dimming best seen in SDO AIA 193 just to the W of AR 3901 starting at 2024-11-18T02:45Z that is accompanied by some faint field line movement.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-18T04:36Z. CME also visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely a small area of brightening near AR 3900 and some associated faint field line movement on the NE limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting at ~2024-11-18T03:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-18T12:12Z. Also seen to SW in SOHO LASCO C3. CME occurs during a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an M1.6 flare from AR 3897 that peaked at 11:12Z. The flare and associated eruption can be seen in SDO AIA 304 starting at 2024-11-18T11:09Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location on Earth-facing disk and running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-11-18T15:38Z. The source is likely an M2.0 flare and eruption from Active Region 13901 (S10E74) starting around 2024-11-18T19:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the east limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery, with post-eruptive arcades starting to form around 2024-11-18T20:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, there is no stereoscopic viewpoint to confirm the measured parameters which may vary slightly as a result.

note: Minor, puff-like CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. There are few candidates for a source region on the Earth facing disk in available EUV imagery and appears to fit a far-sided leading edge measurement using triangulation, so the eruption is likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement using triangulation to fit the source longitude.

note: Very minor eruption seen to the east-southeast in all available coronagraph imagery which may be associated with a small point-source eruption occurring from near AR 3901 near S10E75 or so; some field line movement is seen off the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using triangulation to determine the source longitude.

note: CME seen to the high NW in all coronagraphs, with STEREO COR2A returning from a data gap at 2024-11-20T00:09Z abd barely catching the CME front before it leaves its FOV. This CME erupted very slowly at first with speeds around 63 km/s, accelerating to a more constant speed by ~2024-11-20T23:00Z well into LASCO C3's FOV. The source is far northern latitude field line movement on or beyond the NW limb, observed best in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284 beginning around 2024-11-19T08:00Z and accelerating faster aroudn 2024-11-19T12:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with late SOHO LASCO C3 frames only as STEREO COR2A was in a data gap, and the front was traveling much slower in earlier LASCO C3 frames and all of LASCO C2. To get a more accurate final speed, only frames past 2024-11-20T23:00Z were used, as significant acceleration was observed when including frames earlier than this.

note: CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to data gap lasting from 2024-11-19T12:38Z to 2024-11-20T00:23Z. Source is opening field lines near AR 13892 (S10W89) on the SW limb. Seen in GOES SUVI 284/304 at 2024-11-19T16:37Z. Field line movement on the SW limb near AR 13892 also seen in SDO AIA 193/171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using an abundance of only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 frames, using a true longitude of W90 based on the source location seen in UV imagery. STEREO A COR2 was in a data gap lasting from 2024-11-19T12:38Z to 2024-11-20T00:23Z.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to field line movement starting around 2024-11-20T04:30Z visible over the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is faint but visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. It is too faint to be considered measurable in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to field line movement visible on or just beyond the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-20T08:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location, which is visible near the western limb.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-11-20T13:38Z. The source is related to an M1.1 flare and subsequent eruption from Active Region 13897 (S08W89) starting around 2024-11-20T19:15Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible over the western limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, the measured parameters could not be confirmed using stereoscopic viewpoints and they may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-11-20T13:38Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore uncertain source location.

note: Faint CME to the southeast, where the likely source a small filament eruption near the Active Region 13899 (S18E26). The filament stretches from S13E11 to S25E50 and lifts off starting around 2024-11-21T01:00Z, as seen in SDO AIA 131, 193, 304 imagery. There is also a movement of field lines in SDO AIA 171 which seems to be closer to the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based solely on the best fit with two coronagraphs. The erupting filament seems to be much more central that the longitude in this analysis, so there must have been some deflection - or the source was more eastern.

note: Bright wide CME to the southeast, with a wider, more halo-like shock front seen in SOHO. Except for two early timestamps, the CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A. Its source is a significant eruption of a large filament off the southeast limb (likely behind the limb), seen most clearly in AIA 304, 171 and SUVI 304 (but also seen in other channels) starting with 2024-11-21T11:17Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Imperfect analysis of the bulk front based on the fit in two coronagraphs (note that only two timestamps for COR2A are available at the time of analysis).

note: Bright and fast partial halo to the northwest, with bulk and (fainter) shock fronts, associated with the fast backsided eruption marked by an EUV wave and fast opening of field lines behind the NW limb seen around 2024-11-21T18Z. The source is backsided, based on the coronal signatures and might be Active Region 3889 which would be at the longitude 115 to 120 degrees at the moment.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with ONE coronagraph only (SOHO) since there is no imagery from STEREO A COR2 because of an extensive data gap and the source is backsided, based on the coronal signatures. The range of possible longitudes that produce a decent fit in SOHO is from 115 to 140 degrees.
Preliminary analysis based on the SHOCK of the CME. Higher degree of uncertainty with parameters due to single-spacecraft analysis.

note: Slow to erupt CME to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery but speeds up in later frames. This CME appears to be associated with a filament eruption along the SW limb in SDO/AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-11-21T19:45Z. There are also moving/opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. CME appears to speed up in later frames. Earlier frames measured speeds around 300-350km/s.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be an eruption in the NE between N25E35 to N35E50 associated with moving/opening field lines in SDO/AIA 171, dimming in SDO/AIA 193, and brightening in SDO/AIA 131 between 21:00Z and 22:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME seen to the NW in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain with no visible source in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI, or STEREO A EUVI. The CME is less visible in SOHO LASCO C2, becoming more distinct in LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a good far-sided fit between the coronagraphs.

note: Faint and narrow CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-22T04:17Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this CME is some minor field line movement and dimming seen in SDO AIA 193 at approx. 22/03:27Z centered near S40E70.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 running difference imagery as it is obscured by the pylon.

note: Narrow, faint CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-22T07:12Z as well as by SOHO LASCO CC3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a minor eruption from the East limb (approx. S20E90) beginning at approx. 22/06:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 304. Field line movement is also visible in SDO AIA 171 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint and narrow CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-22T08:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a minor eruption beginning at approx. 22/08:25Z centered at approx. S30E20 exhibiting heavy Eastern deflection as seen in SDO AIA 304. Faint field line movement is also visible in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Far SSW thin CME seen in all coronagraphs. The source for this CME is uncertain with no visible source in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI, or STEREO A EUVI. The CME is less visible in SOHO LASCO C2, becoming more distinct in LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a good far-sided, high southern latitude fit between the coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME first visible in the West by STEREO A COR 2 beginning at 2024-11-22T09:38Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in later frames. There is no clear source seen for this CME, and the leading edge fades quickly in SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to uncertain source location and unreliable imagery in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Faint, hazy CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-22T10:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a region of dimming centered at approx. N35E35 as seen in SDO AIA 211, along with opening field lines seen in SDO AIA 171 tracing back to this same region.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. This event is not measurable in SOHO LASCO C3 due to faint leading edge.

note: Narrow CME to the E/SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be an eruption from AR 3906 starting around 2024-11-22T15:00Z, best seen in SDO/AIA 304 (filament ejecta), SDO/AIA 171 (moving/opening field lines), and SDO/AIA 193 (moving/opening field lines and brightening).

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on potential source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. The CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery due to the pylon blocking most of the CME. It is also not visible in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery due to a data gap.

note: Mystery faint front to the south in SOHO LASCO C2 difference imagery starting around 18:48Z. The source is unclear but may possibly be associated with very slow moving/opening field lines along the southern limb in SDO/AIA 171. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on plane-of-sky analysis using SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. The source is likely an M1.0 flare from AR 3906 (S18E74) peaking at 2024-11-22T22:15Z, with brightening and an eruption best seen in SDO AIA 193. Opening field lines are visible in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284. The eruption is not clearly visible in STEREO A EUV 195 due to a data gap from approx. 2024-11-22T12:35Z-22:05Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as the source location. The leading edge of the CME fades away quickly in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption around N25E30 starting around 2024-11-22T19:45Z, best seen as dimming in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely beyond the west limb of the Earth facing disk, as moving/opening field lines can be seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2024-11-23T00:00Z. The eruption is best seen from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195, where opening field lines from an AR near the limb are visible between a data gap from 2024-11-22T23:05Z to 2024-11-23T00:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as source location beyond the limb.

note: Narrow CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is an eruption near the west limb from the point of view of STEREO A EUVI 195 starting 2024-11-23T01:25Z. Moving/opening field lines are also visible in SDO AIA 171/193 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Two potential source candidate eruptions are seen in EUV imagery: one around S15W55 (near AR 3898) and another around S25W55 starting around 2024-11-23T03:38Z, best seen in SDO AIA 193. The eruption near AR 3898 is believed to be the more likely candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Limited imagery was available for this measurement as the CME fades away quickly in later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint, narrow CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, and may be eruptive activity from AR 3906.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. The CME is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source may be an eruption on the disk from AR 3906 (S16E65) starting at 2024-11-23T09:37Z, based on field line movement seen in SDO AIA 171 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as potential source location.

note: CME faintly visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. It is obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. The potential source may be an eruption on the disk starting around 2024-11-23T12:01Z around S15E50, best seen with some brightening and rising field lines in GOES SUVI 284 and SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location. The CME was blocked by the pylon and not measurable in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The source appears to be an eruption from AR 13898/plage region 13893 in the SW based on SDO/AIA 131 and 193 starting around 2024-11-23T19:20Z. There are also moving/opening field lines visible along the limb in GOES SUVI 284 which may be associated with the eruption on the disk but could also indicate a far sided simultaneous eruption which could play into overlapping fronts seen with this CME to the SW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on potential source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery.

note: Narrow CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-24T10:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no distinct source for this CME, however a large amount of field line movement, brightening and general activity is visible in the vicinity of ARs 3905 (S09E48) and 3906 (S16E54) as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-11-24T16:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not reliably visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is a minor eruption and brightening centered at approx. N15E75 as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Narrow, jet-like CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T00:24Z. Also visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C3 but is not visible in STEREO A COR2. There appears to be some northward deflection starting a couple frames into the propagation. There is not a definitive source for this CME. One possibility is some brightening and activity just to the NW of AR 3905 best seen in SDO AIA 193 starting at 00:08Z. This coronal signature is likely too late to be the source. Another more likely source possibility is some faint field line movement on the ESE limb best seen in SDO AIA 171 starting at 2024-11-24T23:21Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made using SWPC_CAT based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: CME first seen to the NNE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T01:48Z. CME also seen to the NNE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME is very faint in white light and is better seen in running difference imagery. The source of this CME is possibly some minor brightening and movement of plasma centered around N20E25 starting around 2024-11-25T00:27Z with some northward deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as potential source location.

note: CME first seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T03:12Z. CME also seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely a small filament eruption centered around S40-45E28 that is visible in SDO AIA 304 and SDO AIA 193 starting about 2024-11-25T01:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT as well as potential source location.

note: CME first visible to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T04:00Z. Also visible to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME closely follows CME: 2024-11-25T03:12Z but is slightly slower and slightly wider and is clearly distinguishable in running difference imagery. There is not a clearly definitive source for this CME, but a possible candidate is a deflected source associated with an M1.1 flare from AR 3906 (S13E46) that peaked at 2024-11-25T01:59Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this CME. The front appears to be faint with a brighter core and possible h-alpha emission visible in C2 imagery. The source appears to be a filament eruption starting around 17Z beyond the SW limb in SDO/AIA 304. Associated moving/opening field lines are visible in SDO/AIA 171 and 193 as well as in GOES SUVI 284 imagery

cmeAnalyses.note: As the source is visible slightly beyond the western limb, a precise source location is unknown. However, the source is visible near the western limb so a measured longitude of 90 degrees was used. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result of the unknown/far-sided source location. This measurement tracks the brighter leading edge portion and excludes the faint feature preceding this.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-11-25T13:38Z to 2024-11-26T00:38Z. This CME partially overlaps with and follows in the path of preceding CME: 2024-11-25T18:00Z. The source for this event is unknown and likely far-sided, but may be related to the filament eruption visible just beyond the southwest limb in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-25T17:00Z, which was associated with the aforementioned CME: 2024-11-25T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the unknown and likely far-sided source location.

note: CME first visible to the W in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T21:12Z. CME also visible to the W in SOHO LASCO C3 but is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. There is not a clear, separate source for this CME, and it follows in a similar propagation path to CME: 2024-11-25T18:00Z and CME: 2024-11-25T19:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SPWC_CAT.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and possibly to the SE in STEREO A COR2 imagery following a data gap. The CME is likely associated with the M1.9 flare from AR 13091 as seen from SDO/AIA 131 and associated dimming in SDO/AIA 193 starting around 20:33Z. The dimming and associated EUV wave is seen moving out in all directions, most notably seen to the north, east, and south of the source location. This CME event overlaps with CMEs visible to the southwest which began around 2024-11-25T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters are based on best fit of feature in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery with guidance of directionality of features seen after a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery. Since the features aren't clear in STEREO A COR2 imagery it was not usable for this fit. Due to this, there is a higher degree of uncertainty with this CME analysis.

note: CME first seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-11-25T21:36Z. CME also seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C3 (partially obscured by pylon) and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely some activity involving ARs 3905 and 3906 staring around 2025-11-25T17:00Z that continues for a few hours. The movement and brightening is particularly visible in SDO AIA 304 and SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 and probable source location.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is limited imagery available for this CME in STEREO A COR2 data. The source appears to be a filament eruption on the eastern limb of SDO/AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-11-26T12:50Z. Moving/opening field lines are also visible in GOES SUVI 284 to the east with this eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of features in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery using potential source location for longitude.

note: Narrow CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to the faintness of the CME. Source is a C3.5 flare from S20W72 (no AR) with peak time 2024-11-27T02:28Z and a narrow ribbon of ejecta similarly from about S20 near the SW limb seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-11-27T02:34Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and fit using SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 frames only. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2, likely due to the faintness of CME as seen from STEREO A's perspective. (This CME is oriented farther out of STEREO-A's plane of sky than SOHO LASCO's plane of sky, making it less likely to be visible in STEREO-A than in SOHO.)

note: Very faint loop CME seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is very faint field line movement seen beyond the E limb in GOES SUVI 304/284 imagery, with a small amount of material (it did not fully escape and become ejecta) possibly associated with the eruption, starting around 2024-11-27T08:50Z. General field line movement and a very gradual 'thinning'/dimming/opening of field lines can be seen when toggling through GOES SUVI 284 imagery between 2024-11-27T08:00Z-14:00Z. GOES SUVI used for analysis; outage in SDO affecting all SDO data product timestamps starting at about 2024-11-26T23:52Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using best fit between C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2, as well as observation of field line movement that may be an eruptive signature beyond the E limb, as seen in GOES SUVI imagery of the Earth-facing disk.

note: Southeastward partial halo CME where the likely source a filament eruption seen in GOES SUVI 304 and 284 starting around 2024-11-27T18:45Z. The filament extends southeastwards from Active Regions 13905 (S09E01) and 13906 (S16E08). The CME also has a second, follow-up front - a loop seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-11-27T20:36Z. Only one frame for this CME is available in STEREO A COR2 because of an extensive data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs, the latitude of the analysis seems to be more southern compared to the latitude of the possible source, so there was possibly some southward deflection.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and one frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a filament eruption  visible on or just beyond the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-11-27T19:26Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. Only one timestamp is available in STEREO A COR2 because of a data gap.

note: A slow CME that is very slow to develop (speeds up a little bit with time). Its likely source is a small eruption visible near the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 171, 193, 285, 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-28T01:00Z. The flux rope for this CME is later clearly seen in coronagraph.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate measurement of the well showing flux rope (not the fuzzier front) based on fitting with two coronagraphs, confirmed by the possible source (small eruption near limb).

note: No clear source has been found but around 2024-11-28T18:17Z in GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, there is an area of slight field lines movement close to the southeast limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS measurement is definitive since the CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A and no definite source has been found on disk.

note: Fast narrow jet to the southwest in both coronagraphs. No definitive source has been found on disk, however there may be a very minor movement of field lines on or close to the southwest limb around 2024-11-29T06Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Slow, wide, outflow-like CME seen to the north in SOHO LASCO and to the west-northwest in STEREO A COR2. Likely associated with far-sided activity at high northern latitudes.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement encompassing all but the eastern most portion of the CME leading edge.

note: Loop CME with internal filamentary structure seen due south in SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2; the source of this CME is likely the eruption of a SE hanging filament starting around 2024-11-29T12:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304, 284 and STA EUVI 195 and centered ~S35E20.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge/bulk measurement of the CME using SOHO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Jet-like CME seen to the east-southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3; associated with a minor eruption near an equatorial active region near the eastern limb seen best in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-11-2919:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft leading edge measurement approximating the source longitude based on EUV imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is an eruption visible near the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-30T05:30Z which exhibits a clear southern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption visible on/near the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 284 and 304 imagery starting around 2024-11-30T10:40Z. An opening of field lines is visible over the eastern limb at this time in GOES SUVI 171 and 195 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: A CME to the west where the source is a loop-like filament eruption seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting after 2024-12-01T02:16Z. There are post-eruptive arcades and dimming seen in SUVI 284/195 and in STEREO A EUVI 195. The filament is centered at ~N20W40 in STEREO A so the source is at ~N20W70, as seen in GOES SUVI and SDO.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Minor jet (or rather the first in a series of minor southward jets). The source has not been found and is possibly backsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames following a data gap. The source is likely an eruption near the eastern limb seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, 304 starting around 2024-12-01T21:30Z. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 171 and 195 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Diffuse CME with little to no leading edge seen to the east-south-east in SOHO LASCO C2 and also in STEREO A COR2. Associated with opening and moving field lines behind the southeastern limb seen best in GOES SUVI 284 around 06:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two-spacecraft bulk measurement of the CME taking into account the brightest portions of the CME bulk as the leading edge became untraceable about midway into the CME propagation through LASCO coronagraph imagery.

note: CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-02T16:36Z. CME also seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3. The CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is likely from beyond the SE limb at approximately -95 to -105 degrees longitude based on comparison with two previous CMEs (2024-12-01T22:00Z and 2024-12-02T07:12Z) that are very similar.

cmeAnalyses.note: Initial plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT. Measurement was updated to have a 3D longitude of E90, as source seems to be on/along the East limb, and fits between E85 and E105 were achieved.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-02T19:36Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3. There is no clear or definitive coronal signature, so the source of this CME is likely far-sided. There are some faint moving field lines off the SW limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about 2024-12-02T17:00Z that continue for a few hours that could be associated with this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-03T01:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is an eruption beyond the SW limb as seen in GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304, along with opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 195 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Extremely faint loop CME to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to overnight data gap which lasted from 2024-12-03T12:23Z to 2024-12-04T00:38Z. Source is a filament eruption seen on the NW limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-12-03T20:16Z. This filament is located directly on or just beyond the limb (W90-W110 or so) and spans from N10-N25. Note: The timing of this candidate source is indeed very close to the start time of the CME, which may evoke skepticism about this truly being the source, but due to the congruency between the location and shape of this source with this CME as well as a subsequent source identified which matches well with the CME seen one frame later at 12:48Z, there is a slight increase in confidence that this eruption is indeed a strong candidate source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate location of source as observed in UV imagery and based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 frames. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to overnight data gap which lasted from 2024-12-03T12:23Z to 2024-12-04T00:38Z.

note: Narrow CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to overnight data gap which lasted from 2024-12-03T12:23Z to 2024-12-04T00:38Z. Source is likely a small jet-like eruption of material seen on or just beyond the NW limb (W90-W110) and at about N15 in GOES SUVI 304 (seen most clearly at later frame 2024-12-03T20:56Z) immediately following an on-limb filament eruption which had likely resulted in a preceding northwest CME: 2024-12-03T20:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate location of source as observed in UV imagery and based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 frames. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to overnight data gap which lasted from 2024-12-03T12:23Z to 2024-12-04T00:38Z.

note: Faint CME to the SE seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is an M2.3 flare with peak time 2024-12-04T10:00Z as well as rising and opening loops of field lines which begin simultaneously with the flare and from the same location, as seen in GOES SUVI 131. The location of this source is an unnumbered region directly on the East limb, located at S10E90 at the time of the flare.
