cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of faint leading edge using C2 and COR2A. This CME was not visible in C3 difference imagery; it was nearly entirely blocked by the pylon and the partial edge that could be seen was extremely faint and unreliable to track. The leading edge is faint and quickly becomes diffuse in both C2 and COR2A.

note: This CME is visible to the east/northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption visible near the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery starting around 2024-12-05T00:30Z. A rising loop is visible over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 171 and dimming is visible near the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 195 imagery around this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME with diffuse leading edge seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO and north in STEREO A; likely associated with far-side activity, though could possibly be associated with a point source eruption located near N35E02, with some flickering field lines in the north seen around 02:45Z in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft measurement using triangulation to determine longitude.

note: CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO/STEREO A COR2 associated with an M2.5-class solar flare and subsequent eruption from near Active Region 3906 occupying very close to the southwestern limb. The CME becomes appear bright in initial imagery and well-defined and becomes more diffuse with time, eventually losing its leading edge.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement as the leading edge becomes diffuse with time, utilizing both SOHO and STEREO A for triangulation.

note: Fast CME with protruding/faster nose seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO during a STEREO A COR2 data gap. Likely associated with far-sided activity as evidenced by moving field lines seen off the southeast limb in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary leading edge measurement using one spacecraft (SOHO) which considers a large latitude to fit visual observations; uncertainty in longitude is quite large and may be as large as +/- 30 degrees.

note: CME seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, missed in STEREO COR2A due to a data gap spanning this event. The source for this CME appears to be far-sided, and may be continued outflow following the larger, fast CME 2024-12-05T15:48Z which was analyzed far-sided to S47E124. Field line movement over the SSE limb in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-12-05T16:30Z may correlate to this event, but this movement may just be continued from 2024-12-05T15:48Z as ewll.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
Plane-of-sky measurement with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A and the uncertain longitude of this likely far-sided source, via observations in GOES SUVI 171 and 284.

note: Very faint CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-05T20:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap from 2024-12-05T12:09Z to 2024-12-06T00:38Z. The source of this event is clear field line opening seen along or just beyond the SW limb as seen in GOES SUVI 195 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to source near the limb and lack of available STEREO A imagery to triangulate

note: Faint CME with a fairly narrow shape but a type of "hook" at the end visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery (more easily identified in difference imagery). There isn't a clear source, however there is some moving/opening field lines along the SW of GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-06T23:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit between SOHO and STEREO A difference imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a filament eruption near N10E60 as seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 06/01:15Z with associated moving/opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284 and dimming in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of CME in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint, outflow-like CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which lasted from 2024-12-06T15:53Z to 2024-12-06T19:53Z. Source is subtle and slow field line movement from on or beyond the SW limb, seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting as early as 2024-12-06T13:00Z with a slightly more distinct outflow of material seen at about 14:10Z. Opening field lines on the SW limb can also be seen in GOES SUVI 195 at 14:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement of the leading edge made using SWPC CAT. Several frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 were used. Leading edge becomes too diffuse to track only after a handful of C3 frames. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which lasted from 2024-12-06T15:53Z to 2024-12-06T19:53Z.

note: Very faint, puff-like CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2. The leading edge becomes completely diffuse before reaching halfway through C2's field-of-view. The source is uncertain. One candidate source is an area of dimming seen centered at about N10W40 starting at 2024-12-06T18:00Z in GOES SUVI 284, accompanied by a small amount of brightening from AR 13910 (N16W60) and/or AR 13918 (N13W57). Another candidate source is subtle field line movement on or beyond the NW limb seen in GOES SUVI 284/195. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which lasted from 2024-12-06T15:53Z to 2024-12-06T19:53Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, due to lack of COR2A and uncertainty of source location. The leading edge becomes completely diffuse before reaching halfway through C2's FOV.

note: This CME is faintly visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO and STEREO A coronagraph imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the W/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There are a lot of overlapping fronts following the initial front of this CME. There are two potential sources, one is moving/opening field lines beyond the limb as seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 02:30Z. There is also some movement in the AR's 13912 and 13913 starting around 02Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint jet-like/outflow-like CME to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a very small faint eruption near N20E60 as seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-07T03:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery.

note: Faint front overlapping with the 2024-12-07T04:12Z CME. No clear source was found for this CME on the Earth-facing disk, although there is minor activity from the Active Region 13913 and north of it going on all morning.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. The front in STEREO A COR2 is super faint and fuzzy.

note: Faint jet-like/outflow-like CME to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source appears to be a very small faint eruption near N20E60 as seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-07T06:50Z. (Follows very similar path to the CME first seen at 2024-12-07T04:24Z).

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on the best fit using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: A faint narrow CME in the southwest following the 2024-12-07T04:12Z CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Initially bright but very messy front to the SW in COR2A and C2. The source is the wide opening/movement of field lines on/behind the SW limb in EUVI A 195 (so at longitudes >=120 deg) around 20:05Z. The (very messy) ejecta/filament eruption is also seen in EUVI A 304 on/behind the limb at 2024-12-07T20:15Z after a data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a small eruption from Active Region 13916 (S16E13) starting around 2024-12-08T04:10Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery which appears to deflect towards the southeast.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Flux rope CME with an additional narrow portion on the southern edge that protrudes in front of the leading edge of the main flux rope shape seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is an eruption and X2.2 flare from AR 3912 (S07W52) which peaked at 2024-12-08T09:06Z. Dimming and opening field lines are seen starting at 2024-12-08T09:04Z in GOES SUVI 195/171 spanning from S20W50 to N05W50, with field line movement reaching as far as N20. Ejecta can also be seen in GOS SUVI 304 which can first be seen starting at 2024-12-08T09:24Z, but was likely initiated with the flare. Flare, dimming, and ejecta can also be seen in STEREO A EUVI 195 and 304 at 2024-12-08T09:05Z and 09:15Z, respectively.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2; fits very well to source location (~S10W50) observed in UV imagery.

note: CME faintly seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is unclear, and may be one of several minor candidate source eruptions on the disk, including some brightening from AR 3917 (near S05E05) starting around 2024-12-09T01:56Z in GOES SUVI 195 or some faint dimming starting around 2024-12-09T01:00Z around S50E10 in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT. The CME is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk which agree with the measured longitude of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a faint and minor eruption centered near S50E40 as seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery around 2024-12-09T23:10Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge becomes too diffuse to measure after a few frames, and the measured parameters rely on early imagery as a result.

note: Narrow CME associated with a thin, southward deflecting ejecta seen in the SSE in SUVI 304 around 02:52 and possibly associated with the C9.7 from AR 3922. This southward directed deflection of ejecta and CME is peculiar to today's events from Active Region 3922.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with 2 coronagraphs, somewhat contradicting the location of the flare (long ~-77 deg). Analysis is complicated by a large data gap in SOHO, as well as by the partial obscuring of this CME by SOHO C3 pylon. Longitude of the CME could be as high as -70 degrees (with a different fit with 2 coronagraphs in the tool)

note: A relatively narrow CME associated withthe M6.4 flare from AR 3922 (S18E72), with a narrow southward-deflecting ejecta from this AR seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2024-12-10T04:48Z. Because the sequence of flare/ejecta/CME events is very fast for this and the 2024-12-10T07:24Z CME the attribution to the linked flare is not absolutely certain.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit in two coronagraphs and confirmed by the location of the associated flare.

note: This CME is likely associated with the M1.4 flare from AR 3922 (S18E72) and is also associated with a thin southward-deflecting ejecta from this AR seen in the southwest in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting at 2024-12-10T07:16Z but best seen after 07:28Z. Because the sequence of flare/ejecta/CME events is very fast for this and the 2024-12-10T07:00Z CME (which is associated to the preceding M5.6 flare from the same active region), the exact attribution to the linked flare for these two CMEs is not absolutely certain.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and confirmed by location of the flare.

note: A very slow CME/outflow that follows even slower outflows/fronts that start as early as 2024-12-10T02Z. The source of it could be continuous activity in AR 3920 since this morning (~ location N22E37 at 02Z) which is marked by brightening in SUVI 195. After 08Z there is a minor dimming around this Active Region which could mark the eruption that might be associated with the 2024-12-10T09:53Z front.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs and later confirmed by the possible source (continuous activity all morning culminating with 08Z dimming in AR 3920).

note: Narrow CME associated with M1.5 flare from AR 3922 (S18E72) and a narrow but eventually fan-shaped wide, south-deflecting ejecta from this AR seen in the southeast in SUVI 304/284 and on southeast limb in EUVI A 195 starting at 2024-12-10T11:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. It differs a bit from the location of the associated flare, so there is some westward deflection, in addition to significant southward deflection.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery and at least one frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is a data gap for the majority of this event in STEREO A COR2 imagery with the exception of a single frame at 2024-12-10T14:38Z. The source is unclear but could be a small eruption from AR 13920.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and one frame in STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is high uncertainty due to lack of clear source and having only one frame in STEREO A COR2 imagery of this CME.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and possibly C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for the duration of this event. The source appears to be a C2.8 flare from AR 13920 (N22E27) with a visible eruption and associated filament ejecta starting around 2024-12-10T14:10Z in GOES SUVI 304 and 131 with the ejecta deflected NE.

cmeAnalyses.note: This analysis is based off of the best fit using SOHO LASCO C2 imagery. The front becomes too diffuse/faint to track before it exits the C2 field of view. It is not clearly seen in SOHO LASCO C3 difference imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source appears to be far-sided with moving/opening field lines visible along the S/SE limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-10T15:42Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-Sky analysis based on best fit of CME in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery using SWPC_CAT. The front deflects further south as it progresses out in the C2 field of view.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for the duration of this event. The potential source for this CME is an eruption with filament ejecta from AR 13920 (N22E24) starting around 2024-12-10T16:20Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the potential source location (accounting for deflection of source to the NE) and the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery. The front has a diffuse front making for tricky analysis.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and possibly C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for the duration of this event. The source appears to be a filament ejecta eruption from AR 13920 (N22E28) starting around 2024-12-10T17:08Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304 with deflection to the NE.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the potential source location (accounting for deflection of source to the NE) and the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery. The front is pretty diffuse in SOHO LASCO C2 difference imagery but becomes slightly more clear in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery, however there are overlapping features making this analysis a bit uncertain.

note: This CME is visible to the S/SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. The source appears to be an M1.6 class flare from AR 13922 (S18E70) with a sympathetic eruption to the west of this region starting around 2024-12-10T17:58Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 304, and 284. Moving/opening field lines are visible along the limb as well as a minor EUV wave to the south along the limb as seen in GOES SUVI 284 and 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME deflects far to the south with continued deflection southward as it progresses through the SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 field of view. Due to this, there is some uncertainty with the fit.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for the duration of this event. The source for this CME is possibly a small eruption from AR 13920 (N22E21) starting around 2024-12-10T20:58Z as seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based off of the best fit in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 using the potential source location for longitude and adjusting the latitude to fit the CME.

note: Narrow CME to the northeast, with messy, fuzzy, dimpled front. This CME islikely associated with minor activity in AR 13920 (N15E23).

cmeAnalyses.note: Based on the fit with two coronagraphs, which confirms the source location as the location of the likely associated Active Region 3920 which is showing some minor activity.

note: Relatively slow and wide CME seen to the south in SOHO LASCO imagery and southeast in STEREO A COR2. Very similar in appearance to the far-sided 2024-12-11T12:12Z CME, there are a few sources on the Earth-facing disk including an eruption on the western portion of the disk, but triangulation strongly suggests this event is far-sided. No candidate sources for this CME were observed in EUV imagery. The CME is quite difficult to measure in LASCO C2 with the CME off the southeast (CME: 2024-12-11T06:24Z) obscuring the CME in question (more evidence this is far-sided).

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement using triangulation with difficulty seeing the CME leading edge in SOHO LASCO C2 due to an obscuring CME in front of the CME in question; GONG data supports the eruption coming from a far-sided source with this approximate longitude.

note: Another CME with an asymmetric shape in the "AR 3922 style". It is associated with the M1.9 flare from AR 3922 (S17E55), however the opening of field lines we see in in SUVI 284 seems to be further south from AR 3922. There is also opening of field lines in SUVI 171 closer to this AR.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit in two coronagraphs but confirmed by source location (taking into account southward deflection).

note: Minor CME with messy/fuzzy front with the possible source a lower C-class flare from Active Region 3920, with very minor dimming/possibly faint ejecta seen in GOES SUVI 193/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Narrow CME with fuzzy front to the northeast, with no clear front in SOHO LASCO C2 and likely associated with the M2.7 flare from Active Region 3920 (N22E18) and the narrow NNE ejecta seen at 2024-12-11T10:36 in SUVI 304 at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs, confirmed by the location of the associated flare.

note: Possible partial halo CME seen as two separate portions, a portion to the south and southeast visible in SOHO LASCO C2 as well as a portion to the northeast connected by a very faint front to the east. Also seen to the southwest in STEREO A COR2, suggesting it is far-sided. Likely associated with very faint, fluttering field line movement seen best in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-12-11T12:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-spacecraft measurement attempting to fit both the south/south-southeast bulk measurement as well as the northeast portion in the SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph.

note: Far-sided halo CME with brighter bulk seen to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and also a fainter, torus-shaped shock with wider extent in the equatorial regions. Likely associated with far-sided activity as evidenced by expulsion and rapidly flickering field lines as seen off the south limb best in GOES SUVI 284 around 2024-12-11T21:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Shock front measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 incorporating the southeastward leading edge and western/eastern leading edges simultaneously in one circular-shaped measurement.
Bulk measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 mainly focusing on brighter south portion of the CME.

note: CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO and north in STEREO A COR2 with faster/protruding leading edge/nose feature. Likely associated with far-sided activity as few, if any, sources were observed in GOES SUVI on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft bulk measurement capturing the main shape of the CME inside of the protruding feature (i.e. the CME could be faster than this measurement).

note: Relatively slow and minor CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, seemingly associated with point-source eruption from AR 3916 (S14W46) with some southward deflection as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Not seen well in STEREO A COR2 running difference imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft measurement of the leading edge, holding the known longitude constant.

note: This CME is visible to the west/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery following a data gap from 2024-12-12T15:36Z to 23:24Z. Following the data gap, the CME is visible well into the SOHO LASCO C2/C3 field of view, so the start time is likely earlier than the time stated. This event is visible in STEREO A COR2 after a data gap ending at 2024-12-13T00:53Z for only a few frames. The source is a slow-rising loop visible near or slightly beyond the southwest limb which erupts around 2024-12-12T23:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb at this time in GOES SUVI 171 and 195 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and limited STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery following a data gap from 2024-12-12T15:36Z to 23:24Z. Following the data gap, the CME is visible into the SOHO LASCO C2/C3 field of view, so the start time is likely a bit earlier than the time stated. This event is visible in STEREO A COR2 after a data gap ending at 2024-12-13T00:53Z for only a few frames. The source is an eruption visible from beyond the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery starting around 2024-12-12T23:16Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and the south/southwest in STEREO A COR2. The source is likely a C2.1 flare starting at 2024-12-13T02:21Z from old Active Region 3916 (currently a plage), around S15W55. The eruption is best seen with brightening and an ejecta of material in GOES SUVI 304. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195/304. The CME is not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Reanalysis of this event in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A going more northern and less wide, noting difficulty in tracking the same faint front between both coronagraphs on top of limited STEREO COR2A availaibility.
Only two frames of STEREO A COR2 were available for this measurement, so this measurement is primarily based off of SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery.

note: CME visible to the south/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Partially overlaps in the field of view of the coronagraphs with CME: 2024-12-13T02:48Z. The source is likely an M1.0 flare starting at 2024-12-13T03:11Z from AR 3922 (S18E37) with dimming, opening field lines best seen in GOES SUVI 195/284 as well as an ejecta of material in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 as well as source location in SWPC_CAT. Only one frame of STEREO A COR2 was available for a measurement, and the majority of the measurement uses SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: CME visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source is a filament eruption centered around S35E30 with liftoff starting around 2024-12-13T06:48Z as best seen in GOES SUVI 304. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow CME faintly visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-12-13T11:38Z. The source is not clearly visible in available EUV imagery, and the CME may originate from the far side.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Wide CME seen predominantly to the south in SOHO LASCO imagery during a STEREO A data gap. May be potentially associated with an M1.0 flare from AR 3922 starting at 2024-12-13T14:15Z, but there is no clear eruption of material leading to a CME associated with it. There is some faint dimming seen in GOES SUVI 284 at 14:26Z, close in time to when this was in the coronagraphs. Initial analysis suggests this eruption originates from the far-side, but triangulation with STEREO A data is probably necessary to confirm front-sidedness.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary one spacecraft measurement assuming that the eruption originates from the far-side.

note: Minor narrow outflow seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A COR2 data gap; the source is uncertain, but could potentially be associated with dimming near center disk seen best around 2024-12-13T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge plane of sky measurement as the source is unknown.

note: Fast, thin CME seen to the SSE in all coronagraphs. The source appears to be a small filament eruption from AR 3922 (S16W24), best observed in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-12-14T01:28Z, which then deflects sharply southward after erupting. This eruption is notably close to the CME start time, but it is the best candidate and the filament shape in GOES SUVI aligns visually with the coronagraph signature.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. CME starts smaller than a 10 HW, expanding wider further into the FOV, and is notably deflected southward from the source region as corroborated in GOES SUVI.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW only in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, STEREO COR2A was available at this time but this CME isn't observed there. The source is likely near/south of Active Region 3916 decayed to a plage, with a narrow filament ejecta observed in GOES SUVI 304 around S20W70 starting around 2024-12-14T02:36Z. The CME precedes a similarly shaped, brighter and more distinct 2024-12-14T05:36Z CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis with one coronagraph (SOHO) based on the location of the source (ejecta from former Active Region 3916).
SOHO LASCO C2/C3-only plane of sky due to the lack of CME observation in STEREO COR2A at this time for triangulation.

note: Thin minor jet only seen in SOHO LASCO imagery but not in STEREO A COR2. No source for this CME has been found on the disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: This CME is only seen in SOHO imagery and its source has not been found on the Earth-facing disk, so only plane-of-sky measurement is possible.

note: Faint CME likely associated with minor flare and filament eruption seen around ~2024-12-14T05:12 near/south of Active Region 3916 decayed to a plage (~S15W69) or alternatively a less certain eruption of very long filament along longitude ~S25 centered around 35-40 deg longitude, maybe seen erupting in SUVI 304/284 (but it is more likely that the matter fell back). The CME is preceded by a similarly shaped even fainter 2024-12-14T04:00Z CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and giving preference to the minor eruption in AR 3916 as the source. However, the fit with the longitude of AR 3916 doesn't work, so there seems to be a deflection.

note: A faint northern CME with the source an eruption starting around 2024-12-14T09:20Z in the NW quadrant centered ~(N34W60), as seen in SUVI 195/304/284, with narrow ejecta in 304 to the N and dimming/minor post eruptive arcades in 195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very approximate/uncertain analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs (SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2) and since the longitude of the source eruption does not produce a good fit. The range of possible longitudes and latitudes is very high, with longitudes ranging from 30 to 50 deg.

note: No source has been found for this very slow CME with multiple fronts.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis  based on the best fit in two coronagraphs.

note: The source of this faint CME with a fuzzy front could be a super minor filament off or close to the SW limb seen in SUVI 304 around 2024-12-14T21:44.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on a fit with two coronagraphs, but the front is fuzzy especially in STEREO A.

note: Narrowish CME in the southwest. Its source could be the southwestern eruption/ejecta from AR 3916 (S15W81) seen in SUVI 304 at 2024-12-14T23:39Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximate analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs and on the location of the source (erupting filament).

note: Fast CME to the west, the beginning of which is covered by a data gap in SOHO. Its source was hard to identify since there are multiple eruption close to SW limb near this time, as well as a faint movement of field lines likely beyond the W limb in SUVI 171/195 at 2024-12-15T00:50Z. In EUVI A 195 near the west limb (in STEREO) there are post-eruptive arcades seen at ~2024-12-15T01:05Z after the long data gap. The very approximate location of this  source in STEREO A is ~110 degrees.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit in two coronagraphs and confirmed by one possible source (in STEREO EUV imagery).

note: Bright, 3-part CME visible to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery starting around 2024-12-15T01:25Z. The source of this CME is a long filament stretched from W10 to W60 along the S25 latitude that erupts starting around 2024-12-14T21:50Z with full lift off by 2024-12-14T23:50Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Associated moving/opening field lines are visible along the SW in GOES SUVI 284. Sympathetic eruption appears to occur around/within AR 13924 which is visible as brightening in GOES SUVI 195. Additionally, post-eruptive arcades are visible in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery and potential source location.

note: Faint partial halo CME first seen to the SE in STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-12-15T04:23Z, as well as faintly in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 in later frames. This CME overlaps with previous CME: 2024-12-15T01:25Z, making the front difficult to track in SOHO LASCO. The source of this event appears to be an area of dimming centered near AR 3924 (S19W18) as seen GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in STEREO A COR2. Measurements with similar parameters using possible front seen in SOHO LASCO C3 were also made, but with lower confidence.

note: Faint CME overlapping a bright streamer to the W/SW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a C-class flare and associated filament ejecta from decayed AR 13916 (S15W85) visible in GOES SUVI 304, 284, 131, and STEREO A EUVI 304 starting around 2024-12-15T09:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of features in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The CME has a messy front so some uncertainty may be present with parameters.

note: Bright CME with core visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap beginning at 15/11:38Z in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this CME. The CME has a faint halo shock visible in later frames. The source appears to be far sided with wide moving/opening field lines to the SE in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-15T14:19Z. A portion of the front appears to be moving faster than the rest of the CME which may be indicative of an overlapping CME. However, due to limited stereoscopic viewpoints and lack of a separately identifiable source, this feature was excluded in the measurement of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on probable far sided source and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3
SHOCK measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C3

note: Narrow jet-like CME first seen in the SSE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-15T20:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3. A majority of this event is obscured by a data gap in STEREO A COR2A lasting from from 15/11:38Z to 16/00:23Z. There is no clear source seen for this CME as it is likely far sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and one frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Narrow CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-15T20:24Z as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. There is limited COR2A imagery for this event due to a data gap from 15/11:38Z to 16/00:23Z. There is no clear source seen for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to wide range of fits (approx. 50 to 110) and lack of reliable COR2A imagery to triangulate.

note: Faint CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-15T20:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 15/11:38Z to 16/00:23Z. The source of this event appears to be an area of field line movement seen along the SE limb (approx. S15E90) as seen in GOES SUVI 195 and 284

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to range of fits (approx. -80 to -110) and source near the East limb and lack of STEREO A COR2 imagery to triangulate

note: Faint CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. There is not a clear source candidate for this CME. Field line movement was visible on the west limb in GOES SUVI 195, but no clear source on the disk could be found. This CME may originate on/beyond the west limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Very narrow jet CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery but not observed in STEREO A COR2. Possibly associated with a minor eruption located near the vicinity of AR 3926 (S20E55), but the source of the eruption is unclear, as the EUV signature doesn't show a definite jet signature.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft plane of sky measurement (SOHO) with upper bound on half-width.

note: Minor and relatively faint CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and not seen well in STEREO A COR2 data. Likely associated with moving field lines from an active region rotating onto the Earth-facing disk at perhaps a longitude between -80 and -90 degrees, as seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft leading edge measurement using an approximate longitude as determined from EUV imagery; there is probably a 10 to 15 degree uncertainty in longitude.

note: Minor, relatively slow CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 along a minor streamer. Associated with a minor eruption near N32E80 as evidenced by opening field lines seen best in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft measurement based on visual inspection of source location in EUV imagery.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is an eruption starting at 2024-12-17T03:52Z in GOES SUVI 304 around S10E80. Opening field lines are also visible in GOES SUVI 171/195/284. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is a filament eruption that appears to have a footpoint located at approximately S40E40 and a footpoint that wraps beyond the east limb as seen in available GOES SUVI imagery. Filament liftoff is seen starting at 2024-12-17T06:40Z in GOES SUVI 304. Dimming and opening field lines are also visible in GOES SUVI 195 and opening field lines are seen in GOES SUVI 284. The eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUV 195 and 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME faintly visible to the southwest in STEREO A COR2. This CME not was clearly seen in any available SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source was also not found. The CME fades away after a few frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint CME visible to the east in SOHO LACSO C2/C3, not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-12-17T11:36Z. The source is not clearly visible, and it may be farsided. Field line movement may be seen near the limb in GOES SUVI 171/195/284 from approximately 2024-12-17T07:00Z to 13:00Z, but no clear eruption is seen and no source location can be determined.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Fast, farsided halo CME in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not seen in STEREO A COR2 in real time due to a data gap starting at 2024-12-17T11:38Z. Faint, wide field line movement is seen on the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-12-17T15:59Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit with SOHO LASCO C3 imagery in SWPC_CAT. No STEREO A COR2 imagery was available for a measurement. This measurement primarily tracks the fainter shock feature to the south of the halo, but the leading edge of the bulk is traveling with the shock and the leading edge is indistinguishable from the shock.

note: CME first visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-18T06:36Z. Also visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C3 and in white light only to the NW in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an eruption from south of AR 3920 (N12W90) starting around 2024-12-18T05:56Z in GOES SUVI 284. Another source possibility is a spot of activity a few degrees north (~N16W85) that also "erupted" around 2024-12-18T05:36Z. Both source candidates are bright in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT. This CME is visible in STEREO A COR2 only in white light imagery.

note: CME first visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-18T10:00Z. Also visible to the E in SOHO LASCO C3. The majority of this CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:38Z. The source of this CME is most likely some moving field lines on or just behind the E limb beginning around 2024-12-18T07:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT. Most of the propagation of this CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:38Z.

note: CME first visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-18T11:12Z. Also visible to the NW for a couple frames in SOHO LASCO C3 but is very faint. CME is mostly covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:38Z. The source of this CME is most likely some minor brightening and general, continuous activity best seen in GOES SUVI 304 from AR 3920 in the NW for a few hours prior to and after the CME first emerges into SOHO LASCO C2, but there is no clearly definitive source candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-18T12:48Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:38Z. A possible source of this CME is some very minor activity to the north of AR 3924 at approximately S06W70 best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about 2024-12-18T10:31Z. It is also possible that the source of this CME is far-sided as there is not a definitive source candidate on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT. This CME is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:38Z.

note: Faint loop CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Source is very likely the eruption of a small filament starting around 2024-12-18T14:49Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304, which was seen on the disk spanning approx. S05W70 to S22W65, near Active Region 3924 (S20W65). Part of this CME is not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between C2/C3 and COR2A, as well as source location seen in EUV imagery. Part of this CME is not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-12-18T11:38Z to 2024-12-18T16:36Z.

note: CME first visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-18T18:24Z. Also visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. There is no definitive source candidate on the Earth-facing disk, so this CME is likely far-sided. A far-sided source is consistent with measurements.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 running difference imagery.

note: Faint "puffy" CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. This CME is not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-12-18T18:53Z to 2024-12-19T01:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky analysis using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the NE is SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-19T01:25Z. Also seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME is very faint in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is likely a large rising loop of field lines seen from beyond the NE limb in GOES SUVI 284, first noticeable starting at 2024-12-19T00:39Z. There is some minor influence seen in the NE quadrant of the Earth-facing disk, but this eruption appears much more likely to be far-sided. A far-sided source is also consistent with measurements.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is some uncertainty about the measurement and triangulation of this CME because it is very faint in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Narrow, jet-like CME first seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-19T03:48Z that is easier to see in running difference imagery. This CME does not make it beyond the field-of-view of SOHO LASCO C2 and is not visible in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is likely a small amount of activity and brightening starting about 2024-12-19T01:45Z best seen in GOES SUVI 304 on the W limb at about N10. This is just to the SW of AR 3920 which was at about N22W83 at the time of eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-12-19T14:00Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is a filament eruption from on or beyond the SW limb. The prominence material can be seen lifting off the SW limb in both GOES SUVI 284 and 304 starting about 2024-12-19T12:53Z. This filament eruption is overtaken by a far-sided halo CME with start time 2024-12-19T17:53Z in STEREO A COR2. This CME is only discernible by itself in SOHO LASCO C2 and a couple of frames in SOHO LASCO C3. The majority of the CME is obscured by and blends in with the far-sided halo later in its propagation into the fields-of-view of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: Halo CME first seen in STEREO A COR2 at 2024-12-19T17:53Z. The bulk of the CME is to the SW. This CME is also seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This start time was chosen based on when the CME was first seen in available imagery at the time of analysis, but the actual start time is earlier. The source of this CME is most likely far-sided. There are no good source candidates on the Earth-facing disk, and coronal signatures from beyond the SW limb suggest a far-sided source.  In GOES SUVI 284, there is some flickering in the farthest out field lines over the SW limb across most of the SW quadrant first seen at about 2024-12-19T16:19Z. There is also some very faint ejecta seen from beyond the SW limb in GOES SUVI 304 starting about 2024-12-19T16:21Z. Measurements are consistent with a far-sided source. This CME also overlaps with a prior filament eruption to the SW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME seen to the east in STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The start of the CME is not seen in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a data gap from 2024-12-19T21:36Z to 2024-12-20T02:00Z. There is not a clear source on the disk, but there is some activity seen as moving field lines on the east limb leading up to the CME, around latitude S10, starting at 2024-12-19T22:27Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location just beyond the east limb as well as the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: Narrow jet seen to the WSW in C2/C3/COR2A, potentially associated with a visible filament eruption seen near 2024-12-20T22:30Z seen in the southwest portion of the disk. Triangulation of this event in measurement software suggests it may be potentially associated with one of two filament eruptions occurring near simultaneously seen best in GOES SUVI 304, one near the southern polar crown and one near about S40W35, both filament eruptions having notable southern deflection. Based on the measurement, the filament near S40W35 seems to be better the source candidate.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge with an upper bound on half-width.

note: CME with trianglular/trapezoidal shaped leading edge seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO and farther to the west in STEREO A; was initially theorized to be associated with front-sided filament eruptions on the Earth facing disk in the southwest limb around 2024-12-19T22:00Z, however, triangulation suggests that this eruption is far-sided. Possibly associated with a far-sided eruption corresponding starting around 01:00Z that erupts distinctly different than the filament eruption seen in GOES 304 seen best in GOES 93/171/284 composite imagery off the southern limb and propagating to the southwest.

cmeAnalyses.note: Low confidence measurement using two spacecraft triangulation to determine the source longitude.

note: Faint CME with a fuzzy front seen mostly in STEREO A COR2, with SOHO imagery very poor quality at the time of this event. No source has been found for this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bc of the poor quality of SOHO imagery at the time only STEREO A coronagraph imagery is available and therefore only POS analysis is definitive.

note: CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. In real time, the CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 after a data gap from 2024-12-20T11:18Z to 2024-12-20T15:06Z. The source is likely an eruption from AR 3932 (approx, S18E70) in the southeast, associated with a C9.4-class flare starting at 2024-12-20T10:03Z. The flare and brightening are best seen in GOES SUVI 131, and the eruption is also seen with an ejecta of material and field line movement in GOES SUVI 195/284. The eruption is also visible on the SE limb in STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Narrow CME to the southwest with a possible source a very minor movement/opening of field lines behind the southwest limb around 2024-12-20T21:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint narrow CME/outflow with a fuzzy front to the south after a data gap, with no clear source found on disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: No clear front found in STEREO A coronagraph for this event, so only POS analysis is definitive.

note: Narrow faint CME to the E. A minor eruption off the southeast limb seen in SUVI 195 around 2024-12-20T21:05Z with movement/opening of field lines seen in SUVI 284 starting 21:15Z was explored as a source, however the fit with two coronagraphs doesn't support the longitude close to -90 deg.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: CME visible to the NNE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely an eruption centered around N20E10 starting around 2024-12-20T21:27Z with dimming observed in GOES SUVI 195. Post-eruptive arcades are seen in SDO AIA 284/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Narrow CME visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2, directly following CME: 2024-12-21T21:12Z in the field of view of the coronagraphs. The potential source is near or beyond the west limb as seen in SDO AIA and STEREO A EUV imagery. In GOES SUVI 304, ejecta can be seen departing on the limb starting at 2024-12-20T23:00Z. Moving/opening field lines are also visible in GOES SUVI 195/284 and STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT as well as the potential source location.

note: CME visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is likely on the far side, and rapidly opening field lines are visible beyond the NE limb in GOES SUVI 195/284 starting at 2024-12-21T09:20Z. Field line movement is also faintly visible in STEREO A EUV 195 imagery. The CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2024-12-21T11:39Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source location is near the west limb as seen from GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUV imagery. Opening field lines can be seen in GOES SUVI 284 at 2024-12-21T11:19Z. This can also be faintly seen in STEREO A EUV imagery. Brightening and an ejecta of material can be seen on the west limb in GOES SUVI 304, around S20, possibly near AR 3924, which rotated off of the Earth-facing disk on 2024-12-21.

cmeAnalyses.note: SHOCK measurement of the CME based on the source location using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery.
Measurement of the leading edge of the bulk of the CME based on potential source location. STEREO A COR2 imagery was not available for this measurement.

note: CME visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and in STEREO A COR2 along a streamer prior to a data gap starting at 2024-12-21T11:39Z. The start time is likely earlier, as part of this CME was visible in the coronagraphs as early as 2024-12-21T06:00Z, but did not start picking up speed and moving through the coronagraphs until around 2024-12-21T13:25Z. The source is unclear, and it is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME and possible shock first seen in the SSW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-21T17:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-12-21T11:39Z to 2024-12-21T22:09Z. There is no clear source seen on the disk for this event. A small amount of likely far sided material can be seen leaving the disk along the SSW limb in GOES SUVI 304 which may be a possible source.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK POS measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. This CME had no clear source and no COR2A imagery for triangulation.
SHOCK POS measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. This CME had no clear source and no COR2A imagery for triangulation.

note: Bright loop CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-21T20:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2024-12-21T11:39Z. The source of this CME is a filament eruption seen just beyond the NE limb in GOES SUVI 304, along with wide opening field lines seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on best fit in SOHGO LASCO C2/C3 and longitude precedent set by a series of similar CMEs triangulated between longitudes -120 and -130 degrees likely indicating a complex active region near this longitude.
SHOCK measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and approximate source location of the bulk measurement.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery for a few frames before becoming diffuse to track the leading edge. The source is likely related to a C9.5 flare from Active Region 13932 (S18E49) peaking at 2024-12-21T23:05Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, as well as ejecta launched from the same region seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly as this event is too faint to be observed in STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames. The source is a likely related to a filament eruption seen along or just beyond the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 304 imagery. The filament arose slowly, but did not begin to lift off until ~2024-12-21T21:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and limited STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is difficult to observe in STEREO A COR2 due to an ongoing campaign. The source is likely an eruption near Active Region 13932 (S20E51) starting around 2024-12-21T23:25Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. The measured parameters may vary slightly due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is faint but visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no clear source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the uncertain/far-sided source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to faint field line movement visible beyond the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 171 and 195 imagery starting around 2024-12-22T03:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and may be related to a faint opening of field lines visible beyond the eastern limb in GOES SUVI 171 and 195 imagery starting around 2024-12-22T06:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: CME seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source for this CME is uncertain and not observed in available GOES SUVI imagery, despite its bright coronagraph signature, indicating a likely far-sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 Plane-Of-Sky given the uncertain, likely far-sided source and lack of STEREO COR2A imagery at this time to triangulate the source longitude.

note: CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The source for this CME is uncertain and not observed in available GOES SUVI imagery, indicating a likely far-sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 Plane-Of-Sky given the uncertain, likely far-sided source and lack of STEREO COR2A imagery at this time to triangulate the source longitude. Measurement is slightly wider than the front itself, as the CME travels nearly due west but the shape of the front forces swpc_cat too far south to track the leading edge if fully tightened around the brightest CME bulk.

note: Faint loop CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-22T21:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2024-12-23T11:09Z to 2024-12-23T01:09Z and limited STEREO A data due to an ongoing campaign. The source of this CME is an M1.1 flare from AR 3932 (S16E37) as seen in GOES SUVI 131. Field line opening is also visible in GOES SUVI 195 and 284, along with a region of dimming to the SW of the region in GOES SUVI 195, suggesting a Southwestern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and one two frames of STEREO COR2A following a data gap resuming at 2024-12-23T01:09Z. The source for this CME is uncertain and not observed in available GOES SUVI imagery, indicating a likely far-sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO C2/C3 Plane-Of-Sky given the uncertain, likely far-sided source and lack of usable STEREO COR2A imagery at this time to triangulate the source longitude.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, but is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk that clearly align with this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided/uncertain source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided and related to an opening of field lines visible slightly beyond the western limb in GOES SUVI 171 and 284 imagery starting around 2024-12-23T06:00Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the south in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is not observed in STEREO A COR2 due to limited imagery from an ongoing campaign. There is an overlapping CME which appears directed towards the southwest starting around 2024-12-23T11:48Z which may be associated with far-sided activity and is separate from this event. The source is likely associated with the M8.9 flare and subsequent eruption from Active Region 13932 (S18E30) starting around 2024-12-23T11:10Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. Ejected material is observed best in GOES SUVI 304 imagery which appears to deflect south of the eruption site. Additionally, dimming is observed south/southwest of the eruption site, centered near S35E20 in GOES SUVI 195 imagery around 2024-12-23T11:15Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based loosely on the source location, taking into account the observed southern deflection of the eruption with respect to the on-disk source location. There is no stereoscopic viewpoint available for this event due to an ongoing campaign in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The measured parameters may vary as a result.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is observable for one frame in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to an ongoing campaign. The source is likely far-sided and may be associated with faint field line movement visible beyond the western limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2024-12-23T11:30Z. Additionally, this event appears to overlap with CME: 2024-12-23T11:36Z, but is not likely associated with any front-sided sources.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 imagery and one frame of STEREO A COR2 imagery. Due to an ongoing STEREO A campaign limiting the amount of usable imagery, and the far-sided source, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the S/SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery for this event. This CME deflects to the south as it moves out in the field of view. The source appears to be beyond the SW limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2024-12-23T19:39Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery.

note: Faint, relatively slow CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2, associated with small dimming signature on the Earth-facing disk near AR13932 to south starting around 2024-12-23T20:39Z best seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the CME using one spacecraft before the diffuse front disappears in LASCO C2.

note: Faint CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO associated with an M4.7-class flare near AR13932 (S15E20) and characterized by a broad area of moving field lines seen best in GOES SUVI 284 and brightening in GOES 304/171, the leading edge disappears in SOHO LASCO C2 before it reaches the end of the field of view. Not seen well in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap/campaign.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2 and EUV signatures to approximate the source latitude and longitude.

note: CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 with faint shock/leading edge seen farther to due east, likely associated with far-sided activity as evidenced by a prominence eruption seen best in GOES SUVI 304 behind the southeast limb around 2024-12-24T04:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft plane of sky measurement due to a STEREO A campaign.

note: This CME is visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. STEREO A is in campaign mode during this event with limited to no imagery. The source is an eruption visible to the southwest near S15W70, just east of AR13930 starting around 2024-12-24T05:03Z. There is associated filament ejecta best seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on potential source location. Longitude may vary by +/- 10 degrees. There is a higher degree of uncertainty due to limited stereoscopic viewpoints of this CME.

note: Faint, "puff"-like CME first seen to the WSW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-24T08:24Z. Also seen to the WSW in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME is best seen in running difference imagery. STEREO A is in campaign mode during this event with limited to no imagery. There is no good source candidate for this CME on the Earth-facing disk, so the source is most likely far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Relatively wide, bright CME in SOHO LASCO running difference imagery seen to the southeast and much fainter in white light imagery, likely associated with an M4.1-flare from AR13932 (S17E17) with an associated eruption. In addition to the flare seen in GOES 131 imagery, a significant looking eruption in GOES 284 with a large magnetic loop and dimming signature around 2024-12-24T08:30Z is observed near the vicinity of the active region.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft leading edge measurement using the known source to approximate the latitude/longitude as STEREO A imagery is not usable due to a campaign.

note: CME first visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-24T20:24Z. CME also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and in one frame from STEREO A COR2, which is currently in campaign mode. The source of this CME is likely associated with an M1.0 flare peaking at 20:28Z from AR 3930. The flare and some preceding moving field lines on the SE limb are best seen in GOES SUVI 284 and GOES SUVI 304. There is significant southward deflection. This CME is immediately followed by a slower, more southern CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement of the CME out to 18 solar radii using SOHO LASCO C3 and knowledge of the source location using EUV imagery.

note: Relatively faint and very wide CME seen to the south and southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 during an observing campaign; the CME is associated with an M4.9-class flare and resulting eruption from the vicinity of AR 13932 seen near S18E10 with predominantly southward directionality around 2024-12-25T04:48Z in GOES SUVI 304, 284, 131, and 171. The signature in GOES SUVI 284 is characterized by a destabilizing arcade south of the active region and broad dimming signature. Associated with a type II radio burst with observed shock speed of 1064 km/s.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft leading edge measurement which results in speeds close to the observed type II shock speed but decreased in velocity with farther frames, potentially due to deacceleration.

note: CME comprised of two parts seen to the east and southeast in SOHO LASCO imagery and to the south/southwest in STEREO A COR2 imagery; the bulk appears to be directed mainly to the east whereas the fainter shock is seen to the southeast; potentially the CME is made up of two separate eruptions that occur near simultaneously. This measurement generally focuses on the faster, southeastern component as observed from SOHO LASCO. Moving field lines seen off the southeastern limb in GOES SUVI 284 suggest this eruption is far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge associated with the fainter and faster portion directed more southeast as viewed from SOHO LASCO using triangulation with STEREO Ahead.

note: Loop CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and south in STEREO A COR2 following the 2024-12-25T08:12Z CME; likely associated with far-sided activity as determined from triangulation.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge using two spacecraft.

note: CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-25T16:36Z. Also seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME is covered by a data gap is STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-25T13:38Z to 2024-12-25T21:53Z. The source of this CME is most likely ejecta from beyond the SE limb. The ejected material is best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting about 2024-12-25T16:20Z. Some field lines opening beyond the SE limb are best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting abut 2024-12-25T16:07Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Slowly developing loop seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery during a STEREO A data gap. Characterized by a dimming (GOES SUVI 284) and destabilization near AR 13934 (N15E02) with northeastward deflection, a surge in GOES SUVI 304, and change in magnetic field structure with rising structure in GOES SUVI 195/171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary measurement with early frames of the CME using one spacecraft and knowledge of the source location seen in EUV imagery. Uncertainty in latitude about +15/-5 degrees.

note: CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-25T21:12Z. The actual start time will be a bit earlier; the CME is first visible in white light imagery after a short gap in SOHO LASCO data from 2024-12-25T20:36Z to 2024-12-25T21:12Z. CME is also visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3. The CME maybe be visible for one or two frames in STEREO A COR2 after a data gap from 2024-12-25T13:38Z to 2024-12-25T21:53Z. The source of this CME is most likely ejecta from beyond the SE limb. The ejected material is best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting about 2024-12-25T20:48Z. Some field lines opening beyond the SE limb are best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting abut 2024-12-25T20:07Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-26T01:25Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is flaring from AR 3936 (N13E11) that contributed to an M3.1 flare peaking at 2024-12-26T00:30Z. This flaring activity is seen clearly in GOES SUVI 131 and 094 along with field line movement/brightening exhibiting a strong Northeastern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and  best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is faint, but visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far sided as there is no clear source signatures seen on the Earth facing disk. Additionally, this CME appears to be quickly overtaken by CME: 2024-12-26T04:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided/uncertain source location and faintness in STEREO A COR2 imagery, which is difficult to measure reliably.

note: CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-26T04:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is likely far sided as there is no clear source seen on the Earth facing disk, and triangulating fits suggest an origin beyond the SW limb. This CME appears to overtake earlier CME: 2024-12-26T03:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Bright CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-26T05:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen beyond the East limb (approx. S02E100 visually) by GOES SUVI 304 beginning at approximately 26/03:40Z, along with field line movement seen by GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2024-12-26T15:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 26/15:23Z. The source of this event is an eruption seen beginning at approx. 26/13:48Z located at approx. S05E85 as seen in GOES SUVI 304. Subsequent field line opening is also visible in GOES SUVI 185 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: This CME is faintly visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery during this event. The source of this CME is a filament eruption visible to the east in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2024-12-26T17:00Z between S00E70 and S10E80.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters are based on apparent source location and best fit of features using SOHO LASCO imagery. There is not STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this event due to a data gap.

note: This CME is seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR imagery during this event. The source appears to be a C9.6 flare peaking at 2024-12-26T18:45Z from a currently unnumbered active region near S05E73 based on GOES SUVI 131 imagery. This CME overlaps and overtakes the CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2024-12-26T17:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using the source for longitude. There is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this event due to a data gap.

note: This CME is seen as a faint front to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery, not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The potential source is a filament eruption near AR 13938 starting around 2024-12-26T18:40Z. The filament stretches between -30 and -45 degrees longitude and 20 to 30 degrees north in latitude as seen in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on fit with the visible front and the potential source location. The half-width may vary due to uncertain left side boundary of CME front. Uncertainty is high due to no stereoscopic viewpoints of this CME.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to a fast opening of field lines observed beyond the southeast limb in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284 imagery starting around 2024-12-27T01:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The CME has an irregularly-shaped front which is difficult to measure, and a wider half-width was used to accommodate the leading edge shape.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to a faint opening of field lines observed beyond the southeast limb in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284 imagery starting around 2024-12-27T04:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption centered near S05E65 seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 304 imagery starting around 2024-12-27T05:50Z. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the eruption site in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 imagery around this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and to the south in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no relevant source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As the source is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: Super faint narrow outflow to the SE. The source could be a narrow ejecta in GOES SUVI 304 at 21Z and opening/movement of field lines behind the SE limb seen in SUVI 284 around 20:59Z (but this eruption could be the source of the 22:00Z or 22:12 CME alternatively).

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Narrow faint outflow to the SSE - one in a group of three narrow CMEs. The source could be a narrow ejecta in SUVI 304 at 21Z and opening/movement of field lines behind the SE limb seen in SUVI 284 around 20:59Z, although this source could be behind two other closely following CMEs.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Narrow faint outflow to the SE. The source could be a narrow ejecta in SUVI 304 at 21Z and opening/movement of field lines behind the SE limb seen in SUVI 284 around 20:59Z - but this eruption could alternatively be the source of the 22:00Z CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit in two coronagraphs.

note: Fast, thin CME seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The likely source for this CME is only seen in STEREO A EUVI imagery, starting at 2024-12-28T02:24Z in EUVI 195 and T02:45Z in EUVI 304, as a small filament eruption near the limb as observed from STEREO A. STEREO A is 28.7 degrees off of SOHO at this eruption time, so this source is likely ranged W100-120.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, noting the CME deflecting southward from the source based on how it travels through the coronagraphs, complicating swpc_cat's tracking of the front direction. However, this fit is close to the estimated source as observed in STEREO EUVI imagery, with visual triangulating getting worse if you go further beyond W95.

note: Faint CME with the front only clearly seen in COR2A. The start is likely much earlier but it is covered in COR2A by a STEREO data gap. No clear source of it has been found, although there is constant minor activity in AR 3938 in the morning.

cmeAnalyses.note: Since the corresponding front has not been found in SOHO and no clear source has been found only POS measurement is definitive.

note: Very narrow and faint outflow/jet preceded by a super faint wider front. The source might be minor flaring and narrow ejecta from AR 3938 (N19E22) seen in SUVI 304 ~2024-12-28T05:28Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain analysis of the faint wider front (not the brighter narrow one), based on the fit of faint fronts in two coronagraphs and on the assumption that the source is Active Region 3938.

note: Faint CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, notably more faint in COR2A and barely visible in COR2A running difference imagery. The source for this CME is uncertain, as it appears to form early in the LASCO C2 FOV rather than moving out from the occulting disk, but there are two potential candidates if it does start on-disk. A small filament eruption from AR 3933 (~S07W55) starting at 2024-12-28T07:56Z in GOES SUVI 195/304 fits the measured longitude well but not latitude, and there is also field line movement beginning on the NW limb (~N18) around 2024-12-28T08:08Z in GOES SUVI 195 that doesn't fit longitude but is a more northward latitude. Both sources time well but are off on other parameters, AR 3933 is a closer match so it has been analyzed as the most likely.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, noting the CME is much fainter in COR2A running difference than COR2A white light. Using the white light imagery as a reference, the CME was matched to the running difference within swpc_cat, allowing a good confidence triangualtion around W65.

note: Faint CME seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The CME front is initially quite faint in early C2, almost appearing to manifest in the FOV rather than emerging from the occulting disk, but it is much better viewed in C3 and COR2A. No source was observed in GOES SUVI imagery, but it triangulated well far-sided and bears resemblence to other SE fronts such as CME: 2024-12-27T22:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, finding a good far-sided high southern latitude fit despite the lack of an observed source in GOES SUVI imagery.

note: Bright CME to the NE seen only in SOHO and not seen in STEREO A COR2 because of a data gap. No clear source was found for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Since the CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 b/c of a data gap and no source has been found for it only POS measurement is definitive.

note: Bright CME seen only in SOHO LASCO imagery and not seen in STEREO A COR2 because of a data gap.
