Its source might be the significant eruption in AR 13939 (S17E35) that starts as early as ~2024-12-28T18:06Z, although the main eruption seems to happen AFTER the start of this CME, closer to ~2024-12-28T19:30Z, with the dimming and post-eruptive arcades seen in GOES SUVI 195/304/171/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: A very uncertain one-coronagraph (SOHO) analysis based on the assumption that the source is the eruption in Active Region 3939.
Initial plane-of-sky analysis of this CME.

note: This CME is visible to the east in STEREO A COR2 imagery and is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The start time is likely earlier than stated as there is a large data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2024-12-28T15:23Z-22:23Z, after which the CME is visible well into the STEREO A COR2 field of view. The source location is unknown, and may be far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -118 degrees due to the uncertain source location.

note: CME seen to the south in SOHO LASCO imagery faintly in white light imagery and southeast in STEREO A COR2 imagery; seems to be associated with a relatively minor eruption with southern deflection just west of AR 3938 (N20W01) near central meridian but with lower confidence potentially associated with AR 3939 (S18E33) as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, and best in 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 to triangulate the source, which suggests higher confidence in the northern hemispheric eruption as opposed to AR 3939 in the southeast.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 and as a partial halo directed towards the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely related to an eruption and subsequent M2.0 flare from Active Region 13939 (S17E30) starting around 2024-12-29T04:20Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. A subsequent dimming is observed around the eruption site in GOES SUVI 195 imagery at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the brighter, bulk portion of this event based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
Measurement of the faint, outermost SHOCK feature based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk which fit this event between coronagraphs.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely related to an eruption visible just on the southeast limb starting around 2024-12-29T11:00Z seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible over the southeast limb at this time as well, as seen in GOES SUVI 171, 193, and 284 imagery,

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location.

note: Jet CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A data gap; associated with an unknown source, potentially far-sided.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO LASCO plane of sky measurement of the leading edge.

note: Minor CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, associated with a minor filament erupting near N40W55 seen best in GOES SUVI 304/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement of the CME using SOHO C2; the leading edge becomes very diffuse with time.

note: Partial halo seen as a faint leading edge without much overflowing material behind the leading edge, seen to the south and southeast in SOHO LASCO and east-southeast in STEREO A COR2. Likely associated with an eruption from AR3939 near S18E15 seen as quickly breaking field lines near the active region seen best in GOES SUVI 131, 195, 284, 304. The attached WSA-Enlil+Cone simulation should not be interpreted as a forecast and is likely to overestimate geomagnetic impacts at Earth given that the measurement represents the faint shock associated with the CME, which does not contain much observed material behind the leading edge.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the faint shock front using triangulation between STEREO A and SOHO; simulation is likely to overestimate geomagnetic impacts at Earth given there is not much observed material behind the leading edge.

note: A faint very slowly developing partial halo CME to the southwest, with filamentary structures seen in coronagraph and with multiple consecutive fronts. There is activity on/close to the SW limb early in the morning (opening/movement of field lines close to the limb and some dimming/brightening), but it is happening after 01:30Z and so is unlikely to be the source of this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on fit with two coronagraphs (since no clear source was found on disk).

note: CME seen in the northwest in both coronagraph. It has a wider, likely shock, front in addition to a narrower bulk. Its likely source is the X1.5 flare from AR 3936 (N13W46) which was associated with the eruption seen in GOES SUVI 195/284 as rising post eruptive arcades and some dimming. There are also moving of field lines closer to the northwest limb seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis is based on the fit with two coronagraphs but also incorporates the location of the likely source of this CME, the flare.

note: Very faint CME first seen in the SE by STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2024-12-30T10:53Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C2 in later frames. This CME fades before exiting the field-of-view in SOHO LASCO C2 and is therefore not visible in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this event is an eruption seen near AR 3939 (S17E15) with post-eruptive arcades and dimming  seen in SUVI 195/284 after 08:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2. This event is not being simulated as it fades after a few frames in SOHO LASCO C2.

note: CME first seen to the WNW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2024-12-31T00:12Z. Also visible to the WNW in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME might be very faintly visible STEREO A COR2 for two frames, but it is not definitively this CME. A possible source candidate is some minor brightening and activity from AR 3936 starting about 21:48Z visible in all GOES SUVI wavelengths, but measurement does not closely match this source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Thin, fast CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source is field line movement and a small post eruptive arcade observed just inside the the NW limb (~N15W89) starting around 2024-12-31T12:56Z in GOES SUVI 171/195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. This front appears to be slightly less than a halfwidth of 10, and also triangulated slightly further on-disk than the source observed in GOES SUVI imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a dimming region centered near S25E40 starting around 2024-12-31T13:15Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171 and imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and is not observed STEREO COR2A due to a data gap starting at 2024-12-31T15:38Z. The source may be related to field line movement on the northwest limb (~N15) starting around 2024-12-31T16:24Z in GOES SUVI 171/195/284 followed by a small post eruptive arcade.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees. A triangulated measurement was not available due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event.

note: Faint CME with a fuzzy front (multiple fronts) to the SW. A possible considered source could be a significant eruption near AR 3939 (S17W15) starting around 2025-01-01T00:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. An alternative source is the movement of field lines close to/on the SW limb seen in SUVI 195 after 2025-01-01T01:30Z, possibly from Active Region 3932 (S15W77).

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. While in SOHO the fuzzy front can be traced over multiple timestamps, in STEREO A COR2 a super faint front to the SW is seen only in two timestamps.

Measurement based on the potential source location of S17W15. At the time of the analysis, the source eruption from S15W77 was determined to be the more likely candidate for this CME, and the CME was simulated based on those parameters.

note: Faint CME obscured by a pylon in SOHO LASCO C3 and not seen in STEREO A COR2 bc of a large data gap. The source could be minor activity from AR 3936 (N13W70) around 01Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very uncertain one-coronagraph analysis with SOHO coronagraph only based on the assumption that minor activity in Active Region 3936 is the source of this CME.

note: Faint fast jet to the NW with the possible source a very minor eruption likely from AR 3934 (N13W81) near NW limb at 2024-12-31T23:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on a fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME to the SSW, not seen in STEREO A because of a data gap from 2025-01-01T04:38Z to 2025-01-02T01:23Z. No clear source found in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME to the NW in SOHO, fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. Two potential sources are activity from from AR 3936 starting about 2025-01-01T10:36Z, a minor filament eruption from AR 3934 on the NW limb.

Faint CME first seen in the NE beginning at 2025-01-02T02:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 or SOHO LASCO C3 due to faintness. The source of this event is an area of brightening and field line movement seen along the NE limb (approx. N10E90) as seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. This CME fit with longitudes between -85 and -110.

note: Narrow CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-02T03:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line movement tracing down to an unnumbered region located at approximately N20E60 as seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-02T03:36Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames before a data gap begins at 2025-01-02T04:38Z. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to faintness. The source of this event may be some minor field line movement seen along the NW limb in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely related to the eruption from Active Region 13939 (S20W30) starting around 2025-01-02T14:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195 and 284 imagery. Dimming is also observed around this time in GOES SUVI 195 imagery. This event overlaps with CME: 2025-01-02T15:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as this measurement does not take into account possible deflection from the source.

SHOCK measurement of the faint, outermost feature based on the source location. This measurement may vary as there is no STEREO A COR2 imagery to confirm the measured parameters. This measurement does not take into account possible deflection from the source location.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source is likely related to the eruption from Active Region 13939 (S20W30) starting around 2025-01-02T14:30Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195 and 284 imagery. Dimming is also observed around this time in GOES SUVI 195 imagery. This event overlaps with CME: 2025-01-02T15:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as this measurement does not take into account possible deflection from the source.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The source is likely related to an M1.1 flare and eruption observed from Active Region 13939 (S10W30) starting around 2025-01-02T17:40Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 294, 304 imagery. Post eruptive brightening is observed in GOES SUVI 195 imagery starting around 2025-01-02T18:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as this measurement does not take into account possible deflection from the source.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap. The source may be far-sided as there are no source signatures visible on the Earth-facing disk that may be associated with this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 90 degrees due to the far-sided/unknown source location.

note: Wide loop CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-03T12:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap beginning at 2025-01-03T11:09Z. The source of this CME is an X1.2 flare from AR 3947 (N10E64) peaking at 2025-01-03T11:39Z. This flare is seen clearly in GOES SUVI 94 and 131 imagery, along with field line movement visible in GOES SUVI 171, 195 and 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. Measurement made with only early C2 frames due to ongoing SOHO and STEREO data gaps.

note: Faint, narrow CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-03T15:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a minor eruption located at approx. S12E23 beginning at approx. 03/14:00Z. This eruption can be seen exhibiting a Southeastern deflection in GOES SUVI 195 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and is seen in STEREO A COR2 for a few frames following a data gap from 2025-01-03T18:23Z to 2025-01-04T01:23Z, before becoming too diffuse to observe. The source is related to an eruption and X1.1 flare from Active Region 13947 (N11E60) peaking at 2025-01-03T22:41Z as seen in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery. An opening of field lines is visible over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 171, 195, and 284 imagery, and faint dimming is observed surrounding the eruption site in GOES SUVI 195 as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Partial halo CME first visible to the WNW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-04T05:48Z. Also visible to the WNW in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. Some continuous outflow continues for a few hours after the start time of the CME. The source of this CME is likely far-sided. Some moving field lines beyond the WNW limb can been seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about 2025-01-04T05:36Z. There is also some activity seen in STEREO A EUVI 304 and 195 from active region 3936, which was ~W116 at the time of eruption, at approximately 2025-01-04T05:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on probable source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Measurements give a possible range in longitudes from ~W110 to ~W140.

note: CME first visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-04T13:25Z. This CME is only visible for a couple faint frames in SOHO LASCO C3 and is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an X1.8 flare from AR 3947 that peaked at 2025-01-04T12:48Z. The flare and some ejected material can be seen in GOES SUVI 94, 131, 171, 195, 284, and 304 starting around 2025-01-04T12:30Z

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on likely source location visible in GOES SUVI.

note: CME associated with a long duration C9.3-class flare near the vicinity of AR 3939 (S17W55) that begins at approximately 2025-01-04T14:30Z, seen to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. It can be seen across all GOES SUVI wavelengths, but is particularly prominent in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft measurement since there is no STEREO A COR2 imagery. Measurement based on source candidate from GOES SUVI.

note: Fast partial halo seen generally to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 quickly leaving the SOHO C2 field of view, seemingly associated with an eruption from near the vicinity of Active Region 3939 (S17W58) and associated long duration C7.6-class flare. Quickly moving field lines off the west limb and bright post eruptive arcades are observed in GOES SUVI 284/304. Associated with solar energetic particle events at SOHO, GOES, and STEREO A.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement with no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for triangulation, assuming that the eruption is indeed on the Earth facing disk and associated with Active Region 3939 near W58.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Very faint and quick to fade CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-05T10:12Z. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 or STEREO A COR2 due to its faintness. The source of this event is an M4.1 flare from AR 3947 (N12E41) peaking at 05/09:36Z. This flare is visible in GOES SUVI 131 and post eruptive arcades can be seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. This event fades after only a few frames and will therefore not be simulated.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-05T16:36Z. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 or STEREO A COR2 due to faintness and a fading front. The source of this event is an M2.4 flare from AR 3947 (N12E40) peaking at 05/15:47Z. This flare can be seen in GOES SUVI 131 along with field line opening seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. This CME fades after a few frames before exiting the FOV in SOHO LASCO C2 and will therefore not be simulated.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-05T18:36Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This CME is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to faintness. The source of this event is a minor eruption seen near AR 3947 (N12E35) in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-05T20:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a minor eruption from AR 3947 (N15E35) seen in GOES SUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2.

note: A narrow faint jet with the likely source a relatively minor eruption centered around ~N17E20, near AR 3947 starting around 2025-01-06T05:08Z in GOES SUVI 304 /195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Uncertain one-coronagraph analysis based on the above source. The width of the jet is less than 10 deg.

note: CME first seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 staring at 2025-01-06T17:24Z. This CME fails before leaving the field-of-view of C2 and is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely an M4.8 flare from AR 3947 (N15E26) that peaked at 2025-01-06T17:24Z. The flare and eruption can be seen in GOES SUVI 94, 131, 171, 195, 284, and 304. A subsequent EUV wave can be seen with slight eastward deflection in GOES SUVI 195 and 284. Another source possibility is a small amount of ejecta from behind the NE limb best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2025-01-06T16:08Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement is based on probable source location identified from GOES SUVI imagery. The leading edge is only well-defined enough to measure for four frames in SOHO LASCO C2, so there is quite of bit of uncertainty in this measurement.

note: CME first seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-06T20:00Z. Also seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely some activity from on or beyond the W limb. There are some opening field lines from beyond the limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about 2025-01-06T18:28Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement is based on probable source location identified in GOES SUVI and on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-06T23:00Z. Also seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely a minor C2.7 flare peaking at 2025-01-06T22:10Z from AR 3941 (S06W79) and some accompanying ejecta best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2025-01-06T22:04Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on probable source location identified in GOES SUVI and on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Slow faint CME to the NNW. It is the first of several consecutive fronts (one first seen at 2025-01-07T08:00Z and at least one other front later). Its source is likely backsided, there is a slight restructuring of magn field/movement of field lines far behind the NW limb around 06:28Z seen in SUVI 195/171/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the best fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Super faint CME to the S (SE in STEREO A). The source could be a C2.5 flare and a minor eruption near AR 3951 (S14W06) seen after 09:35Z as dimming/brightening in STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: This CME is visible to the south/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The source is likely a slowly developing filament eruption visible near the southwest limb spanning S60W60 to S37W75 (centered around S50W70) which begins to erupt around 2025-01-07T15:30Z, seen best in GOES SUVI 304 imagery. A gradual opening field lines are visible in GOES SUVI 195 and 284 imagery around this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: Asymmetrical loop CME seen to the W in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is partially obstructed by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 which lasted from 2025-01-07T17:53Z to 2025-01-08T01:38Z. Source is a large eruption and brightening associated with the long-duration M1.1 flare located just beyond SW limb, likely from AR 3939 (S17W99), as seen in GOES SUVI. Widely opening field lines, brightening, and ejection of material can be seen in GOES SUVI 131/171/195/211/304 starting at about 2025-01-07T22:10Z. The tops of post-eruptive arcades can be seen emerging from beyond the SW limb in GOES SUVI 171 starting at about 2025-01-07T23:48Z. There is some uncertainty in the exact location of this eruption since this is not directly on the disk, but it is very likely associated with Active Region 13939 which is estimated to have been located at roughly S17W99 at the peak time of the flare [2025-01-07T23:05Z].

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery and source location (S17W99) based on UV imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely an eruption visible near the western limb in GOES SUVI 131, 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery starting around 2025-01-08T01:15Z. A subsequent faint opening of field lines is visible over the western limb around this time in GOES SUVI 171, 195, and 284 imagery, and post-eruptive arcades begin to form around 2025-01-08T02:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source may be related to a faint and slow opening of field lines visible over the northeast limb in GOES SUVI 171 imagery starting around 2025-01-08T02:00Z, possibly associated with a faint eruption centered near N45E45 at this time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to faint field line movement visible over the western limb in GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2025-01-08T04:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME faintly visible along a northeast streamer in STEREO A COR2. The CME is not visible in SOHO due to a data gap since 2025-01-08T14:42Z. The source is not clearly visible in EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using STEREO A COR2 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: CME first seen to the NE in STEREO A COR2 beginning at 2025-01-10T01:38Z after a data gap from 2025-01-09T13:38Z to 2025-01-10T01:38Z. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 or C3 due to an ongoing outage which began at 2025-01-08T14:36Z. A possible source for this CME is field line opening seen along the NE limb (approx. N20E100) as seen in SDO AIA 193, followed by intense post eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 131 and 193 from the same area. This suggests a possible far sided eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: STA POS measurement due to very wide range of lon fits (approx. -50 to -130)

note: Faint, jet-like CME first seen in the SE by STEREO A COR2 at 2025-01-10T10:09Z. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 or C3 due to an ongoing outage which began at 2025-01-08T14:36Z. A possible source for this CME is a minor eruption seen along the SE limb (approx. S15E85) in SDO AIA 304 beginning at approx. 10/09:17Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in STEREO A COR2

note: Flux rope CME first seen very faintly in SOHO LASCO C2 and becomes increasingly more visible in C3 and COR2A. No source is discernable in UV imagery of the Earth-facing disk or in STEREO-A EUV imagery; source is likely beyond SE limb based on visual triangulation of CME location in C3 vs. COR2A (and best fit measurement).

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit using several frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 running difference imagery.

note: Diffuse and relatively narrow CME to the N/NW first seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery, then shortly thereafter in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Source is an eruption near the NW limb at N24W80 with narrowly opening field lines and ejecta seen starting at 2025-01-11T07:58Z in GOES SUVI 195/131/171/284 and a small rising loop of filamentary material seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2025-01-11T07:57Z, all wavelengths showing heavy northern deflection. This eruption is associated with a C2.8 flare with peak time 2025-01-11T08:44Z produced by simultaneous brightening from recently-decayed AR 13954 (N24W76) as well as an unnumbered region just beyond the E limb located at an estimated N19E90-N19E100.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. Some uncertainty due to extreme faintness of leading edge in STEREO A COR2 difference imagery and use of reduced-cadence frames in C3 due to comet campaign.

note: Faint jet with a fuzzy, quickly disappearing front, seen in SOHO LASCO and in only one timestamp of STEREO A COR2 after a data gap. The source could be some very minor flaring and minor eruptions close to the W limb seen in AIA 193 around 21:38Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: The front of this CME is not really clear in COR2 (after the gap), so a POS measurement is the best we can do.

note: Narrow CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The potential source location can be seen on the southwest limb in GOES SUVI 195/304 as an ejecta of material and opening field lines starting around 2025-01-12T04:05Z. It is also visible beyond the limb in GOES SUVI 171/195/284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location as well as best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT.

note: Very faint narrow CME with fuzzy (not clear) front seen in several  timestamps of SOHO LASCO C2 and at least one timestamp in STEREO A COR2, with clear front not seen in C3 imagery. A possible source could be a minor filament eruption close to NW limb seen in AIA 304 starting at 19:19Z.

Minor faint and narrow jet with a fuzzy front mostly seen in C2 and one timestamp of COR2A, covered by pylon in C3. Its source possibly a very minor filament eruption in AIA 304 around 4:30Z behind the NW limb or a very minor activity in AR 3947 (N11W68) in AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit of the very fuzzy, unclear front with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint high latitude CME, covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source is likely the narrow filament eruption close to/off the NW limb (N25W90) seen around 2025-01-13T14:08Z in SDO AIA 304. It looks like the source is likely on the limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph analysis based on the possible source location on the NW limb.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is related to a filament eruption centered near S35W45 which begins to erupt around 2025-01-13T23:50Z as seen in GOES SUVI 304 imagery. A faint opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb at this time in GOES SUVI 171 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Fast, thin CME to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source appears to be on/just beyond the NW limb around N15, as field line movement and thin filament ejecta deflecting northward from this area beginning around 2025-01-14T01:56Z in SDO AIA 171/195/304 and GOES SUVI 171/284/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. This CME is directed straight into the C3 pylon, which made it difficult to track the precise front beyond C2 and COR2A.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The leading edge is faint and becomes too diffuse to observe in later imagery. The source is related to a filament eruption visible over the southeast limb which begins to erupt, deflecting eastward, starting around 2025-01-14T02:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery for a few frames before becoming too faint to observe. The source may be related to a faint dimming observed around 2025-01-14T05:00Z from ~N05W30 as seen in GOES SUVI 195 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Fast, thin CME to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source appears to be on/just beyond the NW limb around N16, as field line movement and thin filament ejecta deflecting northward from this area beginning around 2025-01-14T08:48Z in SDO AIA 171/195/304 and GOES SUVI 171/284/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. This CME is directed straight into the C3 pylon, which made it difficult to track the precise front beyond C2 and COR2A.

note: This CME is visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to a small eruption visible on/near the northeast limb starting around 2025-01-15T17:30Z as seen in SDO AIA 131 and 304 imagery. A faint opening of field lines is visible over the northeast limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the uncertain source location and data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: A narrow jet in the SE with the source an eruption visible on the southwest limb starting around 2025-01-15T15:00Z as seen in GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS analysis is the only analysis possible, since the source is behind the limb and no STEREO A COR2 imagery is available.

note: Narrow, jet-like CME first visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-15T21:12Z. Also visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C3. CME covered by data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely some opening field lines from beyond the SE best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about 2025-01-15T19:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.
Plane-of-sky measurement made with running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 using SWPC_CAT.

note: Faint narrow SW jet/outflow seen in both coronagraphs, with no clear source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Very faint SW CME with a clear front. No clear source has been found, but there is possibly some movement of field lines on/behind the SW limb seen in AIA/SUVI 171 and 193/195, although this is rather speculative.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and a few frames of STEREO A COR2 imagery starting at 2025-01-17T02:23Z, in which the CME is nearly outside the field of view.
The source is likely backsided and there is only SOHO imagery available because of the data gap in STEREO A.

note: Bright CME to the SSW. Source: eruption close to the SW limb (S30W75) starting at 21:48Z and seen best in AIA 171/131 as bright ejecta and in AIA 193 as opening of field lines in the SW and dimming.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph analysis with SOHO imagery only based on the location of the source eruptioin.

note: A very faint N CME/outflow with a fuzzy front mostly seen in SOHO. No clear source have been found, but there is flaring with dimming (AIA 193) going on intermittently in AR 3964 (N07W20), as well as a super minor eruption in AR 3963 (N25W5).

cmeAnalyses.note: A very uncertain analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME first seen in the SSE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-17T15:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event was also seen in the SW by STEREO A COR2, suggesting a far sided source. Faint field line movement can be seen in SDO AIA 171 in the South, however no clear source can be seen due to its far sided origins.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: A faint CME to the NNW in C2/C3 (so far covered by the gap in STA), which may be associated with an eruption in AR 3964 (N07W32) that is seen starting 16:29Z in AIA 193/304/

cmeAnalyses.note: One coronagraph analysis with SOHO only, based on possible source location as the AR 3964 eruption.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-17T21:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-01-17T15:53Z. The source of this CME are back to back M1.8 and M1.1 flares and an associated eruption from AR 3964 (N07W33). This flare can be seen clearly in SDO AIA 94 and 131, along with a Northern region of dimming seen in SDO AIA 193 suggesting a possible Northern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and adjusted for best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Faint CME first seen in the West by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-17T22:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-01-17T15:53Z. The source of this CME is field line movement seen along the Western limb (approx. S15W90) in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS due to range of lon. fits (approx. W80 to W120)

note: This CME is visible to the N/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is an M1.7 flare and subsequent eruption involving brightening, dimming, and a post-eruptive arcade from AR 3964 (N06W34) and the surrounding area beginning at approximately 2025-01-18T00:48Z as seen in SDO/AIA 131, 193, 304, and in a few frames of 211 (currently at a reduced cadence). This CME overlaps with the CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2025-01-18T02:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the best fit of the CME as seen in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2. There is likely deflection to the north of this CME due to a large coronal hole located below the erupting active region and source location.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NW in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and to the N/NE in STEREO A COR2 following the front of the CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2025-01-18T01:36Z. There are two potential sources for this CME. The first source of this CME could be associated with the same M1.7 flare from AR 3964 (N06W34) as the 18/01:36Z CME, however there is a simultaneous small filament eruption from an area to the SE of the main flaring AR location. This filament eruption (~S15W12) is the second potential source and is located above the large Earth-facing coronal hole which may have contributed to significant deflection of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit of CME using SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Due to the overlapping nature of this CME and the CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2025-01-18T01:36Z, there is a bit of uncertainty with the parameters. The separate front of this CME is more clearly seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery than it is in SOHO LASCO imagery, adding to the complexity of this analysis.

note: CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. This CME front is quite faint and diffuse. The source may be a faint filament eruption from area of AR 3959 (N20W04) starting around 2025-01-18T13:54Z in SDO AIA 304, which is seen deflecting northwestward slightly in SDO AIA 304/GOES SUVI 304, though for only a few frames before fading. CME partially overlaps with CME: 2025-01-18T15:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft (SOHO LASCO C2/C3) 3D measurement using the source location and faint observed deflection to the NW to get a good fit of this narrow, diffuse front which fades early in C3 in addition to traveling into the C3 pylon.

note: CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not STEREO COR2A due to a data gap. This CME front is quite faint and diffuse. The source may be a dimming eruption from AR 3964 (N04W44) starting around 2025-01-18T13:10Z with a second pulse of field line movement and brightening around T13:51Z in SDO AIA 171, with some dimming in SDO AIA 193. This unclean eruption may explain the diffuse nature of the CME. CME follows and partially overlaps with CME: 2025-01-18T15:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft (SOHO LASCO C2/C3) 3D measurement using the source location to get a fit of this wide, diffuse front, with notable difficulty due to the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery to triangulate a more accurate latitude/longitude to the slow eruption observed in SDO imagery.

note: Narrow but fast jet in the SW. Source is likely the unnumbered AR ~S20W58, although there are no clearly seen eruptions in EUV imagery at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS analysis is definitive since the CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2 imagery and the source is not clear.

note: Faint CME seen in SOHO imagery but not clearly seen in STEREO A coronagraph imagery. Likely source is AR ~S20W58 which had an eruption 18/23:12Z SDO 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph analysis based on the location of the source (filament eruption).

note: Faint CME with the left flank seen clearer in C2/C3 coronagraph. Not clearly discirnable in STEREO A COR2 (partly because of the data gap, partly because it is faint). Its source may be a faint filament from unnumbered AR (S30W58) seen at 2025-01-18T23:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Only POS measurement is definitive because the source is not clear and the CME is not seen in STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME with a fuzzy front seen in the SW in all three coronagraphs. Source is the opening/movement of field lines behind the SW limb as seen in AIA 193/171 at ~2025-01-19T02:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. The source is backsided and the front of the CME is not clear/fuzzy.

note: Faint minor CME with a bit fuzzy front seen in the first few timestamps in C2/COR2A in the NW. While there is a very minor eruption in the NW (~N45W60) seen as faint dimming/brightening in SUVI 284/193 and EUVI A 195 around 07Z, this apparently is not the source as the fitting with two coronagraphs produced a backsided longitude.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME to the SW with the source the minor opening of field lines on/likely behind the SW limb starting at 2025-01-29T18:33Z as seen in AIA 193.
Faint front to the NNE with no clear source found on disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Because of the absence of STEREO A coronagraph imagery due to a data gap, coupled with an absence of a clear source on disk, only a POS analysis is definitive.

note: Faint western front moving in parallel with another front to the NE. No definitive source found on disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Because of the absence of STEREO A coronagraph imagery due to a data gap, coupled with an absence of a clear source on disk, only a POS analysis is definitive.

note: A super faint CME with a dimpled/fuuzzy front seen in C2/C3 and COR2A. No clear source was found on disk, although there is a slow continuous movement of field lines in the SW starting on the preceding evening.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based solely on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint CME seen in C2/C3 and COR2A. No source found on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Faint and narrow jet to the SW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs.

note: Very faint CME to the south seen mostly in C3 difference imagery, covered by data gap in STA. No clear source found.

cmeAnalyses.note: In the absence of clear source and STEREO A coronagraph imagery only POS analysis is definitive.

note: Likely far-sided loop-shaped CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO during a STEREO A data outage which doesn't appear to be associated with activity on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement using only SOHO C2/C3.

note: Jet-like, narrow CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO starting around 2025-01-20T19:12Z, associated with an eruption just behind the southwestern limb seen best in GOES SUVI 284. Occurred during a STEREO A data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: SOHO plane of sky measurement of the leading edge of the CME.

note: Slow, faint CME seen to the southeast in SOHO C2 imagery likely associated with a spray-like filament eruption from near the vicinity of Active Region 3967 (S17E30) seen best in SDO/GOES 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using SOHO C2/C3 and knowledge of the source location of the eruption.

note: Wide CME seen due North in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and NW in STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME is not observed, but appears to be very high northern latitude based on triangulation with the swpc_cat tool during analysis.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement, confirming far-sided analysis.

note: CME seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source is a far-sided filament eruption over the SW limb viewed from SOHO, observed over the limb of SDO AIA 304 at 2025-01-21T04:38Z, and on the limb of STEREO A EUVI 304 at 2025-01-21T04:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A finding a good far-sided fit.

note: Faint CME seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2 only, fading after a few frames into the FOV. The source is some thread-like filament ejecta over the northern limb around 2025-01-21T04:21Z in GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky given the uncertain source longitude over the northern limb and only having a few early SOHO LASCO C2 frames to work with.

note: Fast CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME does not appear to be observed in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI, or STEREO A EUVI, but its direction in both coronagraphs and measurement heavily direct towards a far-sided source around W120-W130. There is a brief filament eruption over the SW limb starting around 2025-01-21T04:38Z in STEREO A EUVI 304, but that is quite early for this signature and that filament is believed to be responsible for CME: 2025-01-21T05:00Z instead.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurment between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A, with good confidence in a matched far-sided fit around W120-W130 despite the lack of source observation in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI, or STEREO A EUVI. The brighter bulk of the front in SOHO imagery is notably dimpled inwards, but the outer edges were sharp enough to track the leading edge.

note: Faint partial halo seen to the west-southwest in STEREO A COR2A and seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 behind the later emerging CME: 2025-01-21T10:53Z which is associated with Earth-facing disk activity. Despite the complexity of the two overlapping CMEs in LASCO imagery in the southeast, this CME being seen to the west in STEREO A suggests far-sidedness.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement mainly relying on STEREO A but also using some late SOHO C3 frames; a poor confidence measurement of the velocity.

note: Bright CME and faint shock to the SE in STEREO COR2A, not yet observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 due to a downlink gap except for a very few late SOHO C3 frames. The source is an M3.3 class flare from AR 3967 peaking at 2025-01-21T10:39Z. Starting around 2025-01-21T09:42Z, a wide area of the disk East and South of AR 13967 brightens up in SDO AIA 304/GOES SUVI 304 with observed filament ejecta fanning out to the SE. Field line movement and extensive dimming, with an EUV wave, over this area also observed in SDO AIA 171/193/211. Partially overlaps with far-sided CME: 2025-01-21T09:12Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using late SOHO C3 frames during a SOHO C2/C3 data gap occurring during early portions of the CME.

PRELIMINARY BULK single-spacecraft measurement with only available STEREO COR2A imagery as of this measurement, updated analysis will follow once SOHO imagery is available. Using the source longitude of E23 as a basis for this measurement with a potential range E10-E30 with the wide eruption signature observed in SDO AIA 304/GOES SUVI 304.

note: Narrow CME seen due south in SOHO LASCO which appears to be associated with a minor eruption from near Active Region 13967 (S20E25) and broad dimming signature seen best in SDO/GOES 193/195, respectively, following a much larger eruption occurring 2025-01-21T10:20Z. The eruption is characterized by modest southern deflection (out of the ecliptic).

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement assuming modest deflection southward out of the ecliptic, though a discernible faint shock feature was associated with this event which seemed to be much wider and slower.

note: Minor, narrow CME seen to the north in SOHO LASCO imagery during a STEREO A COR2 gap. Likely associated with far-sided activity as evidenced by the general lack of eruptive signatures on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge, plane of sky measurement using SOHO C2.

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-22T04:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen beyond the SW limb in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304 along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This shock feature was not visible in STEREO A COR2

note: CME seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and high NW in STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME is a filament eruption over the N limb, best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-01-22T08:09Z. This CME is immediately followed by a similar looking front, CME 2025-01-22T09:12Z, from this same source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A.

note: Lightbulb CME first seen to the South in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-22T08:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a far sided filament eruption seen along the South limb in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304 beginning at approx. 23/07:57Z along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME appears to speed up in later frames.

note: CME seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and high NW in STEREO COR2A. The source for this CME is a filament eruption over the N limb, best seen in GOES SUVI 304 starting around 2025-01-22T08:09Z. This CME is immediately preceeded by a similar looking front, CME 2025-01-22T08:12Z, from this same source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A.

note: Wide, messy CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2. Source is a large eruption from the southwest quadrant of the disk, from the large Active Region 13961 which was centered at S10W28 at the time of the eruption. Dimming starting at 2025-01-22T10:43Z extends from S10-S50 and from W10-W40 as seen in SDO AIA 193. Opening field lines and ejecta can be seen in SDO AIA 171 and SDO AIA 304, respectively. It is possible that two small filaments lifted off in this eruption, however, there is filamentary material visible/reformed after the eruption. An M1.3 flare from AR 13961 with peak time 2025-01-22T11:08Z is associated with this event. This CME visually overlaps with the far-sided CME:2025-01-22T08:36Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using the source location visible on the Earth-facing disk in UV imagery and using several frames of both SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. Data gap in STEREO A COR2 begins at 2025-01-22T12:53Z, so only the first few frames of the leading edge are captured in COR2.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A. No distinct source for this CME is observed, and it could be considered far-sided outflow from prior CME: 2025-01-22T08:36Z (analyzed at S59E164) or outflow from prior on-disk CME 2025-01-22T11:36Z (analyzed at S27W09), with far-sided more likely based on its directionality.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery and unobserved source.

note: CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A. No distinct source for this CME is observed, and it could be considered far-sided outflow from prior CME: 2025-01-22T08:36Z (analyzed at S59E164) or outflow from prior on-disk CME 2025-01-22T11:36Z (analyzed at S27W09), with far-sided more likely based on its directionality.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery and unobserved source.

note: CME seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A. No distinct source for this CME is observed. Analysis is ongoing to determine if this CME is separate from overlapping CME 2025-01-22T17:24Z, which is a thinner, brighter "bulk" looking feature that emerges around the same time in the same direction.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery and unobserved source. Analysis is ongoing to determine if this CME event is standalone, or potentially a shock feature of concurrent CME: 2025-01-22T17:24Z.

note: CME seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A. No distinct source for this CME is observed. Analysis is ongoing to determine if this CME is separate from overlapping CME 2025-01-22T17:12Z, which is a wider, fainter "shock" looking feature that emerges around the same time in the same direction.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery and unobserved source. Analysis is ongoing to determine if this CME event is standalone, or potentially a bulk feature of concurrent CME: 2025-01-22T17:12Z.

note: CME seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, due to a data gap in STEREO COR2A. No distinct source for this CME is observed, but given its direction and width it may bear similarity to earlier CMEs 2025-01-22T08:12Z and 2025-01-22T09:12Z, which had STEREO COR2A imagery to triangualate a far-sided high-latitude source filament eruption.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 with the lack of STEREO COR2A imagery and unobserved source.

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-23T02:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this CME is a far sided filament eruption seen in SDO AIA, GOES SUVI and STEREO A EUVI 304, along with field line opening seen in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Bright lightbulb CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-23T03:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen along the East limb in SDO AIA and GOE SUVI 304, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284. Post eruptive arcades are also visible following the filament liftoff in SDO AIA 131 and 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-23T04:26Z. This event is too faint to be reliably tracked in STEREO A COR2 and is blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this event is a very minor filament eruption from near AR 3959 (N18W61) beginning at approximately 23/02:50Z as seen in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2

note: Loop CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-23T09:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no clear source seen on the disk for this event. This, along with 2-coronagraph fitting, suggests a far sided longitude.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Faint CME first seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-23T14:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. There is no clear source seen on the disk for this event. This, along with initial coronagraph triangulation, suggests a far sided source beyond the SE limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is related to an eruption and subsequent C9.8 flare from a region just beyond the southeast limb as seen in SDO AIA 131 and 304 imagery starting around 2025-01-24T11:30Z. A wide opening of field lines is visible over the southeast limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. No distinct source for this CME is observed but it could likely be outflow from wide, bright CME 2025-01-24T12:24Z which was analyzed far-sided to S42E109. As part of this outflowing material to the SE, some material can be seen in SOHO LASCO C2 at 2025-01-24T19:24Z moving in this same direction, but the material at 2025-01-24T21:00Z moves faster and catches up/overlaps that in C3 to form one, bright trackable front.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky with only SOHO LASCO C3 due to the uncertain source longitude and lack of STEREO COR2A imagery due to a data gap.

note: Faint CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 only - this CME fades after a few frames and is overlapped by further activity from AR 13961. Furthermore, it is only visible in running difference imagery, as a bright streamer hides this front in white light imagery. However it has a clear source, as the M2.7 class flare from AR 13961 best seen in SDO AIA 131, with field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193/211 and filament ejecta in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft measurement with SOHO LASCO C2 as it fades in the FOV, using the source location of the M2.7 from AR 13961 at S05W70 with some northward deflection.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 only - this CME fades after a few frames and is overlapped by further activity from AR 13961. This particular front does not have a directly observed eruptive signature, but is visually similar to other fronts that did have connected signatures in SDO AIA 171/193 from AR 13961 throughout 2025-01-24.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft measurement with SOHO LASCO C2 as it fades in the FOV, using the source location of AR 13961 at S10W60.

note: Loop CME to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. This CME appears much more diffuse in STEREO A COR2 imagery. Source is likely a small eruption near Active Region 13961 and moving/opening field lines with southern deflection seen on the SW limb that appear to trace back to Active Region 13961.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between coronagraphs and location of the candidate source with southern deflection visible in UV imagery. The leading edge of this CME appears very diffuse in STEREO A COR2 imagery and becomes too diffuse to track after only a few frames. The leading edge remains visible for longer in SOHO LASCO, about halfway through the C3 field of view.

note: This CME is faintly seen to the NW overlapping a streamer in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. It is difficult to see in STEREO A COR2 white light imagery, but slightly more easy to see in difference imagery. There isn't a clear source, although there are moving/opening field lines visible in GOES SUVI 284 along the NW limb starting around 25/07:37Z and some filament ejecta from AR13961 deflected northward as seen in GOES SUVI 304 around 25/07:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Only two frames of this CME were captured by STEREO A COR2, due to a data gap starting at 2025-01-25T18:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using source location and best fit in only SOHO LASCO C3. Not captured in STEREO A COR2 in real time; data gap in STEREO A COR2 starting at 2025-01-25T18:23Z.

note: Faint, wide CME seen to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and NE in STEREO COR2A. No source observed on the disk for this event, but it triangulates between coronagraphs to around N34W02. This CME begins to incredibly slowly evolve to the N as early as 2025-01-25T06:00Z, with brighter material slowly emerging around 2025-01-25T20:48Z that accelerates in later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 to its final speed.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO COR2A. Only uses later frames of SOHO LASCO C3 due to acceleration from earlier C3 frames and C2.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 (for all frames) and STEREO COR2A (starting at 2025-01-26T02:23Z when a data gap ends). Source is a filament eruption in the southeast quadrant of the Earth-facing disk, with liftoff starting around 2025-01-26T00:08Z as seen in SDO AIA 304. The curved filament occupied an oval-shaped area on the disk spanning S10-S30 and E38-E65 just prior to eruption. Filamentary material and post eruptive brightening can be seen in SDO AIA 304 at 2025-01-25T00:45Z. Post-eruptive arcades become visible in SDO AIA 171/193/131 around 2025-01-26T02:27Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: SHOCK measurement of the faint, shock-like feature extending much wider than the brighter bulk, best observed in SOHO LASCO C3 imagery. Only two usable frames of STEREO COR2A are available to triangulate this feature, and its longitude could range E40-E60 around the eruption source at E51.
BULK measurement of the brighter, inner feature of this CME. Triangulates well between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery near the observed source centered around S20E51.

note: Narrow CME with the source the same location as the filament eruption producing 2025-01-26T01:25Z CME. This time it is a minor eruption seen around 2025-01-26T10:10Z near ~S20E55 in AIA 304, with brightening and post-eruptive arcades.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fits with two coronagraphs and confirmed by the location of the source eruption.

note: Faint CME seen in SOHO LASCO only (b/c of data gap in STEREO A coronagraph imagery). Source is another (but more minor) eruption in the SE quadrant starting around 18:41Z and centered around ~(S23E48), as seen in GOES SUVI 284 and SDO AIA 304/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: One coronagraph analysis with SOHO LASCO imagery only, based on the clear location of the source eruption. There are no STEREO A coronagraph images available at this point because of the daily gap.

note: CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and in STEREO COR2A starting at 2025-01-27T02:23Z returning from a data gap. The source for this CME is likely narrow filament ejecta from AR 3961 around 2025-01-27T23:28 in SDO AIA 304, located on the west limb around S10W90 at this time. Weak field line movement on/near the NW limb near cluster of ARs 3971/3965/3962, best observed in GOES SUVI 171 around 2025-01-27T23:25Z, creates a diffuse overlapping coronagraph signature to the NW of this more clear signature traveling SW.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement at W90 for the observed source in SDO AIA imagery, not a plane of sky. Triangulates between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery, though notably faint and tought to discern in STEREO COR2A beacon running difference imagery.

note: Faint CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source is observed on/just beyond the SW limb as filament ejecta visible in SDO AIA 131/171/193/304 starting at 2025-01-27T00:15Z, and is likely AR 3961 (S10W90 at time of eruption).

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. Due to poor visibility of this CME in STEREO COR2A running difference imagery, and the known source at W90 in SDO imagery, this longitude could slightly range W75-W95.

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-27T11:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament ejection beginning at 2025-01-27T10:32Z seen just around the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: CME first seen in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-27T16:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 2025-01-27T15:38Z. The source of this CME is field line movement and dimming seen near AR 3972 (S19W57) in SDO AIA 171 and 193 beginning at 2025-01-27T14:54Z. The dimming expands to the South of the Active Region suggesting a Southern deflection.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Due to the bizarre shape of this CME, especially in SOHO LASCO C2, this measurement was based on the furthest edge seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and more defined shape seen in SOHO LASCO C3

note: CME first seen to the SSW in SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-27T17:36Z. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2A due to a data gap beginning at 2025-01-27T15:38Z, and fades before entering the field-of-view in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this event is field line movement seen along the South limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 beginning at 2025-01-27T16:59Z, suggesting a far sided source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2

note: Faint loop CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and SW in STEREO A COR2. Source is an eruption from AR 13961 (S10, approx. W105-110) just beyond the SW limb. Brightening is seen in STEREO A EUVI 195/304 imagery at S10W110 (coordinates from perspective of Earth-facing disk) at 2025-01-28T08:05Z. Opening field lines are seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284 starting at 2025-01-28T08:05Z, and the absence of post-eruptive arcades and/or dimming on the Earth-facing disk further suggests this eruption is beyond the SW limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using location of source observed in UV imagery and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. Leading edge is very faint, especially in STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME first seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-01-28T20:12Z. CME is also seen to the ESE in SOHO LASCO C3 and is covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is possibly a small eruption from near the E limb (~S07).

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement based on the source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 imagery at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not available and the measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.
Plane-of-sky measurement using imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Due to the lack of a definitive source, there is low confidence in this measurement.

note: Faint CME to the SW with the source the minor opening of field lines on/likely behind the SW limb starting at 2025-01-29T18:33Z as seen in AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Approximated longitude based on source location. Plausible longitude fits range from approx. W90 to W125.
POS analysis based on SOHO imagery only. At the moment STEREO A coronagraph imagery is not available.

note: CME first seen in the SW by STEREO A COR2, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C2 due to a data gap from 30/04:00Z to 30/07:36Z. The source of this CME is field line movement seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284, suggesting a far sided source location.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME first seen to the SW beginning at 2025-01-30T09:12Z, as well as by STEREO A COR2 in later frames. This event is overtaken by CME: 2025-01-30T11:12Z in SOHO LASCO C3. The source of this CME is rising field line loops seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2A. This event is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 as it overlaps with CME: 2025-01-30T11:12Z.

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-01-30T11:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is field line opening seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193, GOES SUVI 284 and STEREO A EUVI 195, indicating a far sided source location.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2
SHOCK measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Flux rope CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. CME not captured by STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which started at 2025-01-30T15:09Z. The source is a filament eruption seen beginning at approx. 2025-01-30T13:49Z in SDO AIA 304, spanning approx. S05E05 to S40E40. Dimming and post eruptive arcades are also visible in SDO AIA 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on central location of filament eruption as seen in UV imagery, and best fit of shape in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 frames. CME not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-01-30T15:09Z.

note: Faint partial-halo CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, which remains visible into the C3 field of view. Overlaps with CME:2025-01-30T16:12Z, which is much more well-defined in coronagraph imagery. This CME is not captured by STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which started at 2025-01-30T15:09Z. The source of this CME is a distinct set of opening field lines and post-eruptive arcades seen in SDO AIA 94/171/193 around 2025-01-30T14:25Z located at approx. S15E10, as part of the same filament eruption which sourced CME:2025-01-30T16:12Z, which was seen beginning at approx. 2025-01-30T13:49Z in SDO AIA 304, spanning approx. S05E05 to S40E40.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on location of opening field lines and brightest portion of post-eruptive arcades associated with an elongated filament eruption as seen in UV imagery, and best fit of shape in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 frames. This CME was not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-01-30T15:09Z.

note: Loop CME seen to the West in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is not captured by STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap which started at 2025-01-30T15:09Z. The source of thus event is field line opening seen along/from just beyond the Western limb starting at 2025-01-30T17:57Z in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement taken, since source seen in UV imagery indicated that the eruption was beyond the W limb, and COR2A was not available in real time. CME not captured in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-01-30T15:09Z.

note: This CME is visible to the W/NW. The source is an M6.7 flare from AR13978 (N14E43), based on SDO/AIA 131 imagery, peaking at 2025-01-31T14:06Z. Associated filament ejecta is visible in SDO/AIA 304 starting around 2025-01-31T13:51Z. Moving/opening field lines and EUV wave are also visible along the NW limb in GOES SUVI 284 starting around 2025-01-31T14:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary measurement of the leading edge using only STEREO A data out to about 10 solar radii during a SOHO data outage. These parameters were later confirmed with the 2-Coronagraph measurement once SOHO became available.

note: Narrow eruption seen to the west in SOHO/STEREO A associated with a minor eruption near the vicinity of Active Region 13979 near S10W55, exhibiting some westward deflection seen in GOES 284/304 and SDO 193/171/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft measurement of the leading edge; triangulation of the leading edge indicates some westward deflection occurred relative to the source region of the eruption.

note: Minor, faint loop appearing to the west-northwest in SOHO LASCO imagery following behind the outflow of CME: 2025-02-01T14:24Z to the west. Likely associated with a far-sided eruption as evidenced by moving field lines seen off the northwest limb best in GOES 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft (SOHO) plane of sky measurement.

note: Asymmetric loop CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A data gap. Likely associated with far-sided activity as evidenced by a breaking/disappearing magnetic field line/loop seen far off the southwestern limb in GOES 284 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Updated measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.
Preliminary leading edge measurement with only three frames in SOHO C2, out to about 3 solar radii. Uncertainty in longitude about +/- 25 degrees.

note: This CME is visible as a far-sided halo directed towards the south/southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided, with a fast opening of field lines visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284 imagery starting around 2025-02-02T05:38Z. Eruptive material is also visible over/beyond the southwest limb starting around 2025-02-02T06:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304 imagery. It is possible this event is associated with former Active Region 13961, which was located approximately around longitude 170-175 degrees at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the bulk portion based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. This event has an irregularly-shaped leading edge, and the outermost feature was tracked in this measurement.
SHOCK measurement following the outermost, fainter shock feature based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This event is visible to the west/northwest in STEREO A COR2, but is it not observed in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no corresponding signatures on the Earth-facing disk around the time of this event. There is an eruption visible beyond the southwest limb in STEREO A EUVI 304 imagery starting around 2025-02-02T10:15Z and again around 13:15Z, but both of these eruptions appear too far south to be associated with this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of 120 degrees as this event is only visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery and the source location is far-sided/unknown.

note: This CME is visible to the north/northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely associated with an eruption and M5.1 flare from Active Region 13977 (N20E03) starting around 2025-02-02T14:00Z which deflects to the northeast as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 and GOES SUVI 171, 195, 284, 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location, accounting for northeast deflection, and the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Faint CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-02T18:36Z. This event is too faint to be reliably tracked in SOHO LASCO C3 and is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 02/15:23Z. The source of this event is field line movement seen near AR 3977 (N19E04) beginning at approx. 2025-02-02T18:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 171, 193 and 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2.

note: Far sided halo CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-02T21:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is far sided field line opening seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284. This CME overlaps with CME: 2025-02-02T22:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: Far sided halo CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-02T21:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is far sided field line opening seen along the SW limb in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284. This CME overlaps with CME: 2025-02-02T21:24Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: BULK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3.
SHOCK measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Faint CME first seen to the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-02T23:24Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This CME is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap beginning at 02/15:23Z. The source of this CME is an M4.1 flare from Active Region 3981 (N05E25) beginning at 02/23:04Z. This flare can be seen in SDO AIA 131 along with field line opening seen exhibiting a Southern deflection seen in SDO AIA 171 and 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery and in STEREO A COR2 following a data gap from 2025-02-02T15:23Z to 2025-02-03T02:53Z. The source may be related to a faint opening of field lines observed over the southeast limb starting around 2025-02-03T00:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. As this event is far-sided and a precise source location is unknown, the measured parameters may vary slightly.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is a filament eruption spanning S45W40 to S35W80 which begins to lift-off around 2025-02-03T11:00Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb at this time in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery as well. The eruption exhibits a southern deflection, which was confirmed in the measured parameters.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the approximate source location, accounting for visible southern deflection, and best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: Fast asymmetrical and relatively narrow CME to the SE, covered by a data gap in STEREO A. It source is a narrow filament eruption seen at 2025-02-04T00:02Z in SUVI 284/304 and AIA 304 on SE limb.

cmeAnalyses.note: One coronagraph analysis (SOHO only) in the absence of STEREO A imagery.

note: Streamer-like loop CME seen due north in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and northeast in STEREO A COR2. The source is a large rising loop seen over the N/NE limb in GOES SUVI 284 seen starting at 2025-02-03T20:38Z. Corresponding field line movement on the Earth-facing disk centered over a large cluster of Active Regions in the northern hemisphere (ARs 13976, 13977, 13978, 13981, and 13982) and minor post-eruptive brightening seen at N30E20 at 2025-02-04T08:38Z in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using best fit between several frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2. Agrees with source location seen in UV imagery.
