note: Faint loop CME seen to the south in SOHO LASCO C2 and south in STEREO A COR2. Becomes diffuse after a few frames of SOHO LASCO C3. The source is field line movement seen beyond the southern limb starting at 2025-02-04T01:48Z in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 difference imagery. The leading edge becomes diffuse about halfway through the STEREO A COR2 field of view.

note: CME first seen to the SSE is SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-02-04T08:24Z. Also seen to the SSE in SOHO LASCO C3 and to the SSW in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is most likely some very faint moving field lines visible beyond the southern limb best seen in GOES SUVI 284 starting about an hour prior to the CME start time. A far-sided source fits well with measured parameters.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2.

note: Faint CME to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3, not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source of this CME is unclear but may be associated with moving/opening field lines visible along the NE limb in SDO/AIA 171 starting around 2025-02-04T09:00Z and continuing through 2025-02-04T13:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on a plane-of-sky fit due to lack of visible features in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The left hand side of the leading edge of the CME was tracked throughout the frames used in this analysis.

note: Minor, narrow CME seen to the south-southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, likely associated with a far-sided eruption at extreme southern latitudes as evidenced by flickering field lines in SDO AIA 171 seen off the southeast limb around 2025-02-04T21:00Z. STEREO A imagery is not available to support triangulation.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft leading edge measurement by approximating the latitude.

note: CME first visible to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2 starting at 2025-02-05T02:12Z. Also seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C3 and to the S in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is a filament eruption from the SW quadrant of the Earth-facing disk easily seen across SDO EUV wavelengths. The filament is best seen beginning to lift off at approximately 2025-02-05T00:10Z in SDO AIA 304. The footpoints of the filament were located at approximately S35W27 and S30W65.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement based on running difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 and on the location of the erupting filament.

note: Faint puff-like CME seen to the east-northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 coronagraph imagery and not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery except for one frame. Associated with a spray/prominence eruption taking place off the eastern limb seen in GOES SUVI 284 with strong northern/northeastern deflection. The CME is characterized by a very slow moving bulk and fainter shock-like feature which accelerates outward ahead of the bulk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge of the fainter shock-like portion of this CME which accelerates away from the brighter bulk using only SOHO LASCO C2.

note: Minor, narrow CME seen to the southeast in SOHO C2 and presumably to the south in STEREO A COR2A, seemingly associated with a far-sided minor filament eruption seen around 18:00Z to the southeast in GOES SUVI 304 and SDO AIA 304. Triangulation suggests the CME originates from near a longitude of -145 degrees.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using two spacecraft to triangulate the longitude.

note: Relatively slow, loop CME seen to the east-northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, brightly in running difference imagery and faintly in white light imagery. There are few if any sources on the Earth-facing disk or off of the east/northeast limb to suggest that this CME is associated with eruptive activity on the Earth-facing limb, therefore, it likely originates from the far-side of the solar disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft (SOHO) plane of sky measurement of the leading edge as STEREO A imagery was unavailable and the source location of the eruption was not known.

note: Narrow CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 imagery, brightly in running difference imagery and faintly in white light imagery. Likely associated with far-sided eruptive activity as evidenced by moving magnetic field lines seen off the southeast limb best in GOES SUVI 284, but as well in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky leading edge measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2 as the CME disappears before exiting the SOHO C2 field of view; in addition, STEREO A COR2 is not available due to a data gap.

note: CME seen to the SE fully in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, and to the S/SW potentially as a partial halo in STEREO COR2A after 2025-02-06T05:09Z, with the CME front already at the edge of its FOV when its beacon data downlink resumes. Due to this data gap timing in STEREO COR2A, the CME is observed in white light imagery but unresolvable in running difference imagery. Observed as a rapid snapping open and dimming of field lines over the SE limb centered ~S28, best observed in SDO AIA 171/193 around 2025-02-06T02:31Z and GOES SUVI 284 around 2025-02-06T02:34Z. Also observed in SDO AIA 304/GOES SUVI 304 as some filament ejecta. The far-sided nature of this CME is also corroborated via fitting in swpc_cat and the lack of an on-disk signature accompanying the field line movement.

cmeAnalyses.note: SHOCK measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, as STEREO COR2A beacon running difference imagery does not resolve this front after it resumes from a data gap at 2025-02-06T05:09Z, making triangulation within swpc_cat not possible with real-time imagery. Via visual fitting of this wide shock front, a range of E140-E155 is likely, as further longitudes in either direction make for a poor visual fit of the shock.

BULK measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, as STEREO COR2A beacon running difference imagery does not resolve this front after it resumes from a data gap at 2025-02-06T05:09Z, making triangulation within swpc_cat not possible with real-time imagery. This measurement includes all lobes of the more dense bulk following the shock.

note: Bright filament eruption to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source is a filament eruption occurring on/beyond the NW limb as viewed from SDO AIA and GOES SUVI, first seen on the NW limb as viewed from STEREO A EUVI 304 at 2025-02-06T10:15Z, confirmed to be separate from the M7.6 flare (AR 13981) that occurred on the earth-facing disk at this same time. Also observed starting around 2025-02-06T10:36Z in SDO AIA 304/GOES SUVI 304, launching more explosively around 2025-02-06T11:32Z. Also seen well as the filament ejecta and field line movement in SDO AIA 171/193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulated measurement between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A.

note: Faint, outflow like CME first seen in the South by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-06T15:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-02-06T15:23Z to 2025-02-07T02:53Z. The source of this event is faint field line movement seen along the South limb in SDO AIA 171, 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to source near the limb and no STEREO A COR2 for triangulation. Measurement based on best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: Bright lightbulb CME first seen in the SE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-07T03:12Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is a filament eruption seen along the SE limb in SDO AIA and GOES SUVI 304, along with field line opening seen in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Very faint CME first seen in the NW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-07T08:24Z. This CME appears to fade before exiting the FOV in SOHO LASCO C2. The source of this event is an M3.2 flare from AR 3981 (N06W27) peaking at 07/07:21Z seen in SDO AIA 131. Post eruptive arcades are visible in SDO AIA 94 and 131, along with a region of dimming seen in SDO AIA 211.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. Front fades before exiting the field-of-view in SOHO LASCO C2.

note: Faint CEM first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-07T11:00Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is very minor field line movement seen along the NE limb in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: Minor CME seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A data gap; the CME is likely associated with a far-sided eruption occurring behind the southeastern limb, as evidenced best by moving field lines seen off the southeast limb in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Stereoscopic best-fit measurement taken after STEREO A COR2 data gap ended. The data gap lasted from 2025-02-07T15:38Z to 2025-02-08T02:53Z. The leading edge is very faintly visible for one frame of STEREO A imagery before becoming too diffuse to discern, but fortunately, the leading edge in that one frame is clear enough to achieve a best-fit measurement between STEREO A COR2 and SOHO LASCO C2/C3.
SOHO C2 plane of sky measurement, as STEREO A imagery is not available at the time of measurement.

note: Faint CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. Candidate source is a small amount of brightening seen from AR 13981, followed by dimming and field line movement (centered at N00W45) just to the southwest of AR 13981, which starts at 2025-02-08T00:39Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on potential source location. This measurement is approximate, and based on a few frames of SOHO LASCO C2.

note: Faint CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2/C3, not clearly visible in STEREO A COR2. Source is an M2.0 flare and associated eruption from AR 13981 (N07W41). Opening field lines and dimming seen starting at 2025-02-08T09:09Z, best seen in SDO AIA 193. The eruption is also seen from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location. The CME was not measurable in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Narrow CME visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not visible in SDO AIA imagery, but an eruption can be seen just on or beyond the southwest limb in STEREO A EUV 304 imagery starting at 2025-02-08T12:45Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery in SWPC_CAT and the potential source location as viewed from STEREO A EUV imagery.

note: Very faint CME to the northwest only seen in several SOHO LASCO C2 images and largely obscured by the pylon in C3 imagery. The CME is fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A imagery. No clear coronal signatures have been found for this CME, although some very minor activity is going on in the northwest, possibly from AR 13978 (N14W77).

cmeAnalyses.note: The CME is fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A coronagraph and no source has been found on the Earth-facing disk for it. Therefore, only plane-of-sky analysis is possible for this event.

note: Narrow CME to the east, with pointed and fuzzy nose. The CME is fully covered by a data gap in STEREO A coronagraph imagery. Its source is a filament eruption off the east limb (N10E90) which starts around  2025-02-10T00:01Z, as seen in SDO AIA 171/304 and GOES SUVI 284/304 imagery. The filament could be further behind the limb, so its longitude could differ from -90 degrees.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two-coronagraph analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs once STEREO A imagery became available. The longitude of the fit is confirmed by the location of the erupting filament (on or close to the east limb).

Very approximate preliminary analysis with one coronagraph (SOHO LASCO), made with early SOHO imagery while no STEREO A COR2 imagery was available, and based on the very approximate location of the source (an erupting filament) which could be on or further behind the east limb.

note: A super faint jet to the southeast in both coronagraphs, best seen in STEREO A COR2 (and in difference imagery from SOHO LASCO C2) and only seen in 2-3 early timestamps in SOHO LASCO C3 because of extreme faintness of this event. No source was found on the Earth-facing disk, so it is likely a farsided event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs. No source have been found for this event, so it is likely farsided.

note: This CME is visible to the east/southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely related to a faint eruption visible slightly beyond the southeast limb in SDO AIA 304 imagery starting around 2025-02-10T11:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the east/northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-10T18:09Z. The source is likely related to an eruption on/near the eastern limb starting around 2025-02-10T17:50Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A faint opening of field lines is visible over the northeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the approximate source location. Due to a data gap in STEREO A COR2 at the time of this event, a triangulated measurement was not possible. The measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: Faint CME visible to the west in SOHO LASCO C2, becoming diffuse before leaving the C2 field of view. This CME is not clearly visible in SOHO LASCO C3 or STEREO A COR2. Source is an M1.6 flare and associated eruption from AR 13981 (N05W87). Opening field lines and brightening are seen starting around 2025-02-11T05:27Z, best seen in SDO AIA 131, but also seen in SDO AIA 171/193/304. The eruption is also seen from the point of view of STEREO A EUV 195/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 frames and source location. Leading edge becomes diffuse before leaving the SOHO LASCO C2 field of view.

note: Bright CME visible to the east in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and in STEREO A COR2. Source is an eruption and associated C5.8 flare located at N15E75. Opening field lines, a rising loop, and ejecta are seen starting at 2025-02-11T06:12Z in SDO AIA 193/171/304/131.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 running difference imagery as well as the location of the source seen in UV imagery of the Earth-facing disk.

note: CME seen to the E in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A. The source is best observed in SDO AIA 304 as a filament eruption on the eastern limb around S10E90, beginning around 2025-02-11T17:48Z and erupting more explosively around 2025-02-11T18:04Z. Also observed as field line opening in SDO AIA 171/193, and a C7.2 flare peaking at 2025-02-11T18:25Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: SHOCK measurement of a faint feature traveling ahead and slightly faster than the brighter bulk feature. Triangulated measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery, finding a good fit at E90, not as a plane-of-sky.

BULK measurement of the bright feature traveling slightly slower than the faint shock feature. Triangulated measurement with SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO COR2A imagery, finding a good fit at E90, not as a plane-of-sky.

note: This CME is visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is not visible in SOHO LASCO C3 due to the control arm. The front of this CME fades fairly quickly in SOHO LASCO C2 frames before becoming too diffuse to track. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on best fit using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-12T02:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 and STEREO A COR2 in later frames. The source of this event is not entirely clear. However, a region of brightening is visible in SDO AIA 94 located at approx. N10E70 beginning at approx. 12/02:24Z. A 2-coronagraph measurement indicates that the CME likely resulted from activity in this area, however, due to the timing, this brightening may be post-eruptive arcades from an eruption that is not as visible opposed to the actual source of the CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2

note: This CME is visible to the south-southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. It is not visible in STEREO A COR2 imagery due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-12T10:38Z. The source appears to be a filament eruption visible along the south-southwestern limb in SDO/AIA 304, GOES SUVI 304, and STEREO A EUVI 304 starting around 2025-02-12T06:00Z. Moving/opening field lines are also visible in SDO/AIA 171, GOES SUVI 284, and STEREO A EUVI 195.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky parameters using SWPC_CAT measurement technique. The front of this CME is very diffuse and difficult to track.

note: Faint CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-12T13:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-02-12T10:38Z to 2025-02-13T03:23Z. The source of this CME is a minor eruption seen located at approx. N15E47 in SDO AIA 193, 211 and 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2/C3

note: CME first seen in the SW by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at approx. 2025-02-12T18:00Z. This event fades before exiting the FOV in SOHO LASCO C3, and is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-02-12T10:38Z to 2025-02-13T03:23Z. The source of this event is a very gradual filament eruption seen centered at approx. S50W40 in SDO AIA 304, with movement beginning at approx. 12/13:00Z. Field line opening is seen much later in SDO AIA 171, 193, 211 and GOES SUVI 284 beginning at approx. 12/16:49Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2

note: CME first seen in the East by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 20254-02-12T21:48Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-02-12T10:38Z to 2025-02-13T03:23Z. There is no clear source seen for this event, aside from general field line movement seen along the East limb in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to uncertain source location and range of longitude fits (approx. E60 to E110).

note: Faint, narrow CME first seen in the NE by SOHO LASCO C2 beginning at 2025-02-13T01:36Z, as well as by SOHO LASCO C3 in later frames. This event is not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap from 2025-02-12T10:38Z to 2025-02-13T03:23Z. There is no clear source seen for this event aside from general field line movement along the NE limb seen in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: POS measurement due to range of longitude fits (approx. E70 to E100) and no clear source.

note: This CME is visible to the N/NE in SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 imagery. It is very faint with a diffuse front. The potential source of this CME is a dimming centered around S07W10 just East of AR13992 as seen in SDO/AIA 193 and 211 starting around 2025-02-13T14:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: These parameters are based on the best fit of features in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 imagery. There is likely deflection of this CME due to the large coronal hole south of the potential source location.

note: This CME is visible to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3 imagery. There is no STEREO A COR2 imagery available for this CME due to a data gap beginning at 2025-02-13T17:09Z. The source of this CME is likely a filament eruption visible in SDO/AIA 304 and 171 just beyond the SE limb starting around 2025-02-13T16:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky fit using SWPC_CAT measurement tool.

note: Narrow, faint CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A data gap. Likely associated with a small filament eruption starting around 2025-02-13T20:00Z in the NE on Earth-facing disk around N20W45 (seen best in SDO AIA 193).

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary one spacecraft leading edge measurement of the CME assuming that the source on the Earth-facing disk best represents this CME.

note: Wide, faint CME seen primarily to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 which appears to be associated with a C6.6-class flare from Active Region 13994 and subsequent eruption seen best in SDO AIA 094 and SDO AIA 304 with notable deflection to the east. Despite the overall weak eruptive signature, triangulation strongly suggests that the eruption is associated with front-sided activity bounded by longitudes -25 to -45.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading-edge measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 to corroborate the longitude.

note: Jet CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2A likely associated with a minor eruption from Active Region 13991 (S12E36), as evidenced by an eruptive signature taking place in SDO AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement.

note: Narrow CME seen to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2 during a STEREO A data gap; the CME is possibly associated with a minor eruption from Active Region 13994 located near S21W00 as seen in SDO AIA 94, 304, though it isn't definitive where the eruption originates. Triangulation is not currently possible due to a STA COR2 data gap.

cmeAnalyses.note: Preliminary plane of sky measurement given no STEREO A COR2 data is available.

note: CME seen to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, STEREO COR2A beacon data entirely misses this event. Partially overlaps with CME 2025-02-14T22:00Z to the SE. The source for this CME is likely an area of the disk ~N14E33 which brightens and releases some filament material to the NE starting around 2025-02-14T20:58Z, best observed in SDO AIA 171/193/304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft 3D measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a STEREO COR2A data gap covering this CME, using the source coordinates of N14E33 as a basis.

note: CME seen to the SE in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 only, STEREO COR2A beacon data entirely misses this event. Partially overlaps with CME 2025-02-14T21:48Z to the NE. The source for this CME is likely a broad area of the disk ~S30E68 which slowly dims and moves field lines to the SE starting around 2025-02-14T21:00Z, best observed in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284. There is a concurrent, separate M1.8 flare from AR 13990 (S12E13) which peaked at 2025-02-14T20:57Z which was considered for a source here, but ruled out with lower confidence than the SE quadrant dimming mentioned prior.

cmeAnalyses.note: Single spacecraft 3D measurement using only SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery due to a STEREO COR2A data gap covering this CME, using the source coordinates of S30E68 as a basis.

note: Faint southeastern CME with a dimpled/fuzzy front, seen in both coronagraphs (in SOHO LASCO and in STEREO A COR2 after a data gap). It's source is unclear but possibly the very faint rising post-eruptive arcades and super minor dimming seen around 2025-02-15T00:40Z centered around (S30E65).

cmeAnalyses.note: A very speculative measurement based on the possible but not clear source and on a very approximate fit with two coronagraph. The fit is uncertain since especially in STEREO A the front of this CME is super unclear.

note: Fast CME seen  to the NE in both coronagraphs, faint in SOHO LASCO and bright in STEREO A COR2. In STEREO A it is only seen after the nighttime data gap ends. Its source is likely a significant filament eruption centered around N11E31, seen starting around 2025-02-15T00:56Z in GOES SUVI 304 and in SDO AIA 304, but also seen as small area brightening in SDO AIA 193. There is also a lower class C flare associated with it.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs; it corresponds well to the location of the source eruption.

note: Bright CME with a high southern latitude, seen to the west in STEREO A COR2 and almost exactly to the south in SOHO LASCO, indicating a backsided source. Coronal signatures include a huge prominence seen directly to the south in GOES SUVI 304 starting at 2025-02-12:56Z and originating behind the south limb, and also seen as an extensive movement of matter/field lines to the south and southeast in GOES SUVI 284, also likely happening behind the southern limb. Coronal signatures are almost not seen in SDO AIA, except for minimal movement of ejecta seen in AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs and corresponding well to the southern filament see in EUVI imagery.

note: Narrow CME visible in the southwest of SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Not visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-15T17:09Z. The source is not visible in EUV imagery, and my be farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using SOHO LASCO C2/C3 difference imagery in SWPC_CAT due to lack of known source location.

note: CME visible to the northwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. The CME is partially obscured by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. No visible in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-15T17:09Z. The source is an eruption from Active Region 13983 (approx. N06W90) starting at 2025-02-15T19:22Z. Brightening and opening field lines are best seen in SDO AIA 171/193 and GOES SUVI 284. The eruption is also visible in SDO AIA 304 imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on approximate source location. Only SOHO LASCO C2 imagery was available for a measurement, as the CME was blocked by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Narrow flux rope CME seen to the SW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2. The source is not visible in available EUV imagery, but is on the farside based on triangulation between the SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs. This CME is partially covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 which lasted from 2025-02-15T16:53Z to 2025-02-16T05:23Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using several SOHO LASCO C3 frames and two frames of STEREO A COR2 before the leading edge leaves the COR2 field of view. This CME is partially covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 which lasted from 2025-02-15T16:53Z to 2025-02-16T05:23Z.

note: Faint loop CME seen to the S in SOHO LASCO C2 and the SE in STEREO A COR2. The leading edge is too diffuse to discern in SOHO LASCO C3. Source is a small eruption from N27E30: a narrow set of opening field lines from the location is seen in GOES SUVI 284 at 2025-02-16T07:45Z as well as post-eruptive brightening seen in SDO AIA 304 at 08:25Z, followed immediately by a much wider and fainter set of opening field lines which extends across the southern hemisphere of the disk all the way to roughly near AR 13994 (S20W22).

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2, as well as the source location seen in UV imagery. Leading edge is too diffuse to track in SOHO LASCO C3.

note: Narrow loop CME to the N in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and NW in STEREO A COR2. The source is not visible in available EUV imagery, but is on the farside based on triangulation between the SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 coronagraphs.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using an abundance of SOHO LASCO C2 frames, two frames of C3, and two frames of STEREO A COR2. The leading edge becomes diffuse after a few frames of C3 and of COR2.

note: Faint CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. This CME is completely covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 which lasted from 2025-02-16T11:38Z to 2025-02-16T15:23Z. Source is the partial liftoff of a filament seen starting as early as 2025-02-16T10:48Z in SDO AIA 304 and in GOES SUVI 304/284 as brightening and departure of some filamentary material and opening of surrounding field lines. Filament spans from N00W40, arcs up to N20W60, then arcs down slightly to N10W70, as seen in SDO AIA 304 at 2025-02-16T10:48Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Best fit measurement using candidate source location, several SOHO LASCO C2 frames, and two frames of SOHO LASCO C3. The leading edge is narrow and for most frames is completely obstructed by the pylon in SOHO LASCO C3. This CME is completely covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2 which lasted from 2025-02-16T11:38Z to 2025-02-16T15:23Z.

note: This CME is faint but visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. This event is not observed in STEREO A COR2 due to it's faintness and a data gap starting at 2025-02-16T18:23Z. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery, but is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-16T18:23Z. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to a faint opening of field lines observed over the southeast limb in SDO AIA 171 and 193 imagery starting around 2025-02-16T19:20Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: This CME is visible to the southeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery for a few frames before becoming too diffuse to observe. It is not seen in STEREO A COR2 due to a data gap starting at 2025-02-16T18:23Z. The source is likely far-sided, and may be related to faint field-line movement visible over the southeast limb in SDO AIA 171 imagery starting around 2025-02-16T23:30Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: A plane-of-sky measurement was made using a longitude of -90 degrees due to the far-sided and therefore unknown source location.

note: Extremely faint loop CME visible to the N in SOHO LASCO C2. The leading edge is not discernable in SOHO LASCO C3 or in STEREO A COR2. Source is subtle brightening and field line movement at N50 and spanning W00-W20, just north of a coronal hole, seen in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284 lasting between 2025-02-17T01:40Z-02:50Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on source location and best fit in SOHO LASCO C2. Latitude matches well, but longitude is measuring slightly east of source location; there may have been deflection due to the nearby coronal hole observed in UV imagery.

note: Faint CME visible to the north in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. STEREO A COR2 is in a data gap during this event. There is no clear source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based on plane-of-sky analysis using SWPC_CAT and SOHO LASCO imagery. No STEREO A COR2 imagery was available during this measurement.

note: This event is faint but visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and north in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 imagery. This event may become too faint before entering the STEREO A COR2 field of view, as it is not easily observed. The source is likely related to an eruption from Active Region 13994 (S23W65) starting around 2025-02-19T06:25Z as seen in SDO AIA 131, 171, 193, 304 imagery. A subsequent opening of field lines is visible over the southwest limb in SDO AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284 imagery at this time as well.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measured longitude based on the source location. As this event is not easily observed in STEREO A COR2 imagery, a triangulated measurement was not made and the measured parameters may vary slightly as a result.

note: This CME is faint but visible to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and to the north in STEREO A COR2 imagery. The source is likely far-sided as there are no source signatures on the Earth-facing disk at the time or in the vicinity of this event.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on the best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 imagery.

note: This CME is visible to the NE in SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. There is a data gap in STEREO A COR2 during this event. The source appears to be a filament eruption beyond the NE limb starting around 2025-02-19T18:47Z as seen in SDO/AIA 304, 171, 131, 195, and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Parameters based off of potential source location. Parameters may be off due to limited stereoscopic viewpoints.
Measurement of shock front using only SOHO C2/C3.

note: Wide CME seen primarily to the west in SOHO C2 and C3 imagery associated with a bright C8-class flare and eruption from around AR 13991 (S12W34) as seen in SDO/AIA 304 and SDO/AIA 131 starting around 23:33Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Bulk measurement encompassing more of the brighter, far-southern deflected piece of the CME using SOHO C2/C3 and assuming some moderate westward deflection based on EUV signatures (i.e. about 10-15 degrees from the source).

note: Loop CME which begins as a very narrow event but evolves as a wide loop with time, seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Likely associated with far-sided activity based on its association with several far-sided events throughout the day, though the source is not known.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane of sky measurement of the leading edge measurement of the loop using SOHO C2/C3.

note: Loop CME overlapping overlaps CME 2025-02-20T00:36Z which begins as a very narrow event but evolves as a wider event with time, seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. Likely associated with far-sided activity based on its association with several far-sided events throughout the day, though the source is not known.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft plane of sky measurement (SOHO).

note: Narrow CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 first seen at approximately 2025-02-20T03:25Z amongst a string of events to the northeast; the source is not immediately clear, but is likely associated with minor eruptive activity just on or beyond the eastern limb as seen by moving field lines in SDO AIA 171.

cmeAnalyses.note: One spacecraft (SOHO) plane of sky measurement for the leading edge at lon -90.

note: Narrow CME seen to the south in SOHO LASCO C2 and to the southeast in STEREO A COR2 in association with a large scale filament eruption taking place near S45E70, seen best in SDO AIA 304 and GOES SUVI 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement of the leading edge using two spacecraft.

note: Wide CME seen to the east in SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 composed of a brighter bulk to the south and possibly a separate portion just to the north. Likely associated with large scale dimming taking place near S10E60 seen best in GOES SUVI 195 and SDO AIA 193. Triangulation of the leading edge measures a bit closer to the Earth-Sun line than anticipated, and this may be due to a simultaneous eruption occurring near center disk around 2025-02-20T11:00Z.

cmeAnalyses.note: Triangulation of the leading edge using SOHO and STEREO A, which measures slightly farther east than was anticipated given the source location of the eruption.

note: CME seen to the northeast in SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2 imagery, likely associated with an eruption just beyond the eastern limb as evidenced by moving field lines from an area of higher magnetic flux behind the northeast limb seen best in GOES SUVI 284.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft leading edge measurement using SOHO/STEREO A to triangulate the approximate longitude.

note: Slow loop CME emanating to the northeast in SOHO LASCO C2 with an unclear source, taking the appearance of earlier CMEs 2025-02-20T04:24Z and 2025-02-20T07:12Z. The source is unknown but likely associated with far-sided minor eruptive activity.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge plane of sky measurement only utilizing SOHO C2.

note: Lightbulb shaped CME occurring in association with a filament eruption seen to the north in SOHO LASCO C2 and north-northeast in STEREO A COR2 occurring near the vicinity of Active Region 14000 (N18E20) seen best in GOES SUVI 304 and SDO AIA 304. It expands significantly in later imagery, particularly SOHO C3 imagery, becoming much more wide.

cmeAnalyses.note: Leading edge measurement using all available imagery from two spacecraft out to approximately 18 solar radii.

note: Fairly slow CME seen to the southwest in SOHO LASCO C2 and farther south in STEREO A COR2A; the source is possibly associated with a filament eruption seen in SDO AIA 304 occurring on the Earth-facing disk around 2025-02-21T06:30Z, however, the CME appears to fit to a longitude of W30 to W50 which is not associated with any eruptions visible on the Earth-facing disk.

cmeAnalyses.note: Two spacecraft measurement of the leading edge using triangulation of the leading edge to determine the longitude.

note: The first in a series of three overlapping CMEs. This CME is visible to the W/slightly NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and similarly to the W/slightly NW in STEREO A COR2. The leading edge is more faint and narrow than those of the other subsequent CMEs. The source of this CME is part of a complex eruption taking place on the NW limb in SDO imagery. As early as 2025-02-20T18:00Z in SDO AIA 193, a loop over the NW limb can be seen beginning to slowly rise, located above or near some destabilizing filament material hovering above on the NW limb in SDO AIA 304.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2 and STEREO A COR2 as well as general location of the complex candidate source.

note: The second in a series of three overlapping CMEs. This CME is visible to the W/slightly NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and similarly to the W/slightly NW in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is part of a complex eruption taking place on the NW limb in SDO imagery. At 2025-02-21T09:24Z, a wide loop snaps open in SDO AIA 171/193, and some filamentary material rapidly rises high in the corona but fails to escape solar gravitational forces, remaining suspended in the corona for a few hours. The wide loop that snapped open is a candidate source for this CME.

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and STEREO A COR2 as well as location of the complex candidate source.

note: The third in a series of three overlapping CMEs. This bright flux rope CME is visible to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3 and to the NW in STEREO A COR2. The source of this CME is part of a complex eruption taking place on the NW limb in SDO imagery. Around 2025-02-21T11:27Z, suspended filament material finally ejects outward in SDO AIA 171/193/304. A large post-eruptive arcade on the NW limb also begins around 2025-02-21T11:27Z, expanding from N10->N35 on/just inside the NW limb. This filament eruption is also visible in STEREO A EUVI 195 and 304 imagery, showing post-eruptive arcades and brightening stretching from N35W60 to N15W90, near AR 3989 (~N20W85) [30 degrees have been added to all STEREO A EUVI longitudes to translate to Earth-facing disk coordinates].

cmeAnalyses.note: Measurement based on best fit between SOHO LASCO C2, C3, and STEREO A COR2 as well as the location of the source filament eruption as seen in available UV imagery of the disk.

note: Slow, narrow and faint CME to the southwest, mostly seen in SOHO LASCO C2 and covered by a data gap in STEREO A COR2. No source has been found.

cmeAnalyses.note: No source has been found for this CME and it is completely covered by a data gap in STEREO A imagery, so only plane-of-sky analysis is possible.

note: Faint, wide, multi-front streamer blowout CME seen to the NW in SOHO LASCO C2/C3. A data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2025-02-21T15:53Z to 2025-02-22T03:23Z completely covers this CME. The source is not discernable on the Earth-facing disk and is likely farsided.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky measurement using several frames of SOHO LASCO C2 and C3. Tricky to track the same leading edge between C2 and C3, since there are several slow loops that emerge in C2 and eventually merge into one brighter loop by the time C3's field of view is reached. There is also a data gap in STEREO A COR2 from 2025-02-21T15:53Z to 2025-02-22T03:23Z which completely covers this CME.

note: A loop CME seen to the northwest in SOHO LASCO but partially obscured by pylon in C3 and covered by the 202-02-21T15:53Z-2025-02-22T03:23Z gap in STEREO A COR2. Ira aource is likely a minor activity close to the NW limb (possibly in AR 3989 located at N19W90 at the time on in AR 4001 that is also close to the NW limb), manifesting as the opening/movement of field lines on/close to the NW limb that is seen in SDO AIA 193/171 and GOES SUVI 284 EUV imagery.

cmeAnalyses.note: Very approximate one-coronagraph (SOHO LASCO) coronagraph analysis based on the very approximate/uncertain source location (minor activity on/near the NW limb).

note: A very faint narrow outflow/front, faintly seen in SOHO LASCO and STEREO A COR2, with no clear source.

cmeAnalyses.note: Analysis based on the fit with two coronagraphs, in the absence of clear source.

note: A fuzzy front seen in SOHO LASCO C2, but covered by the pylon in C3. The source is likely the C8.3 flare from AR 4001 (N24W76) peaking at 2025-02-22T21:07Z, and an associated very minor dimming/post eruptive arcades seen in AIA 193 and GOES SUVI 284 at the time.

cmeAnalyses.note: One-coronagraph analysis (with SOHO LASCO), based on the location of the likely source (associated flare).

note: A fuzzy front to the southwest seen in SOHO LASCO. The source could be a narrow opening of field lines on/behind the SW limb seen in AIA 193.

cmeAnalyses.note: Plane-of-sky analysis made while there is no STEREO A imagery.
